PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition by the undersigned people strongly opposes the introduction of the numbered I.D. card system.
This system is totally unnecessary as adequate means of identification already exist and it is also a threat to our civil liberties and the privacy of everybody.

In the present bad economic climate there is no justification for wasting millions of dollars to force people to get unnecessary extra identification. We therefore ask that the Senate reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The high interest rates on home loans of 13.5 per cent has and is placing the recipients in a financially disastrous position, as thousands have lost their homes and thousands more will do so if these appalling conditions continue for the young and established home purchasers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge politicians that therefore no government or opposition in a power position should continue to tolerate this cruel, vicious procedure that shatters the very structure of family life.

We need a five year period to reduce this absurdity by tackling it at its source. Firstly, interest repayments on home loans to be reduced by 2 per cent annually for the next five years or until it is down to 6 per cent.
This would, or should diminish union demands, and cause no hazard for investors, who could reinvest in Government projects, or other worthwhile ventures and also ease the burden on Social Securities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross in an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Mining Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy, expanding gold mining industry;
(ii) the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations;

(iii) the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and will therefore cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights, Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possible cure.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate should: completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67 000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 115 citizens), Peter Baume (from 399 citizens), Brownhill (from 264 citizens), Mason (from 789 citizens) and McIntosh (from 266 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a need for an Independent and Multi-Cultural Broadcasting Corporation to give a firm legislative and financial basis for the SBS Network.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should
Pass Senator Vigor's Bill with all expediency
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Macklin (from 34 citizens), Mason (from 438 citizens) and Vigor (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Accident
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster on 26 April 1986, the Soviet Union has not yet adequately explained to its citizens of those of the Soviet-occupied Baltic States, Ukraine and other areas affected by the radiation fall-out the potential short-term and long-term health hazards and the available modes of prevention or reduction of radiation poisoning. Neither have the appropriate medicines for substitution therapies to minimise bodily accumulation of radioactive elements been adequately provided.

2. That the Soviet Union operates many nuclear power stations without the elementary structural safeguards against radioactive spillage regarded as mandatory in the West. Of particular concern is the safety of the largest Soviet nuclear power station at Ignalina in Soviet occupied Lithuania, of similar design to Chernobyl, which already has a record of operational problems. Radioactive spillage at Ignalina would quickly contaminate the whole of Latvia, Lithuania as well as vast areas of Europe.
We request that the Australian Government will:
1. Through the World Health Organization, provide medical aid and broadcast medical information to the victims of radiation exposure following the Chernobyl disaster.
2. Through the United Nations Organisation request the Soviet Union
(a) to close down all nuclear power stations similar to Chernobyl till protective structures are built.
(b) permit international inspection of such safety structures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing
that Australia should not host nuclear weapons in its territory or in Australian waters; and
that the presence of nuclear armed warships makes a priority target of the ports being visited; and
that the safety precautions for handling and deployment of nuclear weapons are inadequate to guarantee safety from accidents; and
that the malfunction of the reactor on board a nuclear powered vessel could irradiate a large area of the surrounding environs.
Therefore call upon the Australian Government to:
prohibit the entry of nuclear weapons to Australia; and to
deny access to Australian ports of vessels which are nuclear powered; and to
deny access to Australian ports of foreign warships unless an assurance is received that they are not carrying nuclear nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Accident
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
1. The Australian government exert pressure on Moscow to-
a. Allow the International Atomic Energy Commission full expert investigation of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and its human consequences;
b. Allow Australian Ukrainians to send medical aid to family and friends in Soviet Ukraine; and,
c. Allow free communication between Australian and Soviet Ukrainians.
2. The Australian Government-
a. Launch a public appeal to help the Chernobyl victims;
b. Support the removal of Russian nuclear weapons out of Ukraine;
c. Support the decolonization of the USSR so that captive nations like Ukraine and the Baltic States are not exploited for Soviet Russian nuclear purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the fringe benefits tax will place enormous cost increases on employers throughout Australia;
(ii) in so doing, the fringe benefits tax will raise the cost of employing labour particularly in remote locations and it will inevitably worsen the already high level of unemployment in Australia;
(iii) much of the cost of the tax will be carried by employees as employers reduce benefits; and
(iv) the cost of the tax will harm small business particularly as these businesses will be unable to pass on the cost of the tax and as a result many may be forced to close.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Government to repeal this unfair tax before it damages Australian business and thereby reduces the standard of living of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Honourable members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your Budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.

PETITION.TITLE: Prohibition of Exportation of Uranium to France Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that the only activity now taking place in the South Pacific which the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty bans is the testing of nuclear weapons by France at Mururoa and that the export of uranium by Australia to France undermines the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

urge the Government to adhere to the Australian Labor Party's policy, as set out in the Customs Amendment (Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France) Bill which prohibits the supply of uranium to France until France stops testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the fringe benefits tax will place a costly and unfair burden on independent schools.

The fringe benefits tax will have the most damaging impact upon schools which provide boarding accommodation for children as they are also required to provide accommodation for staff members to live in and supervise the boarders. Independent schools have limited resources and this additional impost will ultimately have to be passed onto parents, many of whom are already heavily committed to the financing of their children's education.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Parliament to recognize that the future of Australia depends upon the education given to its children and to exempt schools from the operation of the fringe benefits tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australian showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 739 citizens), Crichton-Browne (from 28 citizens) and Knowles (from seven citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of `X' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects. And your petitioners as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Hour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that any decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to reduce the local content of the programme, the `Country Hour', would represent yet another severe blow to Western Australian rural people;
that even under current programming Western Australian country people receive little locally produced radio, and

in view of the inefficiencies in the operations of the ABC disclosed by the Auditor-General, your petitioners call upon the Government to improve the efficient operation of the ABC before it reduces the local content of important rural programmes such as the `Country Hour'.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed cuts to the functions of the Human Rights Commission.

In particular the undersigned believe that the Human Rights Commission or any body that may replace it in December must be allocated adequate resources for complaint handling and community education in the areas of human rights and equal opportunity. The functions at present carried by the Human Rights Commission and the additional responsibilities relating to ILO Conventions III require increased resources if the rights of Australian citizens are to be safeguarded effectively, particularly in States and Territories which at present lack anti-discrimination legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BAUME; BAUME; BROWNHILL; MACKLIN; MASON; VIGOR
PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned concerned Australian citizens hereby petition the Honourable Senators to totally reject the current proposals for an I.D. Card and the proposed Data Protection Agency.

We believe that they represent potentially undesirable interference in the lives of honest Australians. Provisions for protection of individual privacy cannot be guaranteed as Statutes are easily altered by future Governments.

We believe that there are more efficient methods to prevent fraud in the areas of taxation and social security without the use of these two proposals, which go well beyond the reach of the true role of democratic government. i.e. That citizens may live quiet and peaceable lives. The I.D. Card and Data Protection Agency have strong potential under this or future administrations to interfere with the quiet and peaceable lives of its subjects.
We, your humble petitioners, in duty bound ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 18 citizens), Peter Baume (from 18 citizens), Brownhill (from 18 citizens), Macklin (from 18 citizens), Mason (from 18 citizens) and Vigor (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Khao-I-Dang Refugee Camp: Thailand
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Thai government recently announced that Khao-I-Dang refugee camp will be closed on 31st December, 1986. More than 25,000 Cambodian refugees who survived the `Killing Fields' of the Khmer Rouge and entered Thailand after 1979 are still resident in Khao-I-Dang. We hold grave fears for the future and safety of these refugees who will be relocated to camps along the Thai-Cambodian border when Khao-I-Dang is closed.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should uphold its enviable humanitarian record and act with all haste to facilitate the acceptance and resettlement of as many of these refugees as possible, including a proportion of those who have no relatives to sponsor them.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Mason (from 534 citizens) and Zakharov (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Charge
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the imposition of the $250.00 Administrative charge will:
(1) Prove a disincentive for all students-particularly part-time and mature age students-from continuing their tertiary studies.
(2) Lead to higher levels of youth unemployment as fewer students will now enrol in tertiary studies.
(3) Impose economic hardship upon the student population at large.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should
Vote to reject the imposition of the administrative charge, or, at the very least, vote to impose a lower fee on students who are not full-time.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Centre, Exmouth, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

The geographically isolated town of Exmouth, Western Australia, desperately needs a funded child care centre to care for the children of isolated families, single and deserted parents, transient families, working parents and itinerants. There is no relief for housebound mothers and mothers in caravan parks or any facilities for the care of children when parents are sick or hospitalized. Exmouth is unique inasmuch as most residents are young transient families (approximately 2 years stay) with no extended family support which places great stress on the family unit.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes for Senator Button) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to the payment of subsidy in respect of certain fertilisers.
Bill presented by Senator Grimes, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum, and I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes revised assistance arrangements for fertilisers as announced by the Treasurer in his 1986-87 budget speech and amalgamates the Nitrogenous Fertilisers Subsidy and the Phosphate Fertilisers Subsidy into one Act.

Under the new arrangements subsidy will no longer be payable on imported phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers. The expenditure saved from this decision has however been re-allocated to increase the subsidy rates on the consumption of locally produced phosphatic fertilisers particularly higher analysis phosphate products in recognition of modern trends in fertiliser usage.
The Government is concerned that subsidy benefits will continue to be passed on in full to the consumers. Accordingly this Bill contains strengthened provisions designed to effect this end.

The objective of the Government's policy changes is to bring some rationale to the subsidisation of fertiliser consumption. It is most unusual to subsidise imports at any time and certainly inappropriate in the light of Australia's current trading position. The changes are therefore designed to provide benefits to the balance of payments, to bring some benefits to manufacturers in the form of increased price competitiveness and at the same time avoid disadvantaging the rural sector.

The decision to withdraw subsidies from imported fertilisers followed long and careful consideration of all the issues involved and consultation with all interested parties. The Industries Assistance Commission studied the industry and reported in October 1985. This was followed by a study by an interdepartmental working group of officers from the Departments of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Primary Industry and the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
Perhaps more than with any other issue, the Government has faced a difficult task in trying to reconcile the interests of the producers and users of this important commodity.

Subsidies on fertilisers represent an important element of the Government's support for the rural sector. The changes contained in this Bill reflect the Government's strong commitment to that sector and our desire to ensure that the support should be directed in the most efficient manner possible.

In the economic and rural policy statement delivered earlier this year we said: `The overall cost of fertilisers will not rise as a result of any decisions that may flow from the Government's consideration of the interdepartmental review or Professor Gruen's review of the Customs (Anti-dumping) Legislation'. We also said that the amount of funding available for fertiliser subsidies would be maintained over the life of the scheme and the appropriations for 1986-87 reflect that commitment. Unlike funding for production bounties which was reduced by 20 per cent in the Budget, funding for fertiliser consumption subsidies has been maintained at $55m per annum.

Consequently, the amount previously used to subsidise imports has been reallocated to the consumption of domestically produced phosphatic fertilisers. In doing this the Government has taken particular note of the growing preference of farmers for higher analysis fertilisers by weighting the increase in the subsidies towards these products.

Clause 12 of the Bill sets out the increased subsidy on Australian phosphate fertilisers during the 3-year period of the new scheme. These rates are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.

Subsidy payable on nitrogenous fertiliser remains at $20 per tonne of nitrogen content. We have not increased the subsidy on nitrogen because the amount per unit would be negligible, however nitrogen users who use fertiliser mixtures will benefit from the increased subsidy on phosphorus. As a result of these changes, the majority of farmers now pay less for their fertilisers. All manufacturers reduced their prices following the Budget, in some cases after also cancelling previously announced price rises. The price of single superphosphate has generally fallen by $1.30 per tonne and the reductions for the more concentrated phosphatic fertilisers have ranged up to $11 per tonne. This is because subsidy rates have increased by between 10 and 35 per cent.

Industry has responded by increasing its output of these concentrated, high analysis fertilisers, to meet the demands of farmers seeking to take advantage of the increased subsidies. The Government has also taken separate action to remove a potential impediment to this change in the manufacturers' product mix. The potentially prohibitive import duty on phosphoric acid used in fertiliser production was removed on 1 November 1986.

There have been claims that there is insufficient manufacturing capacity in Australia to meet all the requirements of farmers for fertiliser. Both the IAC in its report on the industry and the Department of Primary Industry in its booklet `Chemical Fertilisers in Australia' have concluded that the domestic manufacturers do have the necessary phosphatic production capacity.

Some farmers, however, will no doubt continue to rely on imported products. I understand that most importers have not raised their prices since the Budget, choosing instead to absorb the effects of the removal of subsidy. The main importers are backed by large corporations, in some cases American fertiliser manufacturers, and are not the small companies which some commentators would have us believe.
The imported price is of course a world price and still a dumped one at that. The Government will continue however to provide grants which offset the effects of dumping duties on fertilisers.

The Bill includes provisions in parts 3, 4 and 5, updating the old legislation to improve administrative effectiveness, in line with similar provisions recently introduced in other subsidy and bounty legislation.

It is possible that competition from imports will decline during the next 3 years, or that suspicions might arise among the rural sector that manufacturers are not passing on the full benefit of the subsidies. This Bill strengthens the statutory requirements to ensure that manufacturers do continue to pass on the subsidy. Provisions at clauses 10 and 22 permit the Comptroller-General of Customs to direct that subsidy not be paid to a producer if the producer is not passing on the full benefit of the subsidy and require an appropriate undertaking to be given prior to registration for subsidy purposes. The previous law only contained a provision similar to clause 10.
In addition to this, the Government is at present considering revised guidelines against which proposed price increases are assessed, to take account of the new subsidy arrangements.
We believe the new arrangements proposed by this legislation to be in the long term interests of Australian farmers.
Financial Impact Statement

The subsidies proposed by this Bill are expected to cost $55m per annum for the next 3 years. The changes proposed by this Bill will not alter expenditure on current fertiliser subsidies as the subsidies previously paid on imports have been reallocated across locally produced phosphatic fertilisers in the form of higher subsidy rates on those products.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes for Senator Button) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to provide for the payment of bounty on the production, by way of repair, of certain ships.
Bill presented by Senator Grimes, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum, and I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is part of a new ship repair assistance package announced by the Government on 10 October 1986, following consideration of a report on the Australian ship repair industry by a quadripartite working group established in June 1984.

The major elements of the package are a bounty payable to registered ship repairers and the clarification of the Government's powers of enforcement in its ship safety inspections to give effect to internationally accepted health and safety standards.
This Bill proposes the introduction of the cash limited bounty scheme to apply to eligible repairs undertaken by registered ship repairers in Australia.
Its companion which I will introduce in a few moments proposes amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 to effect that part of the arrangements relating to safety inspection.

Australian ship repairers face a severe cost disability in relation to overseas repairers. There is significant excess repair capacity in Australia mainly resulting from the failure of the industry to invest in contemporary technologies and to adopt efficient work practices.

Ship repair and maritime unions concerned about the industry's continuing decline and the use of sub-standard shipping in Australian waters have been conducting a campaign to gain additional ship repair work. This has involved detaining vessels and insisting on repairs which in the view of the unions will remove the sub-standard conditions on board.
These practices have damaged the reputation of the ship repair industry and our reputation as a reliable trading partner.

The working group I referred to earlier comprising representatives of trade unions, Government, shipowners and ship repairers made several recommendations aimed at increasing the throughput and efficiency of Australian ship repairers. It agreed that any plan of action for the industry must be accompanied by widespread improvement in terms of better work practices and lower costs. It therefore proposed a package approach under which Commonwealth assistance would be conditional upon commitments from the parties involved.

I am happy to say that since the working party reported a series of discussions have been held with the industry and the unions and all parties have agreed to accept the proposed package. This agreement represents a significant contribution by both the industry and trade unions; indeed the ship repair and maritime unions have agreed to end their detention campaign as a pre-condition to the implementation of the package. I should mention however that the Bill contains a provision at clause 11 to enable the Minister to cease all bounty payments under the Act should the union campaign be re-activated. This may apply regardless of whether the campaign is wide spread or directed at one particular vessel. Decisions of the Minister in this regard will not be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Government believes that review by that body is inappropriate in this case as any decision will involve high level industrial relations policy issues.
As part of its contribution the Government will:

(1) Extend the Department of Transport's official ship safety inspection system to give effect to internationally accepted health and safety standards based on the international Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention 147.
(2) Allow those parts which enter Australia duty free when for use in the construction or modification or ships to also enter duty free when for use in ship repair; and
(3) Introduce registration criteria to be met by ship repairers before being eligible for bounty.

The proposed bounty in this Bill will be limited to $6m over the next 3 years with bounty payable at a rate of 30 per cent of contract price where eligible repairs cost between $100,000 and $400,000 and 20 per cent for that part exceeding $400,000. Bounty will only be paid to registered repairers for certain repairs to international trading vessels of at least 6,000 dead weight tonnes, whether Australian or foreign owned.
Eligible repairs fall to the following categories-
(a) Dry docking (including structural repairs and painting)
(b) Engine repairs, modifications or conversions
(c) Ship systems, which include repairs, modifications or conversions to:
Electronic systems;
Electrical systems;
Communications systems; and
Hydraulic systems; and
(d) Accommodation refurbishment or upgrading.

Under the eligibility for bounty provisions in clause 10, Australian repairers will be required to enter into repair or service contracts with the owners of eligible ships, and because of the bounty limit of $6m in clause 12 they will be required to reserve amounts available for the payment of bounty in respect of the repairs carried out pursuant to those contracts. This should encourage more planned repairs to be performed in Australia, and at the same time, ensure that amounts will be available for the payment of bounty to those repairers who undertake eligible repair work.

Clause 12 of the Bill contains provisions similar to those currently operating in relation to shipbuilding concerning the reservation of bounty. As in the shipbuilding scheme bounty will be allocated to repairers on a `first come first served' basis. Those not on the reservation list will be unlikely to receive bounty. Preference for reservation will be given to persons who are to repair pursuant to written contracts followed by those who will repair on the basis of other than written contracts. Provision has also been made for the regulations to prescribe maximum amounts that may be reserved in relation to repair or service contracts.

I mentioned that part of the Government's ship repair package is the introduction of registration criteria for the purposes of bounty eligibility. To be eligible to receive bounty, repairers will have to meet strict registration criteria including codes of business and industrial relations practices.

The development of these criteria, which will be set out in the regulations, will require detailed analysis of the industry and close consultation with unions, employers and some State governments. I am also expanding the shipbuilding consultative group to include a representative of the repair industry to assist in this matter.

The Government believes that introduction of this assistance package will facilitate industry rationalisation and encourage the development of markets which do not currently exist for Australian repairers. It will restore predictability to the industry and improve efficiency within the ship repair industry.

Finally, parts 3, 4 and 5 of the Bill include a number of standard administrative provisions, which are modelled on similar provisions in other recent bounty and subsidy legislation. These provisions are designed to not only assist the expeditious processing of claims, but also to ensure that proper verification and investigation of claims can proceed where necessary.
Financial Impact Statement
The cost of the bounty assistance to the ship repair industry is limited by clause 12 to $6m over the next 3 years. The relevant appropriation for the financial year 1986-87 is $1.5m.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes for Senator Button) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Navigation Act 1912.
Bill presented by Senator Grimes, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
In presenting the Bounty (Ship Repair) Bill 1986, I foreshadowed the contribution to the ship repair assistance package to be made by the Transport portfolio.

The Navigation Amendment Bill 1986 addresses the issue of substandard ships plying Australian waters, giving the Minister the power to detain a ship on which conditions are such as to present, in the words of the International Labour Organisation's Convention No. 147, `a clear hazard to safety or health.'

The amendment is necessary because the existing powers of detention provided by the Navigation Act 1912 apply only to ships that are unseaworthy, as defined. The term `unseaworthy' has a traditional and internationally understood meaning which does not extend to hazards of the kind that this Bill is concerned with.

Following passage of the Bill, the various criteria warranting detention of a ship as substandard will be finalised in tripartite consultation with industry, based on the safety and health standards established by the International Labour Organisation and included in Convention No. 147. These criteria will be published as a Marine Order under the Navigation Act and will govern the Minister's discretion to detain a ship. The Marine Order will, as is customary, be tabled in the manner of a statutory rule for the scrutiny of the Parliament.
A ship detained under the provisions of this Bill may continue to be detained until the clear hazard to safety or health is corrected.
Financial Impact Statement
There will be no significant costs, revenues or savings to the Government arising from the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISABILITY SERVICES BILL 1986DISABILITY SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motions (by Senator Grimes)-by leave-agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to the provision of services for persons with disabilities.

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to enact certain transitional provisions and make certain amendments in consequence of the enactment of the Disability Services Act 1986, and for other purposes.
Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Bills (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.
Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

It is with great satisfaction that I introduce the Disability Services Bill. The Bill represents the culmination of sustained effort by a broad cross-section of those many people, both within and outside government, concerned for the future of people with disabilities and families which contain a person with a disability. Honourable senators will recall that during the International Year of Disabled Persons 1981 there was a tremendous surge of interest in the potential, needs, and problems of people with disabilities and the general dissatisfaction with traditional services provided in such areas as accommodation, employment and living skills. On attaining office, this Government decided that there was a need for fundamental change in the way the community provides for the needs of people with disabilities and that a truly comprehensive review of all Commonwealth policies and programs was required. Accordingly, in late 1983, the Government instigated the Handicapped Programs Review to examine all Commonwealth programs and services directed at assisting people with disabilities. This Review was the first of its kind in Australia. It sought submissions from interested groups and individuals and held extensive community consultation, especially with people with disabilities, their families, and service providers. The Bill before us is based on the findings of that Review, the report of which, entitled `New Directions', I tabled in Parliament on 30 May 1985.

The report found broad community support for the Commonwealth's policies of meeting needs through mainstream community programs as far as possible, and the ensuring that the least restrictive alternative principle is followed where specific services are required for people with disabilities. Where specific services were required, the Review emphasised that the fundamental criterion in service provision should be the actual outcomes achieved for people with disabilities who are the users of those services-that is, the consumers.

The report concluded that substantial improvements were required in the accountability of subsidised organisations for service content and quality, and that major changes were needed in the programs themselves to reflect this consumer outcomes focus. A restructuring of services, funding and other resources was also required.

The Review believed that these changes could be effected only through legislative change, particularly the replacement of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 and the introduction of new legislation based on the principle that positive consumer outcomes should be the rationale for program development, delivery and review. On 12 June this year I made a statement in the Senate on the Government's intention to introduce new legislation in these parliamentary sittings, and in that statement I outlined the purposes and scope of the proposed Bill. This Bill honours that commitment. The Disability Advisory Council of Australia and the Office of Disability have played a major role in the development of the legislation. The establishment of the Office of Disability was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in December 1984, with a role which includes carrying forward the thrust of the `New Directions' report.
Purposes and Objects
The new legislation, intended to take effect as from 1 July 1987, will serve a number of purposes:

First, the Bill provides the future legislative basis for the provision of financial assistance to organisations conducting services for people with disabilities to replace the present source of assistance, namely, the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, which, apart from certain provisions, will be repealed; the Bill also provides a basis, for the first time under this program, of assisting States for similar purposes;

Second, it provides a specific legislative base for two related sub-programs-the program upgrading scheme and assistance for people with print disabilities-by incorporating them into the new legislation;

Third, it provides for the funding and other mechanisms by means of which existing subsidised services under certain conditions may continue to receive financial support while upgrading to meet the more stringent requirements of the new legislation;

Fourth, it introduces greater protection for the interests of both the Commonwealth and people with disabilities who are the users of subsidised services; this is achieved by a variety of provisions and features of the Bill, including a requirement that all services be formally reviewed at intervals of no more than 5 years;

Fifth, it provides for a range of activities, such as program related research and development, intended to ensure that services funded under the program are designed to suit the changing needs of people with disabilities;
Sixth, the Bill provides a new legislative base for the provision of rehabilitation services by the Commonwealth currently provided for under Part VIII of the Social Security Act 1947.

The Bill contains an explicit statement of its objects which will guide the interpretation and administration of the new Act. These are couched in terms of the benefits and objectives desired to be achieved for individual people with disabilities and reflect the philosophical position of the Government outlined in the draft principles and objectives attached to my statement of 12 June 1986 and refined in the consultation process since then in relation to people who experience double disadvantage because of sex, ethnic origin or Aboriginality. It is my intention that these principles and objectives be formalised and be gazetted and so brought within the ambit of the legislation. These principles and objectives will form the basic yardstick for the development of the program. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PRINCIPLES AND OBJECTIVES
Principles
1. People with disabilities are individuals who have the inherent right to respect for their human worth and dignity.
2. People with disabilities, whatever the origin, nature, type and degree of disability, have the same fundamental rights as all members of Australian society.
3. Every person with a disability has the same rights as other members of Australian society to realise his or her individual capacity for physical, social, emotional and intellectual development.
4. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to services which will support their attaining an acceptable quality of life.
5. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to participate in the decisions which affect their lives.
6. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to the least restrictive alternative in the services they receive.
7. People with disabilities have the same right of pursuit of any grievance as have other members of Australian society in relation to the services which they receive.
These Principles may be translated into objectives for service delivery as follows:
Objectives
1. That the focus of service delivery to people with disabilities should be the achievement of positive outcomes.

2. That services for people with disabilities should ensure that the conditions of the every-day life of people with disabilities are the same as, or as close as possible to, norms and patterns which are valued in the general community.
3. That services for people with disabilities should be provided as part of local co-ordinated service systems and integrated with generic services wherever possible.
4. That people with disabilities should receive services which are tailored to their individual needs and goals.
5. That programs and services should reflect the needs of people with disabilities who experience double disadvantage as a result of sex, ethnic origin, and Aboriginality.
6. That programs and services should promote a competent and positive image of people with disabilities.
7. That programs and services should promote the participation of people with disabilities in the life of the local community through maximum physical and social integration.
8. That no single organisation providing services should exercise control over all or most aspects of the life of an individual with disabilities.
9. That services providing assistance to people with disabilities, be they specific or generic, should be accountable to consumers and their representatives, funding bodies and the public at large.

10. That programs and services should provide opportunities for people with disabilities to reach goals and enjoy lifestyles which are valued by the community at large and are appropriate to their chronological age.
11. That people with disabilities should have access to advocacy support where necessary to ensure adequate participation in decision-making about the services they receive.
12. That services should provide appropriate avenues for people with disabilities to air and resolve any grievances about the services they receive.

13. That people with disabilities should be provided with avenues for participating in the planning and operation of individual services and opportunities for consultation relating to major policy development and program changes.
14. That services for people with disabilities should respect an individual's rights of privacy and confidentiality.
In the above references, individuals with disabilities should be read to include advocates and families of children with disabilities where appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The principles and objectives to which I have referred will become integral to the administration of the programs under this new legislation. I also emphasise here that these principles and objectives reflect the Government's belief about how all services for people with disabilities ought to be developed and delivered-not simply those services to be supported under the present Bill. Accordingly, we will be encouraging their use across all relevant programs and services for people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Other Key Features

The Bill brings together two related programs within my portfolio. Part II of the Bill deals with the provision of financial assistance to organisations, and States, conducting services for people with disabilities, and is directed at implementing the thrust of the New Directions report as far as this program is concerned and overcoming the deficiencies inherent in the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974. Part III deals with the operations of the rehabilitation services program. The new provisions associated with Part II have the following important features.
Target Group

First, there is a clearly and consistently defined target group which will remove doubt about the intended users of services receiving Commonwealth support under this program. To qualify for assistance under the new provisions, services must be predominantly for persons who have a disability deriving from intellectual, sensory or physical impairment, or a combination of these; whose disability is permanent or likely to be permanent; and whose disability results in a substantially reduced capacity for communication, learning or mobility and a need for on-going support under Part II. There may be some funded organisations which presently provide services to people who do not predominantly fit the target group. These services will not come under the new legislation but separate carry-on funding will be provided for them until alternative arrangements can be made. It is recognised that some agencies have included in their services small numbers of people who do not come within the target group definition; these services will nevertheless be able to come within the new legislation and this will be reflected in the guidelines.
Eligible Services

To ensure the legislation remains flexible and responsive to the needs of people with disabilities over time, the Bill adopts an innovative approach to endorsing the various service types which may in future attract financial assistance. Under the Bill, the Minister may approve specified kinds of services from a comprehensive list, but the Minister may also approve other classes of services which would further the objective of the new Act-thus overcoming one of the major deficiencies in the present Act. To provide for parliamentary scrutiny, these approvals will be gazetted and subject to disallowance provisions in the same way as regulations.
Organisations and Bodies Eligible for Financial Assistance

The Bill provides that both States and eligible organisations may qualify for financial assistance for the provision of eligible services. The inclusion of States is a major change; it reflects the fact that most States are already involved to varying degrees in service provision, and the many potential opportunities for co-operative efforts in this field. The new legislation will permit the Commonwealth to provide funds to the States for services provided by them covered under the legislation. The intention is that such funding be provided on similar conditions to those relating to eligible organisations. The legislation will also permit the joint Commonwealth-State funding of services and projects considered as being of joint interest. This will overcome a major restriction of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 and will enable a more co-ordinated effort on behalf of people with disabilities who are part of the target group-for example in relation to the provision of housing or meeting the needs of people with more severe disabilities.

The types of organisations which will be eligible for financial assistance for the provision of services under the new Act will be broadly similar to those eligible under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, although some changes have been included to meet current circumstances. One significant change is that self-help groups will be eligible provided they intend to seek incorporation. Generally, formal incorporation will be expected of all ordinary service providers. The not-for-profit motive remains as a general requirement, local governing bodies continue to be eligible, and in future recognised tertiary institutions will also be eligible. There will be capacity for the Minister to approve other not-for-profit bodies if that furthers the purposes of the Act.
Positive Client Outcome Focus

The Bill has been drafted to ensure that the focus of funding and administration remains on the achievement of desirable outcomes for people with disabilities. This is reflected in particular in the inclusion of a statement of objects of the Bill; the provision for the gazettal of principles and objectives to be furthered, and guidelines to be complied with, in the administration of the legislation; the new definitions of the basic service types; the new mechanisms for approving eligible classes of services generally; the comprehensive provisions relating to the actual making of grants and the terms and conditions which may attach to the financial assistance, including specific reference to agreed client outcomes; and the statutory requirement that all funded services be subject to a formal review against these agreed client outcome objectives. These various provisions meet the central concerns of the handicapped program review in relation to the disability services program.
Mode of Administration

The Bill has been drafted for flexibility and economy of administration. The basic approach taken in relation to Part II is that the Act should set the basic parameters, leaving the more important administrative detail to be dealt with by means of gazetted instruments and regulations which would be subject to the scrutiny of Parliament. Regulations will cover such matters as the detailed funding formulae to apply to the various service types, including transitional funding provisions.
Introduction Strategy and Transitional Provisions for Existing Services

The approach adopted by the Government to introducing fundamental changes in the program addressed by Part II is to have the Bill provide for both the new program structure and the means by which existing subsidised services can, under acceptable conditions, be upgraded and progressively transferred into the new structure.

Any services for which initial funding is sought after the intended date of commencement of this Part of the Act, that is, 1 July 1987, naturally will be expected to meet the more rigorous standards of the new program immediately. Existing services will need both time and possibly additional support to enable them to make the transition and this is recognised and made possible within the strategy of the Bill. The structure of Part II provides for these two levels of operation and the transition process-with Divisions 1 and 2 essentially providing the framework for the new program and Division 3 that for the upgrading and transition of existing services into the new program over a maximum five-year period.

As mentioned in my June 1986 statement, a major consultancy has been commenced so that detailed funding formulae for the new program can be developed. Because of the nature of the task and the need for the Government to consider any new proposals, it is not expected that new formulae can be implemented before 1 July 1988. In the interim, the Government intends that, as with services within the transitional provisions, funding be the same as currently provided under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, plus increased base staff subsidy which will also be provided to existing services under certain conditions. As with transitional funding for existing services, this will be dealt with by regulation. The increase in base staff subsidy was referred to in my statement on disability services made in the context of the August 1986 Budget tabled in the Senate on 17 September 1986. This initiative will cost $21m in a full year.

The intention of the Government is that the new funding formulae to support the new program on an ongoing basis will be responsive to differing client needs and the needs of the different service types. I believe such an approach has the in-principle support of service providers, most of whom recognise, as the Government does, the irrationality, inequities and disincentives associated with the traditional funding approach of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974-which did not recognise the different resourcing needs associated with different levels of disability and service types. This has tended to discourage the provision of adequate services to people with disabilities requiring higher levels of support and the introduction of innovative services. The Government is looking to the new formulae being developed to help correct this bias and other deficiencies of the current funding provisions identified in the handicapped programs review, including the potential for providing incentives for performance in the achievement of positive client outcomes. The upgrading and transfer of existing services progressively into the new program will be a significant task and a strategy has been developed to accomplish this which in recent weeks has been the focus of extensive consultations with consumer groups, service providers and representatives of State governments across Australia.
Briefly, the transition strategy for existing services involves the following components:

Early in 1987, existing services will be invited to indicate that, subject to meeting the target group criteria, they are willing to negotiate new service contracts. These contracts will include commitment to the principles and objectives and to specific outcomes that will be achieved with additional assistance to be provided where the basic staff subsidy of 50 per cent is increased to 65 per cent.

From the commencement of the Act on 1 July 1987, those services which enter into the new service contracts will continue to receive ongoing support at current Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 levels plus the additional staff subsidy component. These services will be referred to in the Act as prescribed services.

With the introduction of the new funding formulae, these prescribed services will be progressively brought within the new program structure. This will be subject to their meeting certain conditions that demonstrate a capacity to comply with the principles and objectives, to meet the more stringent requirements, and to achieve acceptable positive client outcomes.
Prescribed services which have been brought under these transitional provisions but fail to meet their upgrading and restructuring obligations will not be funded beyond 30 June 1992.

Where existing services are ineligible under the Act, by virtue of their client composition, the intention is that carry-on funding outside the Act will be provided under ministerial discretion pending the making of longer term arrangements for those services. This will be to ensure that the welfare of people with disabilities who use those services is not adversely affected.
Current services which are unwilling to commit themselves to meeting the new requirements will be funded outside the Act for a limited time.
The Provision of Rehabilitation Services by the Commonwealth

As I mentioned earlier, the Bill incorporates a new legislative base for the provision of rehabilitation services by the Commonwealth, currently provided through Part VIII of the Social Security Act 1947. This constitutes Part III of the Bill. These services are for people of working age requiring rehabilitation programs for a limited time to enhance their prospects of entering, re-entering or remaining in employment or living independently.

The main provisions of the current legislation are retained in Part III with some amendments having been introduced to enable a greater range of services to be provided, and to streamline the administration of the program. In particular, the Bill widens the scope of what may be provided to an eligible person, from `treatment and training' as it is currently described in the legislation to `a rehabilitation program'. This is consistent with the changes which are taking place in the delivery of rehabilitation services from a predominantly institutional and medically oriented base to a regional base which concentrates on social and vocational programs. The new definition will still allow my Department to arrange for the provision of treatment services where they are necessary, but it will also enable the provision of a wide range of other services which will assist people with disabilities in the target group for this program to reach their social or vocational goal. This, of course, includes an increased capacity to live independently.

The Bill will also enable support to be provided, by way of work place modifications or special equipment, to assist people with disabilities to retain their employment; this assistance is not possible under the existing legislation which was confined essentially to those people with disabilities who were unemployed. At the same time, the Bill will enable the Secretary to charge for all or part of the cost of a rehabilitation program where a client has the financial ability to meet that cost. Rehabilitation services will continue to be provided free to those relying on a pension or benefit for their income.

The removal of this legislation from the Social Security Act 1947 means that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal is no longer appropriate as an avenue of appeal to clients undertaking rehabilitation programs through my Department. Nevertheless, the Bill makes specific provision for clients of the rehabilitation services program to apply to the Secretary of the Department and subsequently to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of decisions with which they are dissatisfied.

The Bill also incorporates strict penalties for those disclosing information on clients and I believe that these penalties and the appeal rights which I have just mentioned are a further indication that this Bill recognises the rights of people with disabilities.
Program of Aids for People with Disabilities

In my June 1986 statement, I indicated that it was intended that the Bill would incorporate the Commonwealth's program of aids for disabled people-PADP. This program provides funds for the provision, through State and Territory health services infrastructures, of a range of aids to assist people with disabilities live in the community. Since my June parliamentary statement, and as referred to in my subsequent public statement on disability services issued at the time of the August 1986 Budget, the Commonwealth has been negotiating with the States on the implementation of new arrangements for Commonwealth aids assistance. As these negotiations are still proceeding, the Government has decided not to disturb the present legislative provisions for this program at this stage.
Financial Impact

It is expected that the Bill will be proclaimed to commence on 1 July 1987. It is estimated that expenditure on services for people with disabilities under this Bill will be of the order of $140m in 1987-88 and $152m in 1988-89. It is estimated that expenditure on the provision of rehabilitation services by the Commonwealth under this Bill will be $3.9m in 1987-88 and $6m in 1988-89.
Conclusion

The Disability Services Bill provides a new deal for people with disabilities-one in which there is a strong legislatively sanctioned framework for the maximisation of their potential through the provision of appropriate, responsive and well-managed services within a flexible program, with the proper recognition of their rights and dignity and opportunity for the fullest possible participation in the community. With this Bill and the related measures announced in the Budget, the Government believes it has honoured its commitment to reform one of its major program areas in accordance with the handicapped programs review. The Government has set the stage, and it will be up to all the players-Parliament, government, departments, service providers, people with disabilities, parents of people with disabilities and the community at large-to ensure that the spirit of the legislation is kept to the fore and acted upon. We have sought to establish a dynamic, responsive process which the community at large and all levels of government can use to meet the needs and aspirations of people with disabilities in positive and creative ways.

Finally, I take this opportunity to thank those many groups and individuals, including a great many people with disabilities, the Disability Advisory Council of Australia, the Office of Dis- ability, and officers of my Department, who have contributed in various ways to the shaping of the Bill. It truly reflects the spirit of consensus which the Government has sought to bring to the issues of importance to all Australians. I commend the Bill to the Senate, and I table the explanatory memorandum.
Mr President, I seek leave to have the second reading speech for the Disability Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill serves a number of purposes relating to the introduction of the Disability Services Bill 1986.

The main measures contained in the Bill are amendments to the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 and Part VIII of the Social Security Act 1947 consequential to the introduction of the Disability Services Bill.
This Bill will provide for the repeal of Parts II to VI of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 from the date of commencement of Part II of the Disability Services Act.

The repeal of Parts II to VI will prevent the making of any further grants under this Act in relation to capital projects, maintenance or rent of premises, acquisition of equipment, and the provision of recurrent funding in relation to staff. The financial assistance currently provided under these Parts will be provided under the new Disability Services Act upon its commencement.
This Bill will retain the current funding arrangements under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 in relation to the following three payments-
the handicapped children's benefit will continue to be paid to eligible organisations that provide approved residential accommodation for handicapped children;

training fees (a one-off payment of $500 for each sheltered employee who successfully moves to open employment) will continue to be paid to eligible organisations that provide sheltered employment; and
the open employment incentive bonus (a one-off payment of $500) will continue to be paid to a sheltered employee who successfully moves to open employment.

Funding arrangements for these payments will be retained so as not to disadvantage eligible organisations providing existing prescribed services and persons with disabilities who benefit from these services. However, these funding arrangements will be retained only until 30 June 1992, after which no further payments may be made under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974. This is also the date after which no further funding will be payable to prescribed services existing at the date of commencement of the Disability Services Act which have not made the transition to become eligible services under that Act.
This Bill will repeal those provisions of Part VIII of the Social Security Act 1947 made redundant by Part III of the Disability Services Act, from the date of commencement of that Act.

Rehabilitation allowance, paid in relation to certain persons undertaking a rehabilitation program under Part III of the Disability Services Act, will continue to be paid under Part VIII of the Social Security Act 1947.

This Bill will also make transitional arrangements in relation to certain matters arising under provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 and the Social Security Act 1947 repealed by this Bill as a consequence of the Disability Services Bill 1986.

This Bill will also amend the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971, the Defence (Re-establishment) Act 1965, the Re-establishment and Employment Act 1945, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, and the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986 to make amendments consequential to the introduction of the Disability Services Bill 1986.
This Bill is expected to involve no significant expenditure or savings. The net financial impact is expected to be neutral.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and table the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend four Commonwealth Acts to enable Australia to implement a number of anti-pollution initiatives and to improve aspects of the existing legislation. The Bill represents a further major step in marine pollution prevention and control in Australia.

Senators will be aware that the Government is committed to ensuring Australia's acceptance of conventions which have benefits for Australia and which will enhance our reputation internationally. Accordingly, our national transport policy supports the promotion, conclusion, ratification and application of transport conventions under the auspices of the United Nations and its specialised agencies, in particular the International Maritime Organisation (IMO).
