Since coming into office, the Hawke Government has demonstrated an active participation in the work of IMO. This is illustrated by Australia becoming a party to the following conventions:
International convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1974 and its 1978 protocol (entered into force for Australia in 1983);
the 1983 amendment to the International Convention on Load Lines 1966 (1984);

the International Convention relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties, 1969 and the Protocol relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Pollution by Substances Other Than Oil, 1973 (1983);
the International Convention of Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage, 1969 and its 1976 protocol (1983);
the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, 1978 (1983);
the International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue, 1979 (1983); and
the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, 1972 (1985).

As an island nation, Australia, with its extensive coastline and spread of territorial waters, possesses national assets of immense economic and recreational worth. Accordingly it is of fundamental importance that we face up to our responsibility and ensure that we continue to provide a high level of protection for our marine environment.

I believe this Bill has the capacity to further improve marine environment protection by prohibiting the discharge of harmful substances into the sea. It is incremental to and consistent with the approach taken by this Government towards the marine environment on previous occasions.

The Bill currently before the Senate contains amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 and the Navigation Act 1912, which will enable Australia to implement annexes III, IV and V of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 (MARPOL).
This will place Australia in a position to exercise control over the discharge of ship-sourced pollutants of all types.

MARPOL, as the 1973 Convention and its 1978 protocol are commonly known, is a significant departure from previous pollution conventions, as the one treaty addresses ship sourced pollution in all the various forms. Australia signed the convention, subject to ratification, in 1973.

Contracting states to MARPOL are obliged to apply Annexes I and II, which deal with oil and noxious liquid substances respectively. Annexes III, IV and V are optional and respectively deal with pollution by harmful substances carried in packaged form, sewage and garbage.
Legislation to bring annexes I and II of the Convention into force was passed by Federal Parliament in the autumn sittings of 1983, with bipartisan support.

Amending legislation extending the operation of the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act to include all ships in the Australian territorial sea and coastal waters also received bipartisan support and was passed in the autumn sittings 1986. The current Bill will enable Australia to fully implement the remaining requirements of this Convention.

I should point out that Marpol annexes III, IV and V will be implemented by way of complementary Commonwealth-State-Territory legislation in accordance with an agreement reached by Ministers of the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) and endorsed by the Government.

The annexes, therefore, will be accepted by Australia when all the necessary legislation is enacted by all governments and they will enter into force for Australia when the annexes enter into force internationally.

Annexes III, IV and V of Marpol will each enter into force internationally 12 months after the date on which a minimum number of 15 states, with not less than 50 per cent of the gross tonnage of the world's merchant shipping, become party to them.

Although these conditions have not yet been fulfilled, progress is being made and annexes III and V are expected to enter into force within the next 18 months. There is not as much international support for annex IV which could result in its entry into force being less certain.
I will briefly summarise the contents of annexes III, IV and V.

Annex III contains regulations for the prevention of pollution by harmful substances carried by sea in packaged forms, or in freight containers, portable tanks or road and rail tank wagons. The annex contains specific requirements relating to the packaging and carriage of such substances. Discharges by jettisoning of harmful substances is totally prohibited except where safety of life or the ship is involved.

The master or the owner of a ship is required to notify the appropriate authority at least 24 hours prior to loading or unloading such substances. To assist with the implementation of these requirements internationally, the international maritime dangerous goods code is being revised to cover pollution aspects.

I believe the evolutionary change of attitudes to environment protection is reflected in this Bill. With the introduction of these amendments, paragraph (c) of section 250 of the Navigation Act 1912 inserted in 1912 will now be removed.
This provision authorised the master of a ship to throw overboard any dangerous goods shipped without his knowledge and specifically exempted such a master from any liability whatsoever.
Annex IV of the Convention contains regulations for the prevention of pollution by sewage from ships, and applies to all ships over 200 gross tons or those certified to carry more than 10 persons.
All discharges of sewage from Australian ships are prohibited, except under conditions specified in the Bill. No discharges are permitted within the Great Barrier Reef area.

In addition to the discharge requirements, Annex IV contains requirements relating to periodical surveys, and the issue of an international sewage prevention certificate. Valid certificates must be carried on board a ship and be produced when a ship applies for clearance to leave an Australian port.

Annex V contains regulations for the prevention of pollution by garbage. The complete prohibition placed on the disposal into the sea of plastics, including synthetic ropes and fishing nets, is a feature of this annex.

Additionally, specific minimum distances have been set for the disposal of the principal types of garbage, including dunnage. The permissible degree of discharge is directly related to the degradability of the waste. Again, disposal of garbage in the Great Barrier Reef area is prohibited.
I believe that a significant effect of this annex will be a reduction in the quantity of litter and waste material which washes up on to our beaches and coastline.
From my own experience I know that the beaches in New South Wales, on occasions, suffer this problem.
The cleanliness of Australian beaches should be enhanced as a result of this legislation.

Additionally, there have been complaints from the fishing industry concerning the problems caused by the disposal of garbage at sea. In particular, concern regarding the fouling and consequent damage of fishing nets. For these reasons, I believe the controls proposed by this Bill will be welcomed by all concerned.

The introduction of these new controls into Commonwealth legislation is based on the legislative arrangements recommended by the Australian Transport Advisory Council, which requires that complementary Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory legislation be enacted before Australia can ratify annexes III, IV and V of Marpol. The proposal is therefore in accordance with long-standing arrangements between the Commonwealth, States and Northern Territory for control of ship-sourced pollution.

A second aim of the Bill is to update existing legislation to reflect the 1985 amendments to annex II and protocol I of the Marpol convention. These were adopted by the International Maritime Organisation in December 1985, and have also been endorsed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC).
Annex II deals with the prevention of pollution by noxious liquid substances carried in bulk. These amendments will enter into force internationally on 6 April 1987.
They are the result of general agreement that the original provisions of annex II, developed in the early 1970s, needed revision to take account of subsequent technical developments.

The amendments are recognised by shipping and pollution specialists in government and the shipping and chemical industries as being more in tune with actual conditions encountered on board chemical tankers than were the original annex II provisions.
Additionally they are designed to make annex II easier for administrations to implement, as the need for on-shore facilities for the reception of chemical wastes is reduced.

The amendments to Protocol I of Marpol incorporate new comprehensive mandatory incident reporting requirements. These new pollution reporting obligations and the accompanying guidelines are designed to speed communication, enabling authorities to respond quickly and be better informed in the event of actual or potential accidental spillages, cargo losses, and illegal discharges.

The simplification and standardisation of ship reporting principles and procedures were the major aims of the Protocol I revision, and have consistently been supported by Australia at international maritime organization meetings.
The standardised procedures will avoid the confusion caused by the variety of reporting requirements, imposed by individual authorities, as ships move from one area to another.
As on previous occasions during the development of Marpol, Australia has argued strongly for the special protection measures to safeguard the Great Barrier Reef region.

Special recognition of this unique area is contained in the Convention. This level of protection is maintained in the proposed amendments, which specifically prohibit discharges of chemicals, sewage and garbage in the reef region.

The third function of the Bill is to enable Australia to implement the 1984 protocol to the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage, 1969. The Convention is implemented in Australia by the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981, which entered into force on 5 February 1984 and will be amended by this Bill.

The polluter pays concept is contained in the convention and the new protocol, which are designed to ensure that compensation is available to those suffering oil pollution damage as a result of maritime casualties.
Owners of ships carrying more than 2000 tonnes of oil are required to maintain insurance or other financial security against the risk of such an eventuality.

The 1984 protocol amending the civil liability convention was developed to overcome the adverse effects of inflation on the real values of the limits of liability. The protocol adopts a minimum for vessels of less than 5,000 gross tons of three million special drawing rights, as defined by the International Monetary Fund. This is equivalent to approximately $A5.8m.

For larger vessels, liability is calculated on the basis of the vessel's tonnage, with an overall maximum for the ship's liability of 59.7 million SDRS, or $A114.5m. As an example, a tanker of 39,000 gross tons which is insured to a limit of $A10.35m under existing legislation will be required to be insured under the 1984 protocol to a limit of $A33.5m. This reflects a threefold rise in the real value of the level of compensation available, and will ensure that the damage that such a ship can cause will be more effectively compensated.
Other amendments effected by the 1984 protocol include extension of the geographic scope of the Convention to cover incidents occurring in the 200-mile zone.
This will afford additional protection to sensitive areas such as the Great Barrier Reef and safeguard existing and potential fisheries in the Australian fishing zone.
The scope of the legislation will also be extended as tankers in ballast and combination carriers are now included in the convention coverage.

Extensive consultations between Federal and State officials resulted in agreement on adoption of the protocol. This was accepted and has been recommended by ATAC Ministers. The text of the protocol has been discussed with industry groups representing insurers, shipowners, and cargo interests, and no objections have been raised.
Although the benefits to a coastal State of the expanded scope and increased limits provided by the protocol are readily apparent, the additional costs are extremely difficult to predict.

Shipowners will have to arrange increased insurance cover. However, the nature of shipping insurance, which is provided largely by protection and indemnity clubs on a mutual indemnity basis, makes it impossible to predict the cost involved.
Furthermore, whether a cost increase would be reflected in increased freight rates and charges in the existing highly competitive international freight market is far from certain.

Finally, the Bill will align references to the tonnage of ships in the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Act 1981, with the International Convention on Tonnage Measurement of Ships, 1969. Australia is already a party to this latter Convention, which entered into force in 1982.

The absolute tonnages of certain types of ships for levy purposes will undergo substantial variation following the determination of new tonnages under the 1969 Convention, although existing ships are not required to be re-measured for tonnage purposes until 1994.

In the intervening period an owner may opt to measure a ship under the Convention or by the traditional method embodied in the Navigation (Tonnage Measurement) Regulations. The amendment proposed by the Bill will compensate for the variations between each measurement regime and cater for ships whose tonnage has been calculated under either regime.

I believe the amendments contained in the Bill will result in substantial improvement in both the control of ship-sourced pollution and compensation available for damage caused by a pollution incident, and will maintain Australia's position in the international forefront in the field of marine pollution convention implementation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up increases in its capital subscriptions to two international financial institutions-the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation.

Honourable senators will be aware that the main activity of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which was established in 1947, is that of providing loans to developing member countries.

Following an increase in the IMF's quotas in 1983, in August 1984 the governors of the IBRD approved an increase in the authorised capital stock of the IBRD of $US7 billion. This allowed the bank to pursue the practice whereby its members' shareholdings were increased in parallel with their IMF quotas.

In September 1984, governors authorised an additional resolution which provided for those members who had suffered a relative decline in their shareholding to regain their relative share. Australia was one of the countries affected by this resolution.
The text of the two resolutions, including the number of shares to which each member is entitled to subscribe, is included in the explanatory memorandum to this legislation.
These two increases will allow the Bank to expand its borrowing on the world capital markets. It is these borrowings which largely finance the Bank's loans to developing countries.
Australia voted in favour of the resolutions authorising these capital increases. Members, including Australia, are entitled, but not obliged, to subscribe to this authorised increase.

Australia is entitled to subscribe to 745 shares under the special capital increase and to 70 shares under the increase in certain subscriptions to capital stock, a total of 815 shares, valued at $US98.32m. Under these capital increases, 91.25 per cent of the subscription is to remain on call, the other 8.75 per cent ($US8.60m) is to be paid-in. Of the paid-in portion, 10 per cent ($US0.86m) has to be in the form of gold or United States dollars while the balance ($US7.74m) can be in Australian dollars. The latter amount ($A12.29m at the current exchange rate) will be paid in the form of a promissory note.

The initial 10 per cent cash payment will be made by 31 December 1986. Subject to agreement with the Bank, the promissory note will be encashed in eight equal biannual instalments of approximately $A1.54m each over the five financial years commencing 1986-87. The exact Australian dollar cost will depend on the exchange rate in effect at the time of lodgment of the promissory note.

The IBRD is an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries, and it plays an important role in the South East Asian region. This has been recognised by Australian governments over the years since the Bank's establishment.

Up to the end of June 1986, the Bank had lent about $US105 billion to its member countries. Projects financed covered all the major sectors of economic development but there has been emphasis on infrastructure facilities in the transport and communications, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply.
I believe it to be in Australia's interest to continue its policy of support by taking up, in full, the increase in our capital subscription to which we are entitled under the two resolutions.

The International Finance Corporation, which was established in 1956 as an affiliate of the World Bank, is an international development institution established to promote the growth of productive private investment and to assist enterprises which will contribute to the economic development of its developing member countries. In addition to the direct financial assistance it provides, which may take the form of loan or equity investment, it also arranges other investment finance, mainly from the private sector, to be made available. Up to the end of June 1986, the Corporation had outstanding investments of about $US2.4 billion.

In view of the need to ensure that the IFC has adequate resources to expand its operations, the governors of the Corporation approved a resolution in December 1985 authorising an increase in the IFC capital of $US650m. This will double the IFC's capital. Australia voted in favour of the resolution. As in the case of the IBRD capital increase, member countries are entitled, but not obliged, to subscribe to additional shares.

Australia is entitled under the resolution, the text of which is set out in the explanatory memorandum, to subscribe to an additional 14,560 shares at a cost of $US14.56m, all of which would be paid-in.

Under the terms of an amendment to the resolution, the initial payment associated with the additional subscription must be made by 1 February 1987. It is expected that payment of $US5.824m will be made by that date, with the remaining commitment being paid in three annual cash payments of $US2.912m each, beginning in February 1988. The Australian dollar cost of these instalments will depend on the exchange rate in effect at the time of payment.

The IFC helps to provide the finance, technical assistance and management skills needed to develop productive private sector investment opportunities in its developing member countries. The encouragement of direct foreign investment in developing countries is particularly important given the external debt problems of those countries.
I believe that it is appropriate therefore for Australia to register its support for the corporation and its activities by taking up its full share entitlement.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:

That Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Durack relating to the disallowance of Regulation 4 of the Companies Regulations (Amendment) 1986 be postponed until the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill will have the support of the Opposition. We believe that acts of care and compassion, and the quality of caring, help to characterise any society and the quality of care that is provided for aged Australians is an important part of that provision. However, we believe that the kind of care that is provided should be appropriate to the need. We believe that this legislation, introduced by a government which we do not generally support, is both appropriate and proper and we wish to be associated with it. This legislation will have our general support but we will propose some specific amendments to it in the Committee stage which we hope will improve both its acceptability and its efficiency. We are willing to discuss matters of detail with the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) if that seems appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to discuss several matters separately and seriatim: First, the philosophy underlying the legislation; secondly, certain moves that have been made to transfer regulation making power to gazettal making power; thirdly, certain financing and indexation provisions; and, fourthly, a new capital funding formula contained in the Bill.

The Liberal and National parties have a considerable interest in this kind of legislation. After all, the National Health Act 1953, introduced by a Liberal Government under the Menzies Administration, introduced subsidies. The Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 started capital funding in that area. The Aged Persons Hostels Act 1972 introduced funding for hostels and my friend and former colleague, the Honourable Bill Wentworth, was responsible for that legislation. I believe that each of those pieces of legislation enjoyed bipartisan support because they sought to improve the options for Australians entering their last years.

This legislation has come from the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review and it seeks to put into effect some of the findings of that review. It seeks to provide better resources for hostel care in Australia and that is largely what Part II of the legislation is concerned with. It seeks also to make a more rational needs-based provision-that is, needs for care based-of residential care and that is included in Part III of the Bill. The Opposition, in general, supports both of those thrusts.

I wish to talk first about the philosophy underlying the legislation as this is the main import of the Bill. It is a real change in the way we approach the provision of subsidies for aged persons care in Australia. This is the first Bill to set in place some of the proposals in the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review and the changes are sensible and desirable.

The Government has sought, and we have supported, moves to place more emphasis on home care and support, for example, through the home and community care program. We support that approach. This Bill seeks to provide more emphasis for hostel care as a form of sheltered, residential accommodation. That is sensible and desirable and we support that emphasis where it is appropriate. This Bill has sought to place relatively less emphasis on the nursing homes as the main form of residential care for the aged. The Bill is not suggesting that there be less nursing home provision or fewer nursing home beds. It is merely that nursing homes will have a less dominant position in the overall provision and as a percentage of the total provision. I take it that that will be achieved by controlling the increase in the number of new beds. More new beds will be in hostels and fewer new beds will be in nursing homes but not a single nursing home bed need be lost. It is not a question of fewer nursing home beds; it is a question of a different proportion, a different emphasis and a different percentage.

How should we think about what the government is proposing if we want to evaluate it? Each of us in the Senate, whether we like it or not, is a potential user of the services we are talking about today, if we live long enough. It makes good sense to me as a potential user of services. It makes good sense to me to be able to stay in my own home setting for as long as possible and it makes good sense to me, as a user of services, to be able to stay in the most independent class of accommodation for as long as possible and, if I need sheltered residential care, to go into a nursing home only when I have to. That is what I want as a potential user and this legislation takes us down that track.

Secondly, thinking about the ones I love, I want the same kind of emphasis for my relatives. I know from my medical practice, from my time as a doctor, what nursing homes look like, what they feel like and what they smell like and I know what hostels look like. I certainly know that there is a world of difference between them. If there is an appropriate need for one class and not the other, fine, let us have the nursing home care. But if it is possible to go to hostels I think it is a better, more pleasant and more desirable way to live. I have seen in the past people who could have been in hostels with more independence, more enjoyment of life, more activity and more personal sovereignty. On the other hand I have seen people accommodated in nursing homes because no alternatives were available. They needed care and they could not find care except in nursing homes. I have seen people go to nursing homes because they did not understand that there were alternative ways of seeking residential care. One of the things that this legislation may help us do is make more widely known what the alternatives are. I have seen people go to nursing homes because they had been in a queue and they wished to take up an available bed rather than wait until their need for care required a nursing home.

To look at these changes to the legislation as a taxpayer is not my main concern but it is not my least. I have talked about my concern as a user of services and as a relative but if I look at this legislation as a taxpayer I find the proposals attractive. Not only are nursing homes sometimes the less appropriate choice but also they are much more costly in terms of public subsidy. For every $1 spent by the taxpayer on a hostel bed, $4.30 is spent by the same taxpayer on a private, participating nursing home bed. For every $1 spent on a hostel bed, $5.63 is spent by the taxpayer on a deficit-funded nursing home bed. I can get several points from that. First, it is expensive to operate nursing homes but, where nursing homes are necessary, let us spend that money gladly. Secondly, deficit-funded nursing homes are more than 25 per cent more expensive to the taxpayer than the private participating nursing homes. I hope that the Government will look at that difference as well and try to tell us why it exists and whether we wish to maintain it. If, the need is expressed to us by many Australians, say, members of the Council on the Ageing and members of senior citizens organisations, if their priorities indicate that more hostels would suit them and if it is cost effective to concentrate on hostel provision, it makes good sense to go down that path.

I comment briefly that the Senate has taken an interest in the question of residential care for the aged. A report from the Senate on some of the achievements and some of the problems within the nursing home and other aged accommodation areas came down not so long ago. It drew attention to some of the problems. It drew attention to some of the standards of care. It drew attention to some of the needs for care and some of the inappropriate features of the care which is provided. I notice that some members of that Committee, the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, are on the speakers list in this debate. I hope that, during the debate, they will put some of their views about what is an appropriate form of care.

I have seen a change in the pattern of nursing home use over recent times. This is partly related to the increasing numbers of Australians who are reaching retirement age, the age of 65 or 70, the increasing numbers of Australians who are becoming what we call `aged aged'-people over 80 years of age-and the increasing need which these people have for some form of residential accommodation. So the numbers are increasing. It is an interesting observation that, whereas 1 1/2 per cent of all Australians aged between 65 and 74 require residential accommodation and whereas 8.5 per cent of all Australians in the next 10-year age group-75 to 84 years of age-need residential accommodation, something like 37 per cent of Australians who are 85 years or older need residential accommodation. As the population is ageing, as Australians are greying, our needs are increasing.

The other change I have seen in nursing home accommodations has been that more and more occupants of nursing homes seem to have a genuine need for care, and a genuine need for quite heavy care in some cases. It may not be known to all honourable senators that the nursing homes have a very great turnover. In the first six months following admission as many as half the patients may no longer be there. Some of them may have needed to come in for only a short time; some of them, of course, may have died. But there is a large turnover and, as the Government has brought in assessment teams, we see more and more people in nursing homes who need that form of care. This has put a strain on the people who provide nursing home beds and who run the industry.

I have looked at the proposed changes. Let me look now at the changes from the point of view of the nursing home industry. Put very simply, the industry-has expressed to me the view that the interests of the sick and aged are being put at risk by the proposals in the legislation. I am not sure whether that is correct. I read this in a full page newspaper advertisement which you, Mr Acting Deputy President, may have seen last week. I will quote part of the advertisement:
. . . ever increasing aged population of Australia will be deprived of any real chance to be accommodated, if they so wish, in nursing homes.

I might discuss that in a moment. I think it is incorrect, but that is the kind of concern being expressed from within the industry. It has been expressed to me by some sections of the industry that they should be permitted to build nursing home beds wherever they want and wherever a demand exists. We might discuss that. It has been put to me further by the industry that a Federal Minister prescribes the number of residential places, their type and location, that the Minister has set up assessment teams to determine who may enter nursing home beds and that he prescribes the fee that may be charged. As a result, the nursing home industry has said to me, patients have no choice in the base services available-they are what the nursing home can afford. By the way, that is probably part of the reason why the deficit-funded nursing homes are more expensive-they offer more services. It has also been put to me that patients have no choice in extra services because the fees are fixed. The industry further asserts that the proprietors have no choice in the type of services and no choice in the level of fee. They are arguing for a deregulated system. I understand that part of the industry has actually approached the High Court of Australia and presently a decision is reserved before the High Court challenging the Commonwealth power and practice in this area. That High Court decision will be both important and instructive when it emerges in time.

I have listened very carefully to the industry concerns. I do not believe, and I have no evidence to lead me to agree with, the industry assertion that the interests of sick and aged Australians are being put at risk by these proposals. Although I hear the industry's concerns, I cannot accept that that is the case. I cannot accept the assertion that these proposals will mean that the increasing aged population of Australia will be deprived of any real chance to be accommodated if they so wish in nursing homes. That is simply not true. What it indicates is that people in the industry who are knowledgeable and experienced and who are worried about this legislation have simply got it wrong. As to the assertion that beds should be built wherever demand exists, that will be fine if only the industry will then tell me that it does not want subsidies from the taxpayer to be attached to each of those beds when they do exist. The difficulty with that approach and argument, however sympathetic one is to the job those people are doing, is that there is substantial subsidy of everything they do. The private nursing home industry in Australia provides the beds and every approved bed attracts a heavy subsidy from the taxpayer. So the taxpayer does have an interest.

If we got to a system where not every bed was subsidised and some beds could be built without attracting subsidy, we might have a completely different situation. But at the moment every nursing home bed is subsidised. There is a taxpayer interest and because of that the call for a completely free and deregulated system simply does not make sense. While ever the Commonwealth is called on to subsidise every nursing home bed, the Commonwealth can properly seek power over the numbers and kinds of beds. I believe that on this matter we support the Minister in what he is doing.

I turn now to the provisions in the Bill which seek to replace certain regulations with gazettals. One of the reasons that we have sought to have regulations in place over the years is to give the Parliament a capacity to overturn any regulation which seems inappropriate in the light of current standards or current practice. A continuing major concern of the Liberal Party and the National Party is that matters which are the subject of ministerial determination should generally be capable of disallowance if the Parliament finds them objectionable in some way. Although that power has been there, I cannot recall when we last had to seek to move such a disallowance. It is simply that having the power there leaves with the Parliament a residual capacity. Using regulation power, the Minister has usually made his determinations known by subordinate legislation via regulations and ordinances. But I understand that the preparation and the processing of these is slow; it is tedious; it is subject to the speed and availability of parliamentary drafting. From my own time as a Minister I know that it used to drive me mad trying to get regulations drafted. The general proposition put by the Minister and by the Department that a move from regulations to gazettal will be quicker and simpler is one which we accept, provided that the gazettal notices themselves remain disallowable by either House of Parliament. After all, all we are seeking to do is to ensure that the possibility of parliamentary scrutiny remains. If that scrutiny remains, if the gazettals remain disallowable, that would seem to have merit.

I make the point to the Minister that at least one of the gazettals has not been made disallowable. Clause 7 (2), I think, creates a new gazettal which is not disallowable. I am told that it is a power under which no action has ever been taken and under which no action is contemplated. If that is the case, if it has never been used, there is no real point in moving it to gazettals and there should be no real point against leaving it as a regulation-making power. If it is to be made a gazettal, we ask that it be a disallowable gazettal. We will vote against that sub-clause unless the Minister can give us some good reason why we should not do so.

I turn now to financing. The Bill provides for measures to increase the amount of subsidy for a hostel sector. We congratulate the Government and we welcome the move. It will enable the better provision of hostel accommodation. I welcome the increase and the indexation moves of hostel fees. It will make hostel provision easier to afford and easier to finance. A new capital funding formula which is contained in the Bill will make it easier for some organisations to obtain capital subsidies. Organisations which are regarded as being in special need categories will be able to attract a 100 per cent subsidy. The Minister will be able to designate certain facilities as special need facilities, and the Minister seeks to be able to designate certain beds in nursing homes as special need beds.

We are not worried about the proposition in general; we have a couple of particular questions. In relation to the designation of, say, a special need organisation and the granting to that organisation of a 100 per cent subsidy, it is very important that there be public confidence in ministerial decisions so to do. We are not objecting to it as a principle, but we believe it is appropriate that such a decision be capable of disallowance within the Parliament. I cannot remember when we last moved to disallow one of the Minister's regulations, but the fact that the power is there gives us a very powerful argument against anyone who says it is unfettered ministerial discretion. It is not, because, while there is a disallowance power, we can always come back to the Parliament. We are asking the Minister to agree to an amendment to make the granting of 100 per cent subsidies, where he considers that necessary, capable of disallowance. I do not imagine that we will want to disallow it, but as a principle it should be disallowable.

The second matter in relation to special need beds is a more difficult one, and I hope the Minister can give us some assistance on this. I believe clause 13 of the Bill says that upon application by the owner of a nursing home `or otherwise' the Minister may do certain things. Why are the words `or otherwise' there? They suggest that the Minister may designate certain beds as special need beds without the owner of the nursing home having sought such a change. If we are talking about a private participating nursing home, which I might own and which might be my life investment, it may not suit me to have certain beds designated as special need beds. I ask the Minister: Why are the words `or otherwise' there? If we are not convinced that there is an overwhelming reason, we will seek to move an amendment to have those words struck out. That would merely have the effect of providing the Minister with a capacity to redesignate certain beds in private nursing homes only if the proprietor so sought. We think that is a perfectly simple proposition. Unless the Minister can tell us that there is some overwhelming reason for the words `or otherwise' to remain, we will seek to have them removed.

I make the point again to the Minister that we are supporting this legislation, but we are trying to make it so that what goes on under the legislation not only is fair but also can be seen to be fair. We think it is desirable and necessary that any ministerial decision either to grant 100 per cent capital funding or to redefine certain beds be seen to be impartial, non-punitive, and non-party political-in fact, totally non-political.

Associated with all this is the decision to control tightly and with minimum flexibility-even minimum flexibility for the Minister-the number of beds which may be allocated to a particular region or a particular town, or in relation to a particular application. The Minister may identify the number of beds in a State or a Territory, but we have discovered within States or Territories certain regional needs which arise, perhaps unpredictably. We do not object to the desire of the Government to alter the ratio of beds to favour hostel provision, and we understand that this will happen by adding relatively fewer nursing home beds and relatively more hostel beds.

The problem remains that some areas are atypical. Perhaps they are atypical in terms of demography; perhaps a difference in their demography emerges. They may be different in terms of the numbers of migrants in particular areas. I can think of areas of Sydney which have changed very markedly as particular migrant communities have moved in. The residents of certain areas of Sydney are aging at different rates from those for other areas. I can imagine different growth rates for different towns. One has only to look at the north coast of New South Wales, which is growing at about five times the rate of the rest of the State. One can see that local needs may emerge.

We do not want to second guess the Minister. We do not want to take out of the Minister's hands the planning and designation of numbers of beds. We are asking, however, that a capacity remain with the Minister of the day such that if he or she thinks a local need has arisen he or she can vary the number by gazettal. That should be disallowable; we should keep the process clean. We will move an amendment to ensure that the Minister has such a capacity.

Having said all of that, we are attracted to what this legislation is seeking to do. It is seeking to help elderly Australians to live their lives with more autonomy, more control, more dignity, more choice and more flexibility. It is seeking to provide more appropriate accommodation for many of them through the provision of more hostel beds. The Opposition wishes to be associated with the legislation. In the interests of comity, we ask the Minister to look at our proposed amendments favourably. We believe they are designed to improve the legislation, and we hope that some of them will be accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 is welcomed in general by the Australian Democrats. This legislation is designed to take what we consider to be appropriate action on some of the recommendations of the report of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review which was tabled in April this year. It introduces arrangements for controlling the growth of nursing home beds. As a consequence, it is estimated that the Government will save $4m in 1986-87 and $27.7m in 1987-88. On the other hand, increases in hostel and personal care subsidy levels and the introduction of automatic indexation in these levels will increase expenditure on care for the aged by an estimated $5.6m in 1986-87 and $26.5m in 1987-88.

SPEECH.PARA: The Nursing Homes and Hostels Review report recommended that aged and disabled people should, as far as possible, be supported in their own homes and their own communities, that aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs. The review report said that services should be provided in an atmosphere and using processes which promote, as far as possible, rehabilitation and restoration of function. The manner in which services are provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and independent functioning of all residents. Services should be based on a recognition that for many people discharge to a residential service providing a less intensive form of care or a community-based support service would be a possible and desirable outcome. The Australian Democrats fully support these recommendations.

Since April the Commonwealth has been in consultation with State governments, nursing homes and hostels, consumer and welfare groups, and so on. With this legislation the Government is acting upon two of some five areas of need which were identified in these discussions. Those two areas that are the subject of this legislation are the need for a more flexible and integrated planning approach to the provision of residential services and the need for a publicised and better resourced hostel sector. To provide for this, the Bill introduces growth control arrangements for nursing homes. The Minister will be able to specify the maximum number of nursing home beds which can exist at any time during a financial year in each State or Territory and in the regions of each State or Territory. These maxima will be gazetted.

The strategy is to maintain growth in new services on the basis of the current national ratio of 100 residential care places per 1,000 people aged 70 years or over and, with this national ratio, to limit the rate of growth of numbers of new nursing home beds to a maximum of 10 per cent of new approvals. By 1988-89 the Government will approve an additional 12,880 places overall, of which up to 1,295 places will be for nursing homes and the balance for hostels. It is clear that in a great many cases the sort of accommodation with the sort of personal care, supports and rehabilitation services provided by hostels for people who need moderate levels of assistance and supervision in their daily lives is preferable. While nursing homes provide extensive nursing care for highly dependent people there are currently many inappropriate placements because of the lack of hostel-type accommodation.

The Bill also addresses that area in which currently, under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the Commonwealth makes grants to eligible organisations towards the capital cost of homes for the aged and disabled, that amount not being able to exceed 80 per cent of the capital cost. This legislation introduces the ability to meet the special needs of groups such as Aboriginal groups, ethnic communities, the aged and the disabled, such as the deaf or blind aged, by enabling them to receive grants of an amount up to the full capital cost of the provision of such accommodation. The Bill will also apply uniform conditions of approval to both government and non-government nursing homes. Existing provisions exempt government nursing homes from the conditions which relate to the number of beds in an approved nursing home and the approval of patients for admission. However, in practice government homes have been subjected to restrictions since 1981, and this legislation formalises these restraints.

The Bill also amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act to provide for increases in the hostel care subsidy, respite care subsidy and personal care subsidy. The hostel care subsidy will increase from $1.80 a day to $1.95 a day; the respite care subsidy from $7 a day to $7.50 a day; and the personal care subsidy from $7.80 a day to $8.40 a day. There will also be an additional increase of $2.60 a day in the value of the personal care subsidy, to $11 a day, from May next year, to assist the hostel industry to provide more adequate levels of personal care for dependent elderly people. The Bill will also, importantly, provide a mechanism for annual automatic increases in subsidy rates for hostel care, personal care and respite care.

The Australian Democrats welcome any moves to provide for and support alternatives in care for the aging in our society. It is significant, however, that this legislation covers only two of the areas raised in the consultations undertaken by the Government since April-those which I mentioned before, namely the requirement for flexible planning and the need for a publicised and better resourced hostel sector. It will be important that the remaining three areas be also dealt with by government if we are to meet the needs of our aged people, the continuing needs of an increasing section of the community. Those other three areas related to the extension of residential care services beyond hostels to other forms of accommodation such as group housing arrangements, the expansion of community services to assist those elderly people most at risk of premature and inappropriate institutionalisation and the importance of carefully developing the process of assessment so that it will gain support from consumers, professionals and service providers.

While the Australian Democrats support the measures in the Bill which provide for the extension of the provision of hostel accommodation, which will introduce a much needed increase in flexibility in the care for the aged, we are concerned that the assumption should not be made that this can be done by the simple redirection of resources from nursing homes to hostels. In a population in which the percentage of older people is increasing, the need for nursing homes will not necessarily decrease along with the provision of additional hostel beds and community services. While it is no doubt the case that a considerable number of people currently in nursing homes-a quite high proportion, quite possibly-could more appropriately be placed in hostel accommodation or cared for in other ways in the community, doubts exist, at least in Victoria, about the assumption which appears to exist that there is a clear demarcation line between hostel and extensive care patients. If, as seems likely under the new provisions, Victoria is facing a possible reduction of some 25 per cent in available nursing home beds, this is cause for concern because it it believed that only around 10 to 12 per cent of current nursing home patients could actually suitably be moved to hostel-type accommodation.

Adding the many nursing home-type patients who are currently occupying acute care beds in both public and private hospitals to the long waiting lists already existing for nursing home placements illustrates that there are potential problems. So it will indeed be important that the commitment of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), given in his second reading speech, that the change in the existing balance between providing intensive care through nursing homes and providing appropriate community services and hostel options will be implemented gradually. The Minister said that he recognises that it is essential that implementation does not affect the people who are already residents of nursing homes and that it is carefully monitored, evaluated and, where necessary, adjusted. The Australian Democrats strongly support those comments of the Minister and will be encouraging such flexibility, graduality and adjustments as they become necessary.

We particularly welcome the measures in the Bill to maintain the real levels of the hospital subsidies and to increase the other available assistance which has been outlined. In particular, we welcome the provision in the legislation for the annual automatic increases. This annual indexation is quite essential when dealing with the provision of financial benefit to people in need in the community at all levels. Indexation is a practice which recently has probably been more honoured in the breach than actually carried out. All I can do is hope that this Parliament will not be party to any further legislation such as that in respect of the increases expected by pensioners through indexation of their pensions, and that indeed this annual indexation will continue in effect. We also welcome what we see as an affirmative action component in this legislation-the ability provided by the legislation for special needs groups of financially disadvantaged people in our community to achieve 100 per cent support for capital funding. This applies to such groups as ethnic groups in the community, the Aboriginal community and the aged handicapped, who will indeed benefit from this provision whereby they can receive 100 per cent support as against the regular provision of 80 per cent. This is most welcome from the point of view of the Australian Democrats.

As we have said, however, there is a great deal more to be done if we are to meet the needs of our aging population. Much of that will require very close and well considered State and Federal co-operation. Concern has been expressed at least by one organisation in Victoria about the replacement of the Federal-State co-ordinating committees by the aged care advisory committees. It will be very important that that State-Federal co-operation be continued and developed as further developments occur in care for the aged. We welcome the Minister's statement about the objective of this new arrangement for the setting up of the aged care advisory committees:

to ensure that in planning residential care services full account is taken of the availability of community care services; the involvement of consumer bodies and service providers and the continuing and essential contribution of State authorities.
Again, that is a significant comment by the Minister, and will need to be carried out if that co-operation is to be effective and further action of and innovative nature is to be taken.

One of the areas that needs to be recognised at all levels and needs to be acted upon if we are to provide adequate service, both residential and in the community and the home, relates to the shortage of professional staff. For example, not enough medical practitioners are undertaking training in geriatric medicine and rehabilitation either under the auspices of the Royal Australian College of Physicians or at the diploma level through the Mount Royal course. Similarly, in the area of geriatric nursing or gerontology training for nurses, wider availability is needed and higher priority needs to be given to funding these courses. There is also a shortage of other allied health professionals with knowledge or experience in the care and understanding of the needs of the elderly. It is important that the obvious problems of recruitment and retention of professional staff are examined and faced so that these people do not continue to move out of the care of the aged and into acute health care services, leaving an enormous gap, particularly in rehabilitation and community care.

Another area to which considerable attention should be paid is that of research into gerontological studies. It is interesting to note that in 1985-86 just a little over $1m of the National Health and Medical Research Council's $50.8m research allocation was allocated to research into the aging process. That area is of some concern, particularly in terms of Alzheimer's disease, which according to figures that have been quoted, is likely to affect some 200,000 people by the beginning of the next century. If one takes into account the families of those people, at least 500,000 Australians will be directly affected. It is an area in which we do not have enough knowledge and into which we need to put a great deal more effort. It is already a growing effort, but it needs to be recognised as a priority area, not just from the point of view of the aging but from that of the carers, very often the families.

Another area where beneficial research could take place, and research which if successful could have a significant impact, is that of incontinence. It is recognised that some 70 per cent of patients in nursing homes have some degree of incontinence. It is often the straw that breaks the camel's back and leads to moving people from home care, where their families have been able to manage, into some form of institutional care. The increase in the number of hostel beds will probably bring about more appropriate placement of such people. If there were to be a breakthrough in research in prevention and treatment, I believe that it would have a significant impact on the costs of caring for the aged, not to mention the comfort of the aged and the ability of their families and other carers in the community to take care of them for longer and at less expense.

Yet another area that needs to be examined arises from the finding of the report entitled `Census of the Aged in Institutions' which indicated that 85 per cent to 95 per cent of persons admitted to residential care are without a partner. It is interesting to consider the link between the lone aged and the institutionalised aged. We need to look at the reasons why so many persons without partners are admitted and the level of support that is available for those who care for their partners at home before institutionalisation takes place. The carer's pension was introduced in November 1985 and has gone some way to make it possible for those other than partners to take care of people-not just the aged but the disabled as well-in the home. This is seen by all, I am sure, as the best possible option. There are some problems, however. Social security or other pension beneficiaries are not eligible, and it has been said that perhaps the only group within social security beneficiaries who might benefit from a transfer to a carer's pension might be the unemployed, who upon transferring to the carer's pension would do better out of the fringe benefits available.

A little lateral thinking in this respect could perhaps provide some initiative that would lead to the availability of more people who are prepared to be carers of the aged in the community and in their homes. In Victoria the Australian Democrats have developed a scheme known as the community services initiative, which gives the unemployed the opportunity to provide services in the community, such as those needed by the elderly who wish to remain in their own homes. It involves the provision of services such as the replacement of light bulbs, helping to make telephone calls, hanging out washing, driving the car, doing the shopping, simply visiting, reading, talking, all the points of social contact that are so important to people who are not able to do those things for themselves. They involve the carrying out of simple physical actions which anyone, certainly unskilled but caring people, could easily carry out. This scheme would operate by allowing the permissible income level of social security, particularly unemployment beneficiaries to be raised so that they could earn a higher income-in this case provided by the government in the form of a carer's income, which together with the unemployment benefit would reach the level of an award wage payable for such work.

I mentioned Alzheimer's disease. I am told by people working in Alzheimer's support groups that there is support for families at local government level, but that a great many families who could use such support are not aware that it is available; that is probably a good thing because if all people were aware of the availability of services-this applies to Alzheimer's as well as to other problems-demand on those services would escalate to the point where in current circumstances there would not be enough people to provide those services. It seems to the Australian Democrats that a scheme such as the community services initiative, in which government would play its role in a much less expensive way than institutionalisation, would enable unemployed people to retain benefits, carry out the important community work of keeping elderly people in their homes, supporting and caring for them and helping them to cope with their daily lives. With that payment on top of their unemployment benefit, they would be able to earn an award wage for the work. If local government were to administer such a scheme, there would be a far larger pool of people to call upon to provide such services. In summary therefore, the Australian Democrats welcome the widening of options for the aged, which this Bill represents. We caution against any view that reductions can or should be achieved in the numbers of nursing home beds or in spending on care for the aged and we urge still further innovative actions to ensure the best possible care and the widest possible options for Australia's aging population.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 is, to my great satisfaction, receiving a great deal of cross-party support in the Senate and not without very good reason. It comes to us as a result of many years of work, starting with the Auditor-General's report nearly 10 years ago on an efficiency audit of the Commonwealth administration of nursing homes programs. This was followed by a House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure report entitled `In a home or at home: accommodation and home care for the aged' and more recently a report by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes entitled `Private nursing homes in Australia: their conduct, administration and ownership'. After years of seeming inactivity, we now have a fairly prompt response to that most recent report which was tabled at the end of 1984 and to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review from the newly formed Department of Community Services, which appeared about six or eight months ago. That review was followed very promptly by this series of amendments to the nursing homes and hostels legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a long overdue approach to a problem which was becoming more and more difficult for the Australian Government to deal with in any rational fashion. In short, all those reports came to a consensus on a range of issues. One of the most remarkable of these was the haphazard manner in which nursing home programs have been launched in Australia, the lack of control that has been exerted over the years and the excessive concentration on institutional accommodation, rather than on the development of a comprehensive range of home and community care programs. Other issues included the failure to develop effective assessment and rehabilitative procedures in order to improve the efficiency of programs by matching services to individuals' particular requirements, the lack of co-ordination between various levels of government, including a lack of co-ordination in the area of inspection and maintenance of standards and in many parts of Australia the lack of concern of the third tier of government-that is local government-to become involved in the provision of these services. Finally and not least there was the inefficiency of the present funding mechanisms, including the lack of rationale for perpetuating both deficit-funded and participating nursing home arrangements.

In the period from 1969 to 1984 we saw that uncontrolled growth in nursing home accommodation to which the review referred. In 1969 the number of nursing home beds per thousand population over the age of 65 was 39.1. In 1983 this increased to 47.4 beds per thousand of the population in that age group. That may or may not have been a reasonable growth, but during that period no assessment was ever made of what was a reasonable ratio of beds per thousand of the population; of whether we were looking at the population aged 65 and over or 70 and over; of whether the provision of beds was appropriate to the needs; and all the other issues that I have included in the consensus that has been reached by the three reviews that have been undertaken over the past 10 years. This uncontrolled growth also demonstrated the enormous increase in public expenditure on nursing home beds.

The point can never be made too strongly or too frequently that the vast majority of our aged population is very healthy and very capable of looking after itself. When we talk about assisted accommodation of whatever degree, we are talking about only 7 per cent of our population over the age of 70. Another point should be made as well: As the population ages progressively, we have more healthy 70-year-olds. Certainly amongst our population aged 85 and over there are more severely handicapped people or elderly people who are restricted by their physical and mental aging, but amongst the 70 to 80-year age group there are many very healthy, lively, intelligent, capable and independent people. This is something of which I became aware when I, as a young woman involved in community activities, offered my services to the local meals on wheels association, only to find that the majority of the helpers were people in the age group that was normally expected to be dependent upon meals on wheels and other services of that nature.

The specifics of this legislation go very closely to many of the recommendations of the most recent review-that from the Department of Community Services. In looking forward for the first time in a manner which seeks to provide in an appropriate way for our aging population, that review has made recommendations for the control of the development of nursing home beds, for the ratio that will be developed in comparison with hostels and less heavily supported accommodation. There were similar recommendations from the previous reports to which I have referred, so that we can now look towards the next five or 10 years and set some goals within overall maximum ratios. We seek within those time periods to ensure that nursing home beds are made available where they are needed and that where they are not needed different types of accommodation are made available. We are looking also to the fact that in many cases extensive nursing care growth requirements can be met by re-absorbing existing ordinary bed care stock. It may not be widely appreciated that in addition to the ordinary subsidy to which nursing homes are entitled for beds that are held by people in need of an ordinary level of nursing care, there is also an extensive bed subsidy of $42 a week for people who are in need of heavy nursing care. This tends to vary a great deal from State to State, as does the adequacy or otherwise of nursing home bed provision generally. For example, we see in Victoria a ratio of 39 nursing home beds per thousand of population, as against 54.7 in Western Australia. This means that the fewer beds per thousand of population in Victoria are more likely to be occupied by more heavily dependent patients. This is reflected by the fact that there is a higher ratio of trained nurses required in Victorian nursing homes, which leads again to the fact that historically a much higher subsidy has developed in that State.

The disparities between the States are also of considerable concern. In the future extensive nursing bed requirements may certainly become much higher if we seek to accommodate a far higher proportion of our current nursing home population in much less heavily dependent accommodation. Ultimately, it may very well be that the nursing homes will be for extensive nursing care only, as for something much more closely allied to extensive nursing care than is the case at present.

As we look carefully at the nursing home industry, we see that, dependent upon the State, the location and the cost of the nursing home beds, in many cases there are beds that are inappropriately occupied by people who would be much better catered for by much less heavily serviced care. The point has already been made on several occasions this morning that that is not only unnecessarily expensive and wasteful of resources but also is certainly of no assistance to the individual concerned, who should be encouraged in every possible way to maintain his or her independence, to maintain a lively interest in what is going on and not to be identified with a heavily dependent group of people.

The comments made by Senator Peter Baume about the power of the Minister to redesignate beds under these amendments is a matter to which the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) will respond. But it seems to me that this really goes to the heart of the problem that has developed over the years-to the fact that the nursing home industry has developed not necessarily in response to the needs of populations but that other matters have intervened between those needs and the services that are provided. As the Senate is very well aware, much of the provision of nursing home care has been through the private enterprise sector. In many cases it has been the case that services have developed where that resource has been sought to be invested. Each of us is aware in each State of a suburb notorious for the high number of beds that have been provided within that sector. In Western Australia I suppose I look at Mount Lawley, an area where traditionally large old homes have been converted into nursing homes over the years, some appropriately and some not so appropriately. They have not necessarily developed in response to the actual needs of individuals in that area, but have developed far more from a range of accidents, including the properties available for sale and the socio-economic mix of that area, with perhaps more people able to afford private nursing home care. It is in cases like this, where there really is a very poor distribution of beds, or rather an inappropriate distribution of beds, that it may certainly be necessary for the Minister to step in and say: `In the course of rationalising what is going on in this region we are aware of the fact that, for example, there is no accommodation for very young people who may need nursing home attention'. This is one of the increasingly regrettable aspects of nursing home care: It is the appropriate care for very severely disabled young people; for example, those who have suffered from very severe head injuries as a result of road accidents. They may have no other opportunity of accommodation except in nursing homes and special provisions must be made for them.

In the course of the inquiry of the Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, we visited a most stimulating institution in Sydney called Austin which accommodates young people in a much less restricted way which is far more appropriate for them. Of course, they must be provided with education and training. Perhaps more than the elderly population, they must be provided with the stimulus that allows them to develop as individuals. Many of them can look forward to quite a long life, but in wheelchairs or in even more restrictive circumstances. For example, a particular region where there are no beds of this nature may very well be a matter that should concern the Minister and should lead to the recategorisation of beds in that area.

Other services that are very scarce on the ground in many areas are those of particular use to migrants. The extra services that may be required by migrants probably go to the provision of staff who have language skills and who have extra knowledge of the cultural needs of particular groups of migrants. Once again, it may well be up to the Minister to ensure that in a particular area a more appropriate service is available to those people. Once again, in the course of our select committee inquiry, we were given evidence from the Sunshine area of Victoria that fairly recently four new nursing homes had been built but that none of them had been equipped with a range of services most appropriate for the people in that area, which included large numbers of elderly migrants who within the next 10 or 15 years would be looking for nursing home accommodation. Not only were those elderly people unable to afford the accommodation that had recently been provided in the area but also the accommodation was inappropriate. The migrant population would probably be forced to go to nursing homes or other accommodation away from their families without any assurance that their particular needs would be sensitively dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not against the redesignation. We only ask that the owners request it. They can approach the Department.

—I understand, Senator Baume. I was not taking issue with the points that the honourable senator made. I just wanted to emphasise the fact that the range of services provided is inadequate in far too many cases and that the planning simply has not been done in the past. That is a matter for which the Government should have considerable concern.

SPEECH.PARA: As has also been mentioned this morning, the provision of particular care for elderly patients suffering from Alzheimer's disease leaves a great deal to be desired. This indeed may lead to considerable extra expense if the appropriate arrangements are to be made. The average dementia patient may well be highly ambulant and must regrettably be restricted to an area for his or her good. One of the most distressing aspects of my career as a trade union official regularly visiting nursing homes was to have the front door unlocked before I could go in. The door was not locked to keep me out; it was locked to keep the patients in. Nursing homes that are well equipped to deal with dementia patients typically have large gardens and the gardens are surrounded by high fences-again not a very palatable state of affairs but one that is absolutely essential for the safety of those people. Of course, within those high fences one must have very well trained staff-people with the time, the sensitivity and the skills required to ensure that the dementia patients have a level of existence which is as valuable to them as possible, with the least number of restraints and the largest possible range of good care, and high quality of life. These are matters that we all seek to achieve. They will not be achieved without considerable expense, and much of the emphasis of these amendments is towards redistributing the very large amount of money that has been spent over the years which, as we are all aware, has gone in many cases into an inappropriate range of care.

I should like to touch briefly on another paper that has come to us fairly recently-the draft discussion paper on quality of care in nursing homes that has been prepared by Catherine Rhys-Hearn, following a very long, detailed and scholarly survey of means of establishing measures for standards of nursing home care. This has been breaking very new ground in many respects. Quantifying and qualifying the level of care of individuals is not something which is done quickly or easily. The report itself is worthy of close scrutiny. In a few minutes, I certainly cannot do it justice. But I note that clause 7 of the Bill points briefly to a very vexed question, one that has been dealt with in industrial arbitration courts at various times. The definition of `nursing home care' is what I am referring to-or, rather, the way in which one can actually interpret a statement which talks about nursing home care or nursing care. I note, anyway, that at least the explanatory memorandum goes to something of a tautology where it states:

The definition of `nursing home care' in sub-section 4 (1) of the Principal Act provides that `nursing home care' means accommodation and nursing care of a kind provided in a nursing home and includes any prescribed service of a kind provided in a nursing home.

This amendment simplifies the mechanism contained in the definition for approving services. This is another matter that will no longer be prescribed by regulation but, much more appropriately, by being specified by the Minister by notice in writing published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

The question, `What is nursing?', has been approached in many different ways. I cannot express any surprise at the tautology which has resulted here. We have tried in the past to defend the right of a nurse assistant, for example, to an increased rate of pay by describing her duties within a nursing home. It is very clear that in many cases those duties are extremely responsible. Of course, they are always supervised by the registered general nurse, but they go to all those nurturing services to which patients are entitled but which, in many cases, are seen in the wider community as the sort of care that any of us would give at home to our families, even when they are in good health, and certainly when they are sick, and certainly to the aged in our families when they are in need of that extra care. As Senator Powell has said, one of the most problematic characteristics of aging may be the development of incontinence. It is a matter which in the last few years has begun to receive the sort of scientific approach that has been lacking in the past. But these are the matters that are all dealt with very well and thoroughly and very professionally by Catherine Rhys-Hearn in her discussion paper on quality of care in nursing homes.

It should not be too long in the future before we are able to say quite categorically that this range of patients with this particular need requires this particular number of registered nursing hours of care per day, that those registered nursing hours should be supported by a certain number of so-called untrained nursing hours, and that in addition-this is going a little more widely than these amendments-that nursing care should also be supported by a range of domestic services within any institution. Too often in the past the nurses, both registered and otherwise, have had to spend a great deal of their time in cleaning, washing, cooking and other duties which are outside the immediate care of the patient and which deprive nurses of time to spend on high quality caring for the individual.

One other point that I should like to make, which goes also to questions that have been raised in all the reviews over the years, concerns the matter of developing some sort of complaints procedure. Too often elderly people, particularly, who spend their latter years in institutions of one sort or another have been without any advocate for their own particular needs. As Senator Powell said, very many of them are without a partner, very many of them are without any close relatives at all. The question of providing an advocate for individuals in this position is one that certainly concerned the Select Committee and I understand that it is being dealt with within the Department of Community Services in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department. Of course, in most cases well run services have by definition a very good relationship with their client, and the vast majority of nurses and administrators in nursing homes are sensitive, just and sympathetic people. Too often, though, the consumer is frightened to complain, feels powerless and thinks that any complaint may be followed by an eviction order-in many cases, of course, quite incorrectly; but the perception is there. In many cases they are unaware of the fact that they are not getting the degree of care that they deserve. In many cases, too, the relatives feel powerless to take any sort of action.

We are looking at various advocacy models, not just in the residential context, and we are actively investigating options through a range of innovative projects. This will also apply to our disability services program, where again we have a very large clientele of people who in the past have held those same characteristics as the aged-an unwillingness to complain, a feeling of power- lessness, and perhaps a lack of knowledge about the level of care to which they are entitled.
