Perhaps I may say once again how pleased I am that we are receiving such wide support, not only in the Senate but in the community generally, for the amendments to the Act and for the very wide range of recommendations upon which they are based. It has taken a very long time, but it seems to me that within the next five or 10 years we can look forward to a range of supportive mechanisms within Australian society which will be far more appropriate to our aging population.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill, but there are some aspects of it about which I should like to speak briefly. For some time I was a member of the Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, and I had the opportunity of moving around a great deal of Australia and looking at nursing homes, and at hospitals and hostels. I do want to pay tribute to private enterprise, to the churches and the benevolent societies who do so much in this area of the provision of nursing homes and hostels. I like some of the set-ups the churches provide, where they have three types of living-first of all independent living, then hostel living, and then nursing home care-all together in one area. I believe that as people get older and feel that they need to go into a home, that is the ideal way to do it. Perhaps it is appropriate to say those few words of commendation today while we are discussing this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a tremendous responsibility to look after the aged in our community. There is no doubt at all that our population is aging, and that presents an enormous challenge for the future. In 1901 only 4 per cent of the population was aged 65 years or more. In 1981 that figure had risen to 14 per cent. The Australian Bureau of Statistics in its most recent series projects that the figure will increase to 16 per cent in the year 2001 and 22 per cent in 2021. Of course, there is a strong relationship between increasing age and the likelihood of admission to a hostel or nursing home. Of the population aged 85 years and over, 36.7 per cent are cared for in residential accommodation, 11.5 per cent in hostels and 25.2 per cent in nursing homes. Figures indicate that there will be a sharp increase in the need to provide care services for aged persons over the next three decades. In particular, there will be a rapid increase from 1991 in most dependent aged groups. Consistent with this trend, expenditure on the aged is projected to rise by more than 50 per cent in real terms between the years 2001 and 2021.

One fact which will present difficulties is that, because of the slow rate of increase in the number of children being born, the working population cannot be counted on to provide sufficient revenue to cover the increasing public costs of the aged. Even since 1973 the nursing home expenditure increase has been greater than increases in the consumer price index and movements in average weekly earnings. Since 1973 there has been a 278 per cent increase in expenditure per average bed day in hostels, and a 606 per cent increase in nursing homes. International comparisons show that Australia is among the high provision countries, although not the highest.

This legislation has a number of parts. Part I is a preliminary and introductory passage. Part II amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. It affords the Minister discretion to provide up to 100 per cent instead of 80 per cent of capital funding for financially disadvantaged groups. It also increases funding for people receiving hostel care services, personal care services and respite care services in hostels. Parts III and IV amend the National Health Act and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act respectively. Control of the growth of the number of nursing home beds is obtained by allowing the Minister to specify a maximum number of subsidised beds in each State and Territory or in a region of a State or Territory. Hostel care subsidies will rise by 19.3 per cent, the aim being to fund a strategy to restructure improved residential and community care services for aged people through a shift to hostel-based services.

Both the report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes-the Giles report-and the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure-the McLeay report-criticised the Government's administration of nursing homes as being ad hoc and unco-ordinated. Senator Grimes, in his capacity as Minister for Community Services, instigated a review and in April the report of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review was tabled in the Senate. This report stated that there was too great an emphasis on nursing homes and inadequate support for hostels, and that this imbalance should be corrected. I support the concept of moving away from institutionalised care and encouraging home and community care so as to enable the elderly a more independent style of living. However, I believe that we have to recognise the need to provide more money for, for example, the Blue Nursing Service, Meals on Wheels and community care. I had the opportunity recently to go to the annual meeting of the Brisbane central area of the Blue Nursing Service. That meeting expressed the view that this was something that needed to be looked at. We need to be concerned also with the reduction in the number of nursing home beds.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no reduction.

—We are trying to make more hostel beds available. All I am saying is that if we are to make more hostel beds available we have to be careful that we do not reduce the opportunity for people who are in need of nursing home care to find a nursing home bed. We have to watch out that we do not make hostels into institutions that provide a type of nursing home care. I find that the people in hostels are fairly mobile and are able to get around; they only need people to look after them, in a caretaking capacity, and to be able to press a bell if they need attention during the night. We have to be careful that we do not put people into hostels who perhaps need care by nursing sisters during the night, which would require the hostels to pay extra wages. We have to look at this. I believe that the provision of respite beds is worth while. I am sure many people who keep their aged or invalid parents at home find that the provision of respite beds for just two or three weeks or even a month is wonderful because it gives them a chance to have a little holiday.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly appreciate that the Government is concerned that nursing home benefits have not been utilised properly, but we have to make sure that the best interests of the aged are given priority. The Minister suggested in his speech that perhaps some 25 per cent of placements in nursing homes were inappropriate. I am not sure whether that figure is correct but it is important when dealing with the aged and the sick to err on the side of generosity and compassion. I listened to Senator Giles speaking about old folk who had Alzheimer's disease and dementia. There is certainly a need for extra nursing home beds for people who have such problems.

One aspect of the Bill concentrates power in the hands of the Minister. I appreciate that there has to be a central governing body, but it is important that there not be such centralised power that the needs of the individual and perhaps isolated communities are ignored or not properly considered. I believe that this will be taken into consideration by the Minister. Queensland, of course, is a highly decentralised State, and demographically different regions have different requirements. A large number of elderly citizens are coming to settle in Queensland each year and that has put a further increase on the demand for nursing homes in the south-east region of Queensland. Actually, I was glad to learn that there will be increases in nursing home benefits. I received a letter from our shadow Minister, Senator Peter Baume, who gave us that information and said that there was certainly a large gap payment that was causing many problems for people in nursing homes. So these benefits have been increased and that, of course, is very good. One thing that I was a little disappointed in, was the fact that in Queensland and Tasmania the amounts are much less than in some of the other States.

I support the notion of moving away from an ad hoc approach to nursing care. The industry is crying out for a needs-based planning approach. It provides for a change in the existing balance between providing intensive care, through nursing homes, and providing appropriate community services and hostel options. I hope that the Government ensures that the welfare of the frail and the aged is the paramount consideration in this shift of emphasis. As I said earlier, I would hate to see a situation where very sick patients are put into hostel-type accommodation where there is perhaps little or no specialised nursing care for them. It is one thing to streamline the operations of nursing home care in the community, but it is another to do so at the expense of the needs of the frail and aged in the community. However, the Opposition parties support this Bill and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, as a member of the Government, am pleased to add my support to this piece of legislation. I think the Government needs to be commended for it. I am also pleased to note that the Opposition, in making its contribution to this debate, in large part is supportive of the general aims and principles in this legislation. It was interesting to hear Senator Giles run us through the history of inquiries in the nursing homes area and I think the Government needs to be congratulated. Perhaps one could say the time was ripe. We have had the inquiries and have found any amount of agreement concerning the importance of assessing the needs of the population and setting limits on the maximum number of nursing home beds and so on. Perhaps the time was ripe but I think it should also be noted that the Government, and the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) in particular, had the will as well. We have had a fairly speedy response from the Minister for Community Services not only on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review but also on this legislation which will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 and make a number of changes in line with the general principles enshrined in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 the amendments will allow the Commonwealth to make grants to eligible organisations to meet the capital costs of homes for aged or disabled people. In particular, it will allow the Commonwealth to provide up to 100 per cent of funding for disadvantaged groups. I think this is very important where, for example, such groups may not be able to find or raise funds to match Commonwealth subsidies. So the Commonwealth, aware of the needs of such groups of people, has provided the option that 100 per cent of the funding of capital costs can be provided by it. Under this Act there has also been an increase in personal care subsidies. These figures will actually increase from $7.80 per day to $8.40 per day from 22 October 1986 and there will be a further increase to $11 per day from 6 May 1987-a total sum of $77 per week, which is a considerable amount in terms of the provision of personal care subsidies. There are other provisions in this legislation for payment to people living in hostels and I will not spell out all the details.

Changes or amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 will allow the Government to establish growth control arrangements over the approval in principle and the approval mechanisms for new nursing homes and new beds in existing nursing homes. I commend Senator Peter Baume for making it absolutely clear that the Opposition understands that there is not to be a decrease in nursing home beds. I simply reiterate that because Senator Bjelke-Petersen's words could have led to a misunderstanding. There is not to be a decrease in nursing home beds; there is to be a control in the rate of growth in new nursing home beds. As Senator Giles spelt out, that is entirely consistent with the thrust of the three reports that she mentioned in this area. Again Senator Baume was quite clear on that. His understanding, which is my understanding and that of the Government, is that there will be no reduction in nursing home beds. But under these amendments the Government will have the ability to set maximums on ordinary beds and special needs beds both in the States and in the regions. This will provide a cost saving over time and those savings will be redistributed to the cost increases under the hostel program. In fact, essentially the amendments have come out as revenue neutral. But I think it is terribly important to say, once again, that there will not be a reduction in nursing home beds; there will be a reduction in the growth rate of nursing home beds.

As well as setting maximums for regions and special needs, the proposals under these amendments will allow a more rational distribution of nursing home beds-again I take up the points raised by my colleague Senator Giles and some of the Opposition speakers-to meet the changes in demography and the changes in the circumstances of communities so that we are not left with a surplus of nursing home beds where there are no people but have the flexibility to adjust the provision of nursing home beds to those areas where people have a need for them. In short, there is an emphasis on trying to provide the nursing home beds as near as possible to where the people who need them live and that is consistent with the other general thrusts of this legislation which I will come to in a moment.

The amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 allow for an increase in capital grants. That cost is assessed to be $0.5m in 1986-87 rising to $2.8m in 1987-88. As well, the increases in subsidy levels and the introduction of automatic indexation mean a cost of $5.6m in 1986-87 rising to $26.5m in 1987-88. Under the amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 the introduction of growth controls in the nursing home area will provide savings of $4m in 1986-87 and $27.7m in 1987-88. If we put those costs and savings against each other we see that the legislation will mean that the net financial impact is more or less financially neutral.

It will certainly not be neutral in terms of its effect on the community. I wanted to make some general points and pick up Senator Baume's point on the philosophy of this legislation. The Opposition has said it welcomes this. As the reports have stated and as Senator Giles has spelt out, the Government is very concerned to provide optimal care for both our aged and our disabled people. It is important to realise that not all disabled people are necessarily aged. It is important to recognise that a number of very young people have disabilities which require very extensive and continual nursing care. While an emphasis is currently moving towards rehabilitation of all disabled people at all ages, not all disabled people are old. I think we have to recognise that and remember it. In the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, of which I was a member, it became clear that there was quite a lot of difficulty and dissatisfaction for young disabled people when the only provision of care available for them was in an elderly persons' nursing home. There was just not sufficient appropriate company, apart from anything else. The service of nursing care may have been adequate, and very often it was, but the community surround for those young people was insufficient. The recommendations in the report urged the separation of young disabled people from the more aged community. I understand that the process of encouraging young disabled people out of aged care provisions and into the community, rather than even to their own nursing home, but as much as possible toward independent living or assisted living in the community, is well under way. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) is very committed to encouraging that to happen as much as possible.

The other point that needs to be stressed is that many people who are sufferers of Alzheimer's disease are not elderly. One of the shocking statistics is that people in their 40s can show early signs of the onset of Alzheimer's disease. I think we have to take a little care, when we talk about legislation in this area, to appreciate that we are talking about a population that is much wider than frail aged people, who may be 75 or 85 years of age. A number of the people needing nursing home care or hostel accommodation are much younger than the aged population to which I have just referred. We have to be careful about that.

Another point which Senator Giles raised and which I think needs to be considered in this area too is that there is a real complexity in providing services for aged or disabled people. For instance, people suffering from senility or Alzheimer's disease-a distinction I draw between those two categories of people-are not in need of hour by hour nursing care. Very often these people are more than able to be up and about, to feed themselves, to do their laundry and in all sorts of ways to look after their own personal needs. Their principal problem is that they need to be restrained. It is hard to know what their diagnostic difficulty is, but they are certainly not able to keep themselves in one place; they wander and they may not be aware of where they are in the world. They may not know their address and they may not remember where they have come from or how they got there. Very often the care they need is some kind of constraint on where they go; that is, they need to have a wall around the perimeter of the place in which they are living and, as Senator Giles said, locks on doors, which is distressing for us. In some ways, it is more distressing for us than for the people who are confined. The point that needs to be made though is that their principal need is for constraint of that sort, not hour by hour nursing care. Very often these people are not in need of the high intensity nursing care that some of the totally disabled and fully bed-ridden people need.

This brings me to another point touched on by Senator Giles: How do we assess the needs of care? It is extraordinarily difficult. Under the home and community care provisions legislation some effort has been made towards addressing that matter by way of assessment teams and making sure that people's needs for care are appropriately matched to the provision of care, if possible. Even within a nursing home or hostel a considerable range of services are needed. For example, people may be incontinent-to pick up the case mentioned by Senator Powell-but for all other reasons perfectly able to manage by themselves. Again, such people do not need high intensity nursing care but may in fact have come to a stage when they cannot manage in their own home or their relatives cannot manage with them at home. So the provision of nursing care for them is very different from that for a totally bed-ridden person who may have had a stroke, some sort of cerebral accident, or a motor car accident. I think that is very important.

Senator Peter Baume raised the point that it is important to have the provisions of amendments open to parliamentary scrutiny and not simply available to the Minister to change by way of gazettal. I spent some time with the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills this morning going through those points and taking note of the Minister's response. I understand that the Minister will address those points at the end of the second reading debate. However, I know from my own experience that, while there are very clearly defined regulations, they can be a constraint on the optimal care and provision of care for people. It is not too long ago-and I am sure Senator Walters will recognise this-when regulations required that for people to be eligible for nursing home benefits they had to be bed-ridden. What happened in nursing homes was that people were encouraged to be bed-ridden. They were kept in bed; they were not encouraged towards programs of rehabilitation and were not encouraged to be up and about or to do for themselves at all. Under the regulations, they would not have been eligible for a subsidy.

We have a tension between the needs of legislation and regulations, or proposed changes under that legislation, to be subject to proper regard or scrutiny by Parliament but at the same time to be flexible enough to provide for optimal provision of care for patients. I know that those two matters are in a bit of tension in this legislation. I do not think that I should come down on one side or the other, but in the area that we are talking about, and from my own experience, I have found it very distressing to see regulations leading to less than proper provision of care for elderly or disabled people. I am hopeful that whatever solution may need to be found, if there is the need for a solution or further discussion between the Opposition about this sort of matter, as much flexibility is allowed to the Minister and to the legislation to enable flexibility at the level of provision of care so that the matron in charge, the doctor prescribing instructions or the family who want things to happen can be clear that they will not lose subsidies and that there will not be constraints on them providing optimal provisions for the care of such people in nursing homes in particular but also, to some extent, in hostels. I think that is really very important.

It is very encouraging to see the changes in the emphasis of care in nursing homes over the last five years or so, perhaps even a little longer, going to such things as the rehabilitation of elderly people. In times past, if an elderly person was admitted to a nursing home, quite clearly there was a feeling of `That is it. We now give up and from Sunday to Sunday we visit and talk to the elderly person'. That is just not the emphasis any more. In fact, both public and private nursing homes are providing rehabilitation programs matched to the needs of the people so that a number of elderly people, who may be admitted for short term surgery or for a stay in a nursing home subsequent to a stroke, are in fact able to return to independent living. This is to be welcomed and is very heartening. People are not being written off once they get into a nursing home. This legislation very much endorses that sort of principle because it goes to flexible provision of where nursing home beds and hostel beds are and encouragement to support the principle of helping people to live independently where they prefer to live, which is very often where they have been living up to this point.

Encouragement of independent living is important. As people become older and more frail some very simple things are beyond their capacity. For example, as was mentioned by Senator Powell, the changing of a light bulb is very difficult for a person with arthritis or a frail, older person, but the simple provision of a new light bulb means that such a person can continue to live very adequately in his or her own home. The support to this legislation which goes under the home and community care provisions and through a number of initiatives from various local governments is to be very much welcomed and encouraged.

The thrust of the legislation is along the lines that we want to help people to live independently and we want to help them to live where they prefer to live, which is usually at home. Importantly, we have to help families of a relative of an older or disabled person to manage with such a person at home. That goes to two points. One is the provision of sufficient community services. For example, ramps might be necessary at home to help somebody with a wheelchair; there may be a need to reconstruct access to a house for cars and so on, or access within a house; there may be a need, too, to provide some kind of respite for such an aged or handicapped person in a hostel. Provisions are made under the amendments in this Bill to allow that to happen.

It is very important that we support the relatives. I am particularly concerned about that because much of the care in this area has been provided in the past by relatives-very often women-in the home. The quite massive contribution that women have made in caring for elderly or disabled people in their families over time has to be acknowledged. It is very important that we do not take away opportunities for people to continue to be generous in that way. A lot of people still prefer to do so. I guess other honourable senators could name as well as I could many people who are willing to make that kind of commitment to their relatives. It is very good that this legislation endorses that and provides for respite if it is necessary so that people can continue as much as possible to support their relatives at home, if that is the preference within the family.

It is very important to appreciate that under the hostel provisions we have a second tier almost-we know that certain people now need some kind of generalised supervision or care but are fairly much able to live independently within those broader constraints. For example, it may be difficult for somebody to clean leaves out of gutters or maintain a household, but once the outside-the walls and the roof-and the payment of rent and so on are looked after a person within such hostel accommodation is able to live perfectly adequately quite independently. I am delighted that the legislation endorses and enshrines that kind of encouragement to people in our community.

As I have said, the nursing home bed provision will continue. The points have been quite well made that there is a need for nursing home beds in this community, and that need will continue. Hopefully we can remove from nursing home beds those people who are most inappropriately placed there. Indeed, I think it was the report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes that found that something like 25 per cent of people could be assessed as being inappropriately placed in nursing home beds. If those beds are freed up by a more appropriate placement of people in hostel accommodation or even, with rehabilitation and encouragement, by returning people home to independent living, while our need for nursing home beds will continue it will do so at a slower rate.

When I became a member of the Senate I joined the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes and had the benefit of the information that was provided to it in submissions and evidence that was sought by that inquiry. It fitted very well with the work that I had been doing prior to coming to the Senate. I am delighted to see that work being fulfilled, at least in part. I think the disability legislation and the home and community care legislation are to be bracketed with this legislation. I am delighted that we have this legislation in place to show clearly the Government's commitment to the recommendations of the Committee following its investigations in that area of nursing homes and hostels. I commend the Government for introducing this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 is, I believe, the first step in a much needed review of government-assisted accommodation for the aged. It is very pleasing that the Opposition is in full agreement with the aim of that legislation, which is to increase the variety of services to the aged in the area of residential accommodation and community services. Like Senator Crowley, I was a member of one of the committees mentioned by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) in his second reading speech, the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. We both had quite an opportunity to go around the country and become very aware of the problems faced by Australian citizens as they get older. However we did not need to go around Australia to know-we knew it from our own experiences-that the aged want to stay at home as long as they possibly can. We have all seen these problems as our relatives have grown old. We all know the traumas of an elderly aunt or elderly parents having to go into a nursing home. Considerable traumas are associated with that. As Senator Crowley said so rightly, previously it was a case of `Once I go into a nursing home that is it'.

SPEECH.PARA: As we get older our capability of looking after ourselves gradually deteriorates. It does not usually happen as a result of a grave illness; it happens over a number of years. We get to the stage at which we are unable to look after our homes properly. This has already been referred to. We become unable to get out of the bath with any assurance. In my early days here, when I was boarding with an elderly woman in Barton, she used to say: `I can always have a bath when you are up here in Canberra because I know that at least you are coming home at night and if I cannot get out you will be there to pull me out'. These are the worries associated with people getting old. Then it goes from not being able to look after one's home and garden to not being able to look after oneself-one's hygiene, cooking and general care-and the worries that are attached to that.

As we travelled around we were told by many of the elderly that they would like an alarm system so that if they were to fall off a stool while trying, for instance, to replace a light bulb in the kitchen they could make sure that someone would know that they had fallen, so that they would not be lying there overnight or perhaps for days. At the moment there is some community care, but we have not really scratched the surface. The most common form of community care at the moment is meals on wheels. I, too, have served on meals on wheels. When one works in the community taking around the hot meal for the day the elderly person to whom one takes it does not want just that meal; he or she very desperately needs someone to whom to chat. I used to find it very difficult just to deliver that meal and walk out.

TALK.START.PARA: —To communicate.

—They wanted to communicate, as Senator Gietzelt says. There is the need for communication. The person delivering meals on wheels is probably the only person to go into their homes for the whole of the day. The need to communicate is really very great. Such people will also ask one to do little jobs for them, such as to post a letter-little things that they cannot do themselves. That need for communication and for someone to enter their homes once a day is very, very important to them. It depends on the State, and on the local government usually, how much assistance in the home is really available to them. Some of the States and local governments have moved in these areas to a considerable extent. Some of the local governments provide quite a degree of home assistance to the elderly; others have not been able to move in that area at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance as Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask whether the Minister is aware that the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure says:

QUESTION.PARA: Taxation revenue losses through non-detection of total taxpayer incomes could conceivably amount to several billion dollars each year.

Is the Minister further aware that the Committee says that, in large measure, this situation `can simply be attributed to the Australian Taxation Office's own internal inadequacies'? I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the Committee that the more efficient use of existing laws and procedures could return more revenue than the combined total of the fringe benefits tax and the alleged savings from the proposed identity card?

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing one must admire occasionally, I think, is the effrontery of these people who sit opposite-the effrontery of these people who have just declared themselves to be on the side of the tax evaders, protecting the tax evaders in opposition as they did in government. To have the effrontery to ask questions--
—I take a point of order. My point of order, Mr President, is that the Minister is starting Question Time very badly, in breach of the Standing Orders, and is debating the question.
—Wimp.
—Wimp.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.
—We withdraw.
—We withdraw.
—I suggest that everyone settle down. If we were playing rugby league we might put someone in the sin bin for five minutes.

—Mr President, would you mind using examples from Australian rules? I do not understand your admonition. My point is that the Minister has simply started obviously with no intention of dealing with the facts in the question but simply of debating it. I ask you to remind him of the Standing Orders and, if he insists on debating the question, to sit him down.
—I will not uphold the point of order at this stage, but I ask Senator Walsh to heed Senator Chaney's remarks.

—This Government is committed to stamping out tax evasion. We have made several attempts since we have been in government to put retrospective legislation through the Senate which would take from tax evaders the ill-gotten gains that they had achieved under the previous Government. Of course, all of those attempts have been resisted by the Liberal and Country parties, by half the Australian Democrats and by Senator Harradine. One of the more notorious-notorious in terms of principle but not terribly important quantitatively, of course-was the way in which that unholy alliance ganged up to protect that pair of crooks, the Kellys, who had been operating a cherry-picker scheme. It was one of the more outrageous examples of a cherry-picker scheme whereby the Kelly brothers had conspired to defraud the Commonwealth revenue and--

—I rise on a point of order. Again the Minister is not addressing himself to the question at all. The question related to a report of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee in which specific statements were made about the present administration of the tax laws under this Government. The Minister clearly is not prepared to face up to the realities of maladministration under his own administration and that of his Government, but I ask you, Mr President, to remind him that this is Question Time and he is under some obligation to direct his remarks to the question which has been raised and not to the latest bit of diatribe that he has come into the place prepared to deliver.

—Order! I would ask the Minister not to engage in debate of the matter. The Minister in answering the question, of course, can use analogies, but I ask him to refrain from debating the matter and come to the question that has been directed to him by Senator Chaney.

—Certainly, Mr President, I have only seen the Press reports. I have not seen the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee report. But, to anybody who has looked seriously at taxation policy at all, it is very clear that two things must be done in order to eliminate tax evasion-or to go very close to eliminating it. First, we have to have an effective identity card system; in other words, the Australia Card, which the Opposition is committed to opposing. Of course, in light of the Opposition's being pushed around by the New Right, as it is, it is not surprising that it is opposing it. The second requirement is a credible threat of retrospective legislation. If any further evidence was required of the need for that, I think it was disclosed on the front page of the Melbourne Age a couple of weeks ago in an article written by Mr McCrann. Mr McCrann, at least in matters where his political bias does not cloud his judgment, is, I think, a very reliable journalist about facts such as that. Mr McCrann alleged that there has been a trans-Tasman tax swindle under which companies with interests in both countries have claimed in both countries tax deductions on interest paid. If that is correct-the facts are being checked out, I understand-it demonstrates that Part IVa, which Mr Howard boasts of having introduced, is not adequate to eliminate fraud against Commonwealth revenue and the only way to really effectively eliminate that sort of fraud is a credible threat of retrospective legislation. In other words, the Opposition claims to be committed to stamping out tax evasion, but everything it actually does, in the way of votes in the Senate and in the House of Representatives, has the effect of protecting tax evaders.

—I ask a supplementary question. It follows the Minister's concentration of his answer on new measures which the Government might take to increase tax collections. My question related to the existing machinery which is available to the Australian Taxation Office and the existing law. I ask him whether he agrees that the Taxation Office is not utilising many of the measures which are already available to it-for example, its existing power to obtain details of all interest payments from institutions.

—I have said that I have only seen some brief newspaper reports; I have not seen that Committee report, so I do not think that I should pass judgment on it. But I do recall that the Commissioner of Taxation, year after year in his annual reports in the late 1970s and the early 1980s, put out an entreaty for more resources in order to more effectively administer the tax laws. Just fortuitously, I have here today the infamous telephone book-the John Howard record, as Treasurer-which Mr Howard was forced to table in 1982 and which contains, I think, a total of some 28 entreaties from the Taxation Commissioner to the then Treasurer to do something about enforcing the payment of tax by certain manipulative and privileged groups in the country. We all know what his response to that was. He sat on his hands for five years while the corporate tax base was eroded to the point where it was in danger of disappearing altogether.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELDERS IXL: INVESTMENT OPPORTUNITIES IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance as Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article on the front page of this morning's Australian Financial Review outlining the early history of Elders IXL and, in particular, the roles of Liberal Party Treasurer, John Elliott, and three associates in founding that corporation? Does the article say that the process of building up Elders IXL began with a $2 company, Akma Pty Ltd, that the four individuals featured in the article each began with assets of between a few hundred dollars and $5,000, and that each is now variously estimated to be worth between $8m and $100m? Is their success story a positive indicator of the opportunities available for investment in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see that story. Indeed, I do find it very hard to understand just where Mr Elliott is and why. The only way I think that I have been able to reconcile the various conflicting statements by Mr Elliott-or at least, the conflicts between the statements he makes and the things he does-is by recognising that sometimes he is acting for himself and sometimes he is a mouthpiece for the Liberal Party of Australia. As I said, I have seen that report, and it just adds to the confusion about Mr Elliott. For example, when he said that there was no incentive to invest in Australia, I thought initially it might just have been that too much Fosters was responsible for that. But if he really believed that, of course, this begs the question of why he spent hundreds of millions of dollars of Elders IXL shares buying himself a seat on the BHP board. He cannot have it both ways. If there is no incentive to invest in Australia-if he really believes that-he should be charged with breach of duty as a company director for using Elders IXL shares to buy himself a seat on the BHP board in the way that he did a while ago.

ANSWER.PARA: I suspect that Mr Elliott is pretty dirty on the Government because he will no longer be able to get away with the sort of de facto embezzlement he pulled in the Henry Jones takeover, which was written about by Terry McCrann in the Age on 15 April this year. McCrann wrote:

Shortly before Elders Smith unveiled its bid for Henry Jones, the leading executives in Henry Jones outlayed $19,000 in taking up one cent paid shares under an executive incentive scheme. The Elders Smith offer delivered a clear tax free profit of $4.16m to those executives. Mr Elliott himself cleared $657,000 on a $3,000 outlay.

He will no longer be able to pick up tax free capital gains of that magnitude. Whether there is incentive to invest in Australia or not, one thing there certainly is incentive to do is to become a director of Elders IXL. It is noted in today's Adelaide Advertiser that the directors have just magnanimously increased by 50 per cent, from $400,000 to $600,000, the remuneration that they may receive as directors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the interest of the Minister for Finance in the collection of taxation, I refer him to the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee's finding that the Australian Taxation Office's record in implementing new technologies, to use its word, has been deplorable. Is the Minister aware that in the past three financial years the Office has failed to spend about $39m allocated to it for computing equipment and associated facilities? Why did this happen? Does the Minister not agree with the Committee that the Australian Taxation Office's approach to data processing has left it with a totally inadequate processing facility, causing significant losses of taxation revenue and imposing unnecessary costs on the taxpayer?

—I have a note from the Treasurer about that section of the report which says, among other things, that the report criticised the Taxation Office's failure to expend the funds allocated to it for computer equipment over a number of years. The figure of $49m shown in the report and tabling statements is inaccurate. A note in the report shows that the true figure per the report should be close to $39m, which I think is the figure Senator Watson used.
—Yes, $39m was the figure I used.

—I know, but it is worth noting that there are inaccuracies in the report-pretty fundamental inaccuracies. Further, the figures in the prior years include a doubling up. Amounts for certain projects were carried forward in successive years, so another heavy qualification has to be put on that figure. In addition, there was an Australian supplier which was unable to deliver equipment to schedule. Despite this failure, there was pressure to persist with the contract. Those problems with the supplier meant that the allocation could not be spent in the year. The two major areas of underspending are the prescribed payments system and the replacement data entry system. The data entry system money has now been spent and the system installed, but the PPS has not yet been concluded.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I and other senators have received representations from the Returned Services League and other ex-service men's and women's organisations strongly opposing any attempts to amalgamate the Department of Veterans' Affairs with other departments. Will the Minister give an assurance to this chamber that amalgamation or incorporation along the lines rumoured will not occur under this present Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as Senator Tate suggests, that there was Press conjecture and speculation some months ago suggesting that there was a master plan for the amalgamation of departments. That caused some anxiety in the veterans' community and in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This led to a question being asked of the Prime Minister yesterday at the weekly meeting of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party. The Prime Minister gave that Caucus meeting a complete assurance that under this Government there would be no amalgamation of the Department. I hope that that will allay some of the suspicions and anxieties that may have existed.

ANSWER.PARA: I wish I could give the same assurances, however, to veterans as to what would happen under a Liberal-National coalition government, having regard to some of the decisions made at the Thredbo conference of the Liberal Party last weekend. That meeting agreed to establish a super-ministry concept and in those circumstances, as many business organisations suggested, the Department of Veterans' Affairs would be amalgamated. The threat comes not from this Government, but from the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate give an unqualified assurance that the Government will proceed with the imputation legislation as promised? If so, when will the draft legislation be available for study, and when will it be introduced into the Parliament?

—I give an assurance that the imputation legislation will be introduced, but I am unable to give a precise answer on the second part of the question. I shall obtain an answer and advise Senator Siddons as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and refers to the recent proposal to build a high temperature toxic waste incinerator 40 kilometres from Tennant Creek. Has the Minister noted the statement made by Dr Mark Stafford-Smith on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Territory Extra program that 20 kilos a year of extremely poisonous chemicals would be released into the environment from a plant such as this? What feasibility and environmental impact studies are being carried out concerning this proposal? What action has the Government taken following the strong opposition to the plant voiced by the organisation representing the Tennant Creek Aboriginal town camp, the Julalikan Council? Is it correct that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment believes that this incinerator should be a private commercial venture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hazardous waste management within Australia, including siting and regulation of hazardous waste disposal facilities, is primarily the responsibility of State and Territory governments. Responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government in this field relate par- ticularly to international aspects-for example, imports and exports of hazardous wastes-and the encouragement and facilitation of a national approach to waste management where appropriate. There is no facility in Australia capable of destroying highly stable organochlorine waste materials and other intractable wastes. Incineration of these wastes in a specialised incinerator capable of operation at a very high temperature is the only proven, environmentally acceptable means available for their disposal. Substantial quantities of organochlorine wastes are being stockpiled in Australia pending availability of facilities for their destruction.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government, in common with State governments, supports the objective of establishing a high temperature incinerator in Australia. However, any facility proposed would need to be constructed and operated according to stringent environmental conditions so as to avoid environmental contamination. Such plants operate in Europe and North America in a fashion which does not cause damage to the environment or the health of the community. The Government, on behalf of the Australian Environment Council, has sponsored national consultations which have the specific objective of addressing possible public concern surrounding establishment of a high temperature incinerator in Australia. I am advised that the Northern Territory is proceeding with feasibility and environmental impact studies in relation to the proposal for an incinerator near Tennant Creek. Dealings with the local community and arrangements for commercial management of the proposed project are the responsibility of the Northern Territory Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that public hospitals will be subject to the fringe benefits tax on the difference between the amount allowed for accommodation in nursing awards and the assessed value of that accommodation? Why has the Government decided to reduce further the ability of public hospitals, for example in my State of New South Wales, to cope with the health care crisis in the community by imposing on those hospitals a substantial extra tax burden? Does the Minister suggest that the hospitals should now cash out the benefit by increasing nursing salaries?

—Specifically on that question, I have no idea what hospitals charge and what the likely assessed value of board will be. Subject to some concessions and exemptions which were announced a couple of weeks ago and before, the general principle which applies to fringe benefits taxation is that where there is an employer-employee relationship and the employee receives benefits in kind, on which a monetary value can be placed, then the employer will be liable to pay the tax on those fringe benefits. I can only assume that the Opposition believes that income in kind can be substituted for wages and salaries and that nothing should be done about that. That is what Mr Howard says publicly-that there should be no tax on fringe benefits and that the fringe benefits tax should be abolished lock, stock and barrel. Mr Sinclair, of course, says that this taxation should be picked up under section 26 (e) and meanwhile Mr Howard, as part of the secret tax agenda for the Liberal Party, has his own beavers working away on legislation for his particular variant of the fringe benefits tax. That has been going on for some months. Publicly Mr Howard says that there should be no tax on fringe benefits and that this tax should be abolished lock, stock and barrel. If I may say so, that attitude is consistent with the view that he adopted when he was Treasurer. I have a document-it is part of the telephone book of documents I have with me-which shows that when the Commissioner of Taxation early in 1978 replied to some earlier correspondence, he noted that the Government of the day had taken a decision not to tax fringe benefits. At least that much is consistent about Mr Howard. When he was Treasurer he took a decision that fringe benefits should not be taxed and he is now saying publicly that they should not be taxed. He is consistent up to that point. But of course with his secret agenda he has a group of people beavering away to produce his variant of the taxation of fringe benefits. Should he ever become Prime Minister-that is highly unlikely; he is unlikely to survive another six months as leader of the Liberal Party, let alone become Prime Minister-he will follow the secret tax agenda.
—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister telling me that the accommodation provided for nurses in public hospitals is in the nature of a fringe benefit and therefore will attract the tax?

—I do not know what charge is levied for that accommodation. I have spelt out the general principle and if Senator Peter Baume wants an answer to that specific question, I will refer it to the Treasurer.

—Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs seen the allegations in Press statements by the Opposition shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs and other Opposition members to the effect that what they describe as left wing elements, including the Minister himself, peace activists and so-called trendy historians, are seeking to distort the focus of the Australian War Memorial? It is alleged that these elements are seeking a change in the Memorial from one commemorating Australians who served and died in wars to a peace memorial. How does the Minister respond to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the inquiry into the Australian War Memorial began a couple of months ago, there have been a number of obviously contrived letters to the newspapers suggesting that there was some sort of hidden agenda in respect of the problems of administration at the War Memorial. There is absolutely no substance in the allegations that were made by the shadow Minister or, for that matter, by the honourable member for the Northern Territory in the adjournment debate last evening and by other such persons who have written letters suggesting that an attempt is being made by the Government, the Minister or historians at the War Memorial to change the character and nature of that Memorial. Never at any time have I sought to change the direction or the policy of the War Memorial. In discussions with members of the Council of the Australian War Memorial, with staff members or with any other person associated with the War Memorial, I have never sought to change the functions of or reasons for the Australian War Memorial Act or the structures or responsibilities that flowed from that Act. The Government is satisfied that the Australian War Memorial's policies reflect the aspirations of that Memorial-that is that they reflect Australia's involvement in past conflicts and commemorate those who served and died in those conflicts.

ANSWER.PARA: It would be totally wrong for government, Ministers or any other persons to find themselves in the position of Mr Nakasone, the Prime Minister of Japan, whose Minister for Education sought to distort the historical involvement of the Japanese in the invasion of China in the late 1920s and the 1930s. Therefore, any suggestion that any person would seek to distort the historical position of Australia's involvement in past conflicts would be obviously laughable and completely unacceptable, not only to the Government but, I would hope, to every member of the Parliament. Consequently, any suggestions made by so-called responsible people in the Opposition that there is some sort of hidden agenda will be refuted by me and the Government because the conflicts which exist over the Australian War Memorial are about administration and not about policy directions.

Of course, within the community there are different concepts about how history can be recorded. For example, I have received complaints from the Vietnam Veterans' Association that the Memorial's gallery on Australia's involvement in Vietnam does not correctly reflect the total position with respect to the Vietnam War. That is a view that that organisation holds and obviously people will hold different views about the way in which the Council accepts its responsibilities. However, I repudiate completely any suggestion that I have at any time entertained any thoughts of changing the basic thrust and responsibilities on which the Australian War Memorial Council carries out its functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that, despite the review of the fringe benefits tax, churches which provide accommodation for youth workers or other non-religious personnel are still subject to tax on the value of that accommodation? Is the now confirmed intended consequence of the fringe benefits tax a fair way to treat the providers of non-profit services to the community?

—I do not know whether these facts, as alleged by Senator Sheil, are correct. However, I do know that the Opposition is consistently on the side of the tax evaders, a lesson which it drove home in a most convincing manner yesterday when it made a formal decision to oppose the Australia Card. That means that tax evaders, people operating in the black economy and people moonlighting can continue to evade tax without fear of being caught in the future as they have done in the past. It also means that those people who are cheating on the welfare system may continue to do so. Some spectacular cheats are occasionally caught, put into court and sentenced to substantial terms of imprisonment, as they should be, like the guy who was claiming 54 unemployment benefits and pocketing the lot himself. However, whether welfare frauds are doing it spectacularly or on a more modest scale, thanks to the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, they will be able to defraud more effectively the welfare and taxation systems in the future. That is thanks entirely to the declared policy position of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. It is of course known that there is a ginger group in the Liberal Party--
—Order! The Minister is now clearly debating the issue and is in breach of standing order 100. I ask him to return to Senator Sheil's question.

—You are quite correct, Mr President. Nothing has really changed. In government and in opposition, Mr Howard is on the side of the tax evaders. The only time as Treasurer that he took effective action against some of the most outrageous tax evasion schemes, the notorious bottom of the harbour schemes, was when he was flushed out by the publication of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the McCabe-Lafranchi report.
—Order! Again, I remind the Minister that he is clearly debating the subject.
—I have finished, Mr President.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. As these institutions are non-profit and the services are given on a non-profit basis, does the Minister really classify these people as tax evaders?

—Where an employer and employees have reached an agreement to provide income partly in cash and partly in kind, the effect of that agreement is to reduce Commonwealth revenue. It is precisely that practice that the Government's legislation is directed to stop. Of course, on the other hand, we know that the temporary Leader of the Opposition says that there should not be any tax on fringe benefits; in other words, that the system should be wide open to rorts in the future, as it was when he was the Treasurer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED KINGDOM-UNITED STATES OF AMERICA AGREEMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is Australia a signatory to the United Kingdom-United States of America Agreement? Is it a fact that under this Agreement the National Security Agency operates electronic intercept stations in Australia? Does any other form of station operate in Australia under the Agreement? If so, is it operated by an Australian or an overseas authority, or is it operated under some sort of joint authority? Will he identify the participating country or countries in any such agreement?

—In accordance with the long-standing practice of this and previous governments, I decline to provide information which might confirm or deny speculation on the intelligence and security matters raised in Senator Vallentine's question.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister aware that this very same question was asked by Mr Hayden of Prime Minister Fraser on 9 March 1977?
—Order! The honourable senator is adding new material and I rule that that question is not a supplementary question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I seek clarification of the estimated revenue from the fringe benefits tax and the substantiation requirements. It may be that the Minister will have to seek this information for me. Will the Minister confirm that in the last Budget the collections from the fringe benefits tax were stated as $575m, giving a total revenue collection of $680m if one adds the $105m from substantiation estimated by the Treasurer in September 1985? Can the Minister explain why on 29 October the total was stated as $775m, from which the Government said it will cut $75m as a result of the fringe benefits tax review? Does the Minister agree that, despite its review, the Government is still collecting $700m, which is $80m more than just over a year ago it said that it would collect, and $20m more than was forecast as recently as the August Budget? Will the Minister advise what figure is included in the $700m which relates to substantiation?

—I was not able to follow all of the figures that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle gave but I think there was an apparent inconsistency between them. If one takes estimates from particular times, there is an apparent inconsistency. The reason for that is that the original estimates that were made were subsequently revised. There has been at least one revision since the Budget figures were prepared. The most recent estimates-I will check this with the Treasurer-are that for a full year the fringe benefits tax will yield $520m and the substantiation requirements will add $180m, making $700m in total, which I think was one of the figures that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle gave. That is the most recent estimate but there have been revisions from time to time, which of course is not at all unusual, as more knowledge and information come to hand. That accounts for what I think were apparent inconsistencies in the figures that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle cited. I do not know whether there was another purpose to the question, to show that there is something wrong with collecting more revenue. To the extent that revenue estimates have been revised upwards, and if that revision is more accurate than the earlier estimates, that of course demonstrates that there was an even greater need for the fringe benefits tax than had previously been believed.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Defence seen Monday's Brisbane Sun which reported the Queensland minority Premier as calling for the establishment of a political army? Can the Minister comment on whether it is a treasonable offence to establish alternative defence units in Australia? Is the Federal Government prepared for this type of insurgency? Does the Minister have any rational advice to such minority fringe groups who seek to overthrow the democratic traditions of this country?
—I call the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I am sure he will heed my advice not to proffer a legal opinion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether the propositions advanced by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and miscellaneous acolytes around the place, such as Andrew Hay, might amount to the offence of treason under section 24 of the Crimes Act, which relates to levying war against the Commonwealth, would be a matter for the proper authorities. All I can really say is that the issue need not concern us unduly because, quite apart from the legal position of such an army, there must be quite serious doubts about the ability of extremists such as Mr Hay to muster troops and to hold together any kind of united force. I remind the Senate that last month Mr Hay went on a very expensive public campaign against the fringe benefits tax yet managed to attract only an estimated 80 people to an extraordinarily heavily publicised anti-tax rally in Hobart, and even fewer people as a proportion of the population in other capital cities-hardly a popular uprising. Earlier this year he was not able even to maintain unity among his senior officers, as was evidenced by the angry departure from the Australian Federation of Employers of Mr John Leard, who I see has now gone off to mount a pop-gun revolution of his own.

ANSWER.PARA: The kinds of antics mounted by these characters in the New Right suggest nothing but that, if one is looking for a military metaphor, we are confronted with a latter-day version of Dad's Army, which I suppose is only marginally preferable to the kind of grand-dad's army that we might have to contemplate were the minority Premier Bjelke-Petersen to succeed in his aspirations to come south. The Federal Government is clearly able and willing by all available means to meet this and any other half-baked insurgency that might emanate from the north. As to the advice I am asked to give to the Premier, to Mr Hay and to the gaggle of vulgar populists such as Katharine West who follow their banner, I simply advise them to stop trying to jump on to a right wing authoritarian band wagon of the kind that they are engaged in. It is out of the Australian character. It is not consistent with either the temperament or the intelligence of their fellow Australians. They ought to go home and grow up.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the Minister to a communique issued by the Australian Minerals and Energy Council at its meeting in Canberra on 7 November, and particularly to the section dealing with taxation of gold mining which states:

QUESTION.PARA: State and Territory Ministers sought early action by the Commonwealth on the report of the Inquiry into the Taxation of Gold. Some States and the Northern Territory pressed for continued exemption of the gold industry from income tax.

I ask the Minister: Firstly, does he agree that early action should be taken by the Commonwealth in relation to the report of the inquiry, on which the Government has been sitting like a frightened hen since 29 August last? Secondly, when does the Government intend to announce its decision on that matter and on that report? Thirdly, will the Government make the report public and, if so, when? Fourthly, which States pressed for the continued exemption of gold from income tax and which States supported the tax?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the suggestion that we have been sitting like frightened hens on the Gutman report; I suggest that confident cocks would be a much more apt description of our reaction to this and other difficult policy issues that confront us. I accept that an early decision would be desirable in this matter. The Government acknowledges the dangers of uncertainty continuing for too long in this matter. I am sure that the Treasurer and those responsible in the first instance for this decision will act accordingly to set the industry fears at rest. I do not propose to go into any more detail about who might have said what, so far as the different Ministers are concerned. Proceedings of ministerial councils are robust but confidential-except to the extent to which they are willingly put on the public record. This is a matter in which the positions of the various jurisdictions have been publicly articulated on a number of occasions. The Government is perfectly capable of making a rational policy decision and will do so in its own good time.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I asked the Minister a question which he totally ignored: Will the Government make the report public, and, if so, when?
—When we make either a decision to make the report public or a decision on the substantive policy issue, or both. In either event, it will be in our own good time.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware of a purported public information paper released by the Australian Computer Society which claims that the Government intends to merge some two dozen computer databases from nine different government departments or agencies under the Australia Card program? Does the Government's planning involve any such merger of databases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has given me the following information, which followed his reading of the Australian Computer Society paper, which is so riddled with misinformation that one wonders why the Society bothered with it. The author, Mr Roger Clarke, either has shown a complete misunderstanding of the Australia Card program or, more likely, I suppose, has chosen to ignore and to distort the facts.
—Why should he?

—Wait, Senator. For example, the claim that the Government intends to merge some two dozen databases from nine different government agencies is completely false. There will be nothing other than the basic identification material on either the Australia Card or the Australia Card register, and there will be most definitely no merging of databases. The superficiality of the Society's paper is demonstrated by the suggestion that consideration of the Australia Card proposal should be deferred until a privacy protective regime has been firmly established. As all honourable senators know, this is exactly what the Government has done with the Data Protection Agency which will be established under the Australia Card Bill and the Privacy Bill which will be enacted in tandem with it. It is also wrong to suggest that the Australia Card program is designed to enable automatic computer matching to be undertaken. In fact, there will be no exchange of information other than that which already happens and, indeed, for the first time, the Data Protection Agency will place strict limitations over the exchange of information available.

ANSWER.PARA: Every assertion in the paper is based on distortion, misinformation or conjecture, so that it really does the professional reputation of the Australian Computer Society no good. The Opposition has, of course, picked up this paper and has resorted to using scare tactics about the Australia Card in order to hide how weak it is about tackling tax evasion and social welfare fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! If it is a tax measure, why is it being introduced by the Minister for Health? Answer that one.

—That is because the Health Insurance Commission is the administrative body. At least we are making some efforts to do something about tax evasion, unlike the previous Treasurer who, as Senator Walsh happens to point out, spent a lot of time avoiding doing anything about tax evasion, as indicated by the famous telephone book that Senator Walsh carries around with him at all times.
—He has his finger in the wrong hole.

—We know all about people who had fingers in what, with Patrick Partners; so let us not have too much of that. The Australian Computer Society has been done over by Mr Roger Clarke, who is obviously acting for party political reasons. I understand that the Australian Computer Society is now embarrassed by the paper and embarrassed that it has been done over by this gentleman, and that in future it will not be putting its name to ridiculous papers of this type.

—Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs inform the Senate of the reasons why the Hon. Des Corcoran, a former Labor Premier of South Australia, a man with a very distinguished service record and a member of an equally distinguished military family, was not reappointed to the Australian War Memorial Council?

—It is very interesting to find Senator Jessop being very much interested in the career of a former Labor Party leader in South Australia. I fully support Mr Corcoran in that particular capacity. However, the matter of appointment to the War Memorial Council is one for the Government, and I do not propose to canvass it in this place.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Community Services. Has he seen the advertisement in the Australian of 6 November headed `A letter to the Commonwealth Parliament' and signed by Mr Doug Moran? Is he aware that Mr Moran is criticising the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill and claims that the Government will deny aged and frail people sufficient nursing home care? Can the Minister say whether there is any substance to the criticisms and whether Mr Moran is specially qualified to criticise this legislation and to speak for the frail aged in the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As for the latter part of Senator Crowley's question, I would find it difficult to understand how Mr Moran could be qualified to speak for the poor and disadvantaged in the community. He is, in fact, one of Australia's most astute and successful nursing home entrepreneurs; of that there is no question. The fact that he could afford to pay about $16,000 or $18,000 for a full page advertisement in a newspaper in that way demonstrates that. I also draw attention to the fact that a similar advertisement was put in by Mr Moran, where he has sponsored a portrait prize in this country, the prize money for which is $190,000, which is, I understand, the highest amount of money for a portrait prize in the world. I am not objecting to these activities. They certainly demonstrate his skill as an entrepreneur. But they also demonstrate, first, that he, as the proprietor of 20-plus nursing homes and the agent running more than that number, is not doing too badly if he can afford that sort of money for that kind of art prize and those sorts of advertisements.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind honourable senators that a large proportion of Mr Moran's income comes from the public purse. The nursing home benefits which are paid to his nursing homes and the ones that he operates for others provide him with considerable income and considerable wealth. He is also very familiar with the mechanisms for administrative review of the nursing homes legislation as it exists at present. For many years he has consistently appealed against decisions of various Ministers. I note that an appeal has been lodged over one decision of this Government, which will involve a full four weeks of the time of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which will involve considerable public funds in providing legal aid for the community organisation being appealed against. In fact, I know that sometimes I and some Ministers of previous governments have wondered who administers the nursing homes legislation-the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Federal Court, Mr Moran, or the Minister and the Government.

What we have been trying to do is to introduce legislation, after considerable consultation with non-government organisations, government organisations, private organisations and the representatives of the aged people in this community, and this legislation is the result of reviews that have been conducted for the last 10 years, and the result of a nursing homes and hostels review by this Government, which has been considerably discussed throughout the community in the last two years, both before the report came out and since then. To suggest, as he suggests in the advertisement, that this legislation is being rushed through the Parliament without consultation is extraordinary.

I have some sympathy for Mr Moran, I suppose, because politicians sometimes find themselves in a similar situation. He has spent some $16,000 or $18,000, maybe more, putting this advertisement in the paper. One journalist in the whole country has bothered to ask me about it. As far as I am concerned, no newspaper carried any comment on it. He must be disappointed that such considerable expenditure has created so little interest in the media generally. I admire him for his astuteness as an entrepreneur, I admire him for his capacity to achieve considerable wealth as a result of his activities in the nursing home profession, and I admire him for spending some of that money on the arts; but I do not admire his attempts to influence the Parliament in such a crude way. I wish that he would spend more time discussing these matters both with my Department and in fact with me, and I dare say with the Opposition, rather than trying to address this Parliament through expensive full page advertisements which have little effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the poisoning of the Rhine River from pesticides and mercury by the Sandoz chemical company, which demonstrates what can result from chemical spillage into waterways, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment: Does the Government support the development of the Kurnell peninsula as an area suitable for the siting of a hazardous chemicals industry, including the planned establishment by the Bayer chemical company of a pesticide formulation and chemical manufacturing plant at Kurnell, close to the internationally recognised Towra Point nature reserve wetlands? Consistent with the Government's obligations under the Japan-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement and the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands, has the Government informed the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources that the Towra Point nature reserve wetlands may change as a result of technological developments, pollution or other human developments should these proposals go ahead?

—As a practical matter, land use and land management at the Kurnell peninsula are primarily the responsibility of the New South Wales Government. I am advised that the Bayer Australia Ltd proposal to relocate its operations to Kurnell peninsula does not require Commonwealth approval. The Government recognises its obligations under both the Japan-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement and the Ramsar Convention, and in this context the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has written to the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment emphasising that every effort must be made to protect the wetlands from any serious risk of ecological damage. Additionally, the New South Wales Minister has been asked to ensure that the New South Wales representative on the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers working group on international agreements relating to migratory and wetlands birds keeps the working group fully informed on actions being taken to protect the Towra Point nature reserve.
—In the light of recent Press reports, I ask the Minister for Finance what role the New Right is playing in its support for tax avoiders--
—Order! The honourable senator must relate his question to the Minister's portfolio. I trust that he will do that.
—I will, Mr President. What are the financial ramifications for the Federal economy of the unveiled threat of the Howard-led Liberal Party mission to torpedo the Australia Card concept?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 10-year effect of the Opposition's decision to oppose the introduction of the Australia Card is that tax evaders and those indulging in welfare frauds will rob-I use that word advisedly-their fellow citizens of about $4 1/2 billion. That is what is likely to happen over a 10-year period because of the actions of the Opposition, with the support of the Australian Democrats. As I said earlier in Question Time, that decision by the Opposition is entirely consistent with Mr Howard's record in government, when he allowed massive evasion of the taxation system and refused to take any really effective deterrent action against such evasion until the publication of the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports put him in the position where it was politically untenable for him to do anything else.
