We know, of course, that there are many pressures on Mr Howard to behave in the way he has done, and one significant pressure comes from the New Right, or at least from some of its members, chief among whom I suppose is Andrew Hay, former private secretary to another Liberal Party Treasurer, Sir Phillip Lynch. I have in this `telephone book' a minute from the Commissioner of Taxation dated 20 July 1977 in which the Commissioner was responding to a number of alleged tax evasion schemes which had been earlier forwarded to him. On one, a share trading scheme, the Commissioner outlined the ways in which it was possible that such a share trading tax evasion scheme could work, and then said:

ANSWER.PARA: However, this kind of scheme would then be open to attack under the gift duty law.

Gift duty was then promptly abolished. So to the extent that the gift duty law was a deterrent to the use of that tax evasion scheme, that tax evasion was then facilitated by the Fraser Government abolishing gift duty. Presumably it then became open slather. That was at the time Andrew Hay was the principal private secretary to the Treasurer, Sir Phillip Lynch, and I presume was facilitating tax evasion in that capacity, as he continues to do. It ought to be noted that I have received some complaints from Lady Lynch, and indeed a report was published in the Melbourne Herald, I think in September, in which Lady Lynch said effectively that Mr Hay had not helped to organise the Stumpy Gully affair-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is clearly out of order. I ask him to resume his seat.

—My question is addressed to you, Mr President. During Question Time we have had attacks by Ministers on Mr Clarke, Mr Elliott, Mr Andrew Hay, Mr John Hay, Sir Phillip Lynch, Lady Lynch by inference, and a Mr Moran. Will you refer to the Standing Orders Committee what action might be taken to protect the citizens of this country in a situation where anyone who dares to oppose this Government is bucketed in the Senate by Ministers who have no sense of morality or decency?

—On a point of order, Mr President: Should you consider to look seriously at the question raised by Senator Chaney, I wonder whether you would take into account the actions of previous Leaders of the Government now on the Opposition side. I can remember when they spent 10 minutes bucketing a distinguished professor in this country, Professor Manning Clark, without a complaint from Senator Chaney.

—In reply to Senator Chaney's question, he would know that the naming of the people mentioned by him in his question is completely within the bounds of the existing Standing Orders. Senator Chaney, as a member of the Standing Orders Committee, would know that next Monday night another meeting of the Committee is scheduled and he will be entitled to raise any matter he thinks fit. I would suggest to the honourable senator, though, that the matter he has raised is more a matter for the Privileges Committee than the Standing Orders Committee.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, relates to the report into the administration of the Australian War Memorial which was presented to the Government yesterday. The report considers in detail questions relating to the transfer of the Australian War Memorial's bank accounts and advice provided by the Director to the Australian War Memorial's Executive Council and the Minister at the time. The report was damning of the Director's performance in this matter and I ask the Minister whether he has considered the issues raised in the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as Senator Elstob suggested, that the report into the Australian War Memorial makes a number of serious findings in relation to the involvement of the Director in the transfer of bank accounts from the Commonwealth Bank to the Westpac Banking Corporation. The report finds that he reacted contrary to the strong advice given to him by a senior officer of the Australian War Memorial and that he gave false information both to the Executive Committee of the Australian War Memorial Council as well as to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and the Parliament concerning the way in which the Australian War Memorial administration had canvassed a number of banks before transferring the account from the Commonwealth Bank to Westpac. If this were not so serious the activities of the Director in this matter would be almost laughable.

ANSWER.PARA: When the Director was first asked by the investigator, Mr Jones, to explain what discussions had taken place with different bankers about transferring the account he nominated the branches of four banks and named four bank managers as having been contacted. Mr Jones's inquiries revealed that the banks concerned knew nothing about the matter. When Mr Jones again took this matter up with the Director he acknowledged that he had misled Mr Jones but said that he had not intended to imply that he had talked to the bank managers he had nominated. Rather, the Director claimed that he had visited each bank deliberately as a private individual and discussed their services with the counter staff. This explanation almost defies belief and indicates that, whenever faced with a difficult situation, the Director prevaricates or treats the truth rather carelessly. Naturally, Mr Jones, to use his words, found that the reply of the Director compounded the problem as far as the transfer of that bank account was concerned.

If the Director is to be believed the counter staff of banks in Canberra need to be specifically alert the next time a potential customer, who looks as though he represents a statutory authority with an account of some millions of dollars, leans confidentially across the counter and asks in a whisper: `What are you offering?'. It seems to me that they would be within their rights if they believed that the person was from the Australian War Memorial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer and the completely unsatisfactory situation which is faced by him, having regard to this material, will the Minister table the Auditor-General's report on this matter?
—I am quite happy to table the document and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard. It is not a very long document and it canvasses a number of the matters-

—I hope that the document is not a long document. A long document was incorporated in Hansard yesterday, as the Minister knows, and I trust that this is not a long document because it becomes quite expensive.
—No.
—Order! The Minister has tabled the document. Is leave given for its incorporation in Hansard?
—Not until I have seen it, in accordance with the guidelines that were suggested. Leave is not granted until I have seen it.
—Leave is not granted for incorporation of the document.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, at 8.30 a.m. today, two honourable senators each submitted letters in accordance with standing order 64-the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, proposing a matter of urgency and Senator Harradine proposing a matter of public importance. To decide which letter should be submitted to the Senate, I determined the matter by lot in the presence of Senator Chaney, Senator Harradine and the Clerk of the Senate. In accordance with the result of that procedure, I now read Senator Harradine's letter which is dated today's date:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 64 I propose that the following Matter of Public Importance be submitted for consideration:

The substantial loss in net disposable income suffered by male and female wage and salary earners with family responsibilities by comparison to other wage and salary earners at all levels under Federal and State Awards and the need for the Government to redress this situation as a necessary adjunct to a more realistic and just wages policy and to give a fair go for all families.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance would be one of the most important to be discussed because it is time to face the fact that wage and salary earners with family responsibilities have suffered discrimination, at least over the last 10 years. The reason that I have put this matter forward today is that I know that discussions are taking place within Government circles, trade union circles and employer circles about the attitude they are about to take on the next national wage case. This is a plea to acknowledge that discrimination against wage and salary earners at all levels of Federal and State awards has occurred, is continuing to occur and is getting worse. It is a plea to understand why this discrimination has occurred; it is a plea to recognise the damaging consequences of this discrimination; and, most importantly, it is a plea to redress this discrimination. Unless this discrimination is redressed, the Parliament and, more particularly the labour movement, the Government, and the trade union movement, will lose credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the facts? By comparison with others in the work force the net disposable income of male and female workers with family responsibilities under all Federal and State awards has fallen substantially. Not only has it fallen substantially but also these families have been saddled with an unduly greater share of the taxation burden. As an example of what I am saying let me take a family with four children living on average earnings. The standard of living of that family has dropped by 11 per cent over the last 10 years and will fall a further one per cent by June next year, even allowing for the much trumpeted tax cuts. Any worker with family responsibilities who thinks the tax cuts will redress the situation has another think coming. In fact, given the tax cuts, the purchasing power of that family, as described, next financial year will be $1,230 less than the purchasing power of the same sized family in 1976. On the other hand, the purchasing power of a couple with no children and a combined income of one and a half times average weekly earnings will be $910 more than for the same unit in 1976.

We must ask ourselves: Why are we not acknowledging this? We must surely acknowledge that the discrimination has occurred. Pointers to this acknowledgment have been tabled in the Parliament. The most recent one was tabled yesterday, but the one to which I wish to refer is the Social Security Review, Issues Paper No. 1, `Income Support for Families with Children'. That was forwarded to Parliament three weeks ago. On page 6 of that document the review committee says:
Payments to families with children in Australia developed as an adjunct to wages policy, recognising that wages do not take account of family responsibilities.

National wage decisions in the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in 1974 and 1977 determined that wage fixation should no longer consider the issue of ``family needs'' which had been an integral part of the Australian concept of the basic wage.

As I well remember, this question was canvassed during discussions on the total wage. It is now 19 years since the total wage was introduced. Now is the appropriate time to consider what has happened, specifically since 1974, when the decision about the minimum wage was taken. In that decision in 1974 the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission said:

The Commission has pointed out in the past that it is an industrial arbitration tribunal, not a social welfare agency. We believe that the care of family needs is principally a task for governments. For the reasons mentioned we have decided that the family component should be discarded from the minimum wage concept . . .

From that time at least formally, and before that time in effect, the family factor has been excluded from consideration of wages by industrial tribunals. I might point out that it is only in the last 20 years, and particularly since the introduction of the total wage in 1967 and that decision on the minimum wage in 1974, that the family factor has ceased formally to be taken into account by industrial tribunals in considering wages policies advocated by unions. Institutionalised union advocacy on behalf of the family wage earner has thereby been lost, and the fate of the worker with family responsibilities has been left to the vagaries of politics.

What has happened in those vagaries of politics? As the Social Security Review mentioned, since 1976, when the tax rebates for children were taken away from taxpayers and were cashed into a family allowance system, all families have experienced a decline in their disposable incomes relative to individuals and couples without children. I refer to page 10 of the review. Additionally, on page 56, the review says that the taxation burden has shifted towards families with children. This has resulted in families bearing a greater share of the tax burden.

I refer to that Government document because, in telling us that we are in a crisis situation and that the standard of living of every Australian cannot be expected to increase but can be expected to decline, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that that burden must be shared equitably. The point of this matter of public importance is that the burden has not been shared equitably, is not being shared equitably and, if present policies are to continue, will not be shared equitably-quite the reverse. One must ask oneself also: Why has this discrimination occurred? Particularly where we have a Federal government which ought to have regard to its traditional family supporters, why are its present policies acting against that traditional support? It is clear to me that the advice that it has been getting from the largely two-income aristocracy of Canberra is in effect lobbying for policies which discriminate against workers with family responsibilities.

The policy, might I say, is playing into the hands of the New Right, the new establishment, which seeks to pursue policies which will ensure an oversupply of labour. Let me prove that point. In the Financial Australian of 23 October 1986, in the report of an interview between Rowena Stretton and a self-styled member of the new establishment, Darrel Drieberg, it is stated that he is Managing Director of the recently floated Trans Equity Ltd. It states:
He is rich, entrepreneurial and tough-but likeable.
At 37, he is divorced and earns an undisclosed sum well above $100,000 a year.
He talks about ``the youngsters'' in the business community flexing their muscle and promotes the ideal of ``being a high net worth individual''.
If he was in political control of Australia he would maintain a high level of unemployment as an economic weapon-``it's always nice to have a surplus of just about everything''.
``I don't get hooked up in the inequities. I want what you might call a dog-eat-dog world with degrees of excellence and efficiencies.

``Attitudes are changing. There's a mental revolution. It's survival of the fittest. People say the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer and society will break down . . . but society will never break down.''

TALK.START.PARA: —A miserable philosophy.

—Exactly. That push to create an oversupply in the labour market is one which I believe is being pursued by the advisers to the Government. I mention particularly the Office of the Status of Women because Senator Susan Ryan is in the chamber. I do this in all seriousness. I believe the proposal that has been put forward by the Office of the Status of Women, as indicated by the Director of that Office, concerning the need to ensure that 85 per cent of married women are in the work force is one which should concern the Government. It flies in the face of what was said by the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, in his John Curtin Memorial Lecture in Perth in September 1983. Bob Hawke said:

SPEECH.PARA: The plain fact is that no government in Australia will now, or in the foreseeable future, solve the problem of unemployment solely through the available methods of increasing the supply of jobs. At least equal attention must be paid to the question of reducing the demand for jobs by helping to provide socially constructive alternatives.
That is what the Prime Minister said in Perth in September 1983. What more socially constructive alternative to paid work is there than the raising of a family by a spouse?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not just for women.

—But the plain fact is that it is naturally women who seek to achieve that goal, and it is unfortunate that the advice that has been given to the Government in respect of these matters is coming from people who have priorities which are obviously not the Prime Minister's. We must not only understand why it has occurred; we must recognise its damaging consequences. Recently a survey was done on unemployment, and that survey showed that, whilst the official statistics for unemployment are dramatically high, there is a great deal of hidden unemployment. In other words, there are people who seek to be employed in the paid work force but who have no show of getting into the paid work force now or in the foreseeable future. Many of those persons, of course, have family responsibilities and are from families with only one income. The type of family policy being pursued condemns those people to a very sub-standard standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government might say that it has developed the policy of the family income supplement. Let me say to the Government that the policies it has been pursuing have resulted in the dignity of both male and female workers with family responsibilities being affronted and more and more families being forced into the poverty trap of having to rely on the family income supplement welfare scheme, with no incentive to get out of it. I should like to incorporate in Hansard three tables which have been prepared for me by the Parliamentary Library. The first one is entitled `Effective Marginal Tax Rate on 6 Hours of Regularly Worked Overtime for Person with Dependent Spouse and 4 Children on Average Minimum Award Wage'. This worker's overtime earnings are $69.32, of which $55.02 is taken by an effective marginal tax rate of 80%. That is an absolutely devastating figure. I do not have time to go through the other two, but they are entitled `Tax Payable and Disposable Income, Family with Four Children' and `Disposable Income and Tax Payable', comparing the family with four children and the couple with no children. I seek leave to have those three groups of statistics incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The result is now clear to all, particularly to workers with family responsibilities. Had the discrimination they are now suffering been at the hands of employers, the trade union movement would not have tolerated it. Had it been at the hands of industrial tribunals, the trade union movement would not have tolerated it. Why should workers tolerate this discrimination because it is at the hand of government? The time has come to establish an industrially and politically supported social wage system which recognises the family as the basic unit of society. This system would require specific government commitments before the trade union movement agree to enter into any future accord or agreed wages policy. Government commitments should include action to lessen the unfair cost and tax burdens on workers with family responsibilities, to restore the true value of family allowances, which are now worth less than two-thirds of their 1976 value, to resist the accord-breaking threats to the spouse rebate, and to give a fair go to all families. I believe that such action would receive the support of all workers genuinely committed to trade union principles of social justice and equity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition wishes to support this matter of public importance. We have no doubt that there has been a substantial loss in net disposable income suffered by Australian families, as set out in the terms of the matter of public importance, and we have no doubt that this is a genuine matter of public importance for all Australians. Family units are an easy mark for government neglect. Families make up those parts of society which are relatively static, which are concerned with keeping jobs, and which are concerned with and often contribute to the better functioning of community structures such as child care, education, charities, nursing homes and voluntary agencies. Often families are heavily involved in making them work. Families are the people who pay their taxes. They tend to be busy people involved in mutual care and too involved in those things to be the kinds of people who take to the streets in vocal protests, as we see so often on our television screens. In that conservative sense of a group in society which tends to maintain and protect the values of that society, our families are not only important but critical to the transmission of the culture and to the care and nurture of our young. More importantly, family units provide irreplaceable services and support for their own members.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make it quite clear that I enter this debate from a very special position. I am a member of such a family. I am from a one-income family and have been married for 28 years. We are part of a very large extended family whose members depend upon each other for mutual support. We have aged parents looking to us for care and we have adult children living at home much of the time. That is the kind of background we come from. We know, and everyone knows, that family life is not all sweetness and light. Not all families are perfect. Family members are human. They can be mutually unkind as well as kind and they can be mutually cruel, but on balance, across the population, family units provide the emotional, physical and financial security which no other social agency can match. We will yield to no one in the concern we feel for the structures of our family, diverse and varied though they may be. We believe that family membership enhances individual happiness and achievement and provides services to the members that cannot be matched in quality by anything government can do, except in those cases where we are dealing with family pathology, when special government help may be needed.

Where families fail governments have to expend huge sums of money trying to match or at least provide a pale reflection of the services that families normally provide. My daughter worked recently in a youth and community services government receiving home for children of families in crisis. Not only were the tales horrific but she was very distressed by some of the people with whom she interacted and whom she had to help. This was a pale reflection of the kind of environment which families operating properly can provide. Where that happens we find we are in a vicious circle where over-taxed families fail and where, having failed, they force up the welfare bill and provide extra responsibilities for government.

We have no doubt that the current Government's policies and actions in the years it has been in office have contributed markedly to the pressures under which Australian families suffer. We have no doubt that since the election of the first Hawke Government Australian families have progressively become worse off. Australian families have had less disposable income-certainly less disposable income in real terms. They have had less buying power. I think Senator Harradine, certainly from the terms of this motion, would acknowledge that the economic pressures on our families are among the most difficult to resist. We find Australian children have been suffering. We find that the disastrous record of the Hawke Government in the areas of wages, taxation-particularly the fringe benefits tax-family allowances, the cost of providing housing and shelter and health costs has affected families adversely. The Hawke Government has been so busy patching up problems, putting out bushfires, that it has forgotten the importance of maintaining and strengthening families. With the job that they do and the irreplaceable function that they perform, families are needed for our society to be sustained. By weakening families the Government creates more problems, more hurt and more disadvantage.

Let me just turn to a few of the areas. Looking at the areas of wages and taxation we see that the real wages of Australian workers have declined not only because of wage discounting but also because their purchasing power has gone down. The discounting has been brought about partly by the fall in value of the Australian dollar, which is another gift of the Hawke Government. That fall was caused by that Government's economic policies. Worse still, we see the decline in the after-tax income, the real take home pay, the money that people use to pay for their needs day by day. Both the average and the marginal rates of tax have increased greatly under Labor and if we look at the total tax take-the numbers of billions of dollars taken from Australian families, from pay as you earn taxpayers-we find that this has increased enormously since the election of the Hawke Government both in dollar terms and in real terms. That money has been taken from families. It is the families that have less money themselves, particularly families on average weekly earnings which are particularly hard hit. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. The average tax rate has increased from 17.5 per cent to over 21 per cent and the average marginal tax rate has risen from 30 per cent to 46 per cent. Even after the tax cuts in December, themselves deferred three months from what was promised, and the July tax cuts, if they ever eventuate, the rates which people pay will still be higher than when Labor came to office-and the people who are paying those extra tax rates are the families of Australia. We estimate that each family is $15 per week worse off because of Labor's tax increases. I believe that Senator Harradine offered some figures-I do not know whether they are the same-but in terms of order of magnitude he and I are talking about exactly the same thing. There has been no indexation of the dependent spouse rebate, so families with a parent looking after young children full time have been even more adversely affected. Looking at family allowances, we see that the Labor Government has taken no steps to increase the levels of family allowances, and their value has declined by about 20 per cent since the Labor Government came to office. This could be a loss of about $130 a year to an Australian family with two dependent children. In addition, of course, we know that from 1 January 1987 the family allowance for children over 16 will be means tested, and this could cost families even more.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at housing, we discover that we have the highest real housing loan interest rates we have ever had. At the moment people are paying 15 1/2 per cent to try to service their loans so that they can buy a house to shelter the family that they love. The monthly mortgage repayments for a family with a typical 25-year $50,000 home loan have risen by a staggering $152. They have risen from $508 when Mr Hawke was elected to $660 today. That money has to be found by families. I have had Commonwealth car drivers, as we talked in the car going home, saying: `Senator, if there is any further increase in those interest rates I don't know whether I will be able to keep my home. I am working as much overtime as I can, but I do not know whether I will be able to pay the mortgage and keep my home'. People should not have to say those kinds of things. It is the families that are being affected. If we look to private rental accommodation as the alternative we must realise that one is lucky to find any rental accommodation. It is very scarce now in most of the major cities of Australia and we find that the rents that families have had to pay have raced ahead even of inflation, even though wage rises have been somewhat discounted.

Looking at the area of health and families, we find that under Medicare costs are up by 40 per cent, so the Medicare levy now has to rise. It will rise by 25 per cent on 1 December. Who will pay the increased levy? It will be Australian families once again. Overall, looking at all of this-wage discounting, tax increases, the real cuts in family allowances, increased housing costs and rising health costs-all of these things have made the average family with two children something like $27 per week worse off.
