TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. This means that food, clothes, books, luxuries, sporting gear-anything one would like to name; all the things required by children and by families-cost much more today than they did when Mr Hawke came into government and it costs parents much more just to feed, clothe and house themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The Howard alternatives are quite clear and they will benefit families. We will adopt a much more flexible wages policy. I notice that that is part of the motion-that we must look to new approaches to wages. We will want to see employers and employees doing around Australia what was done so successfully at Mudginberri and at the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd. At Mudginberri a group of workers left to make their own arrangements and ended up better off in net terms. We want all Australians to be able to do that, and if we do it for all Australian workers we are doing it for Australian families.

We have promised and we have had on the table income splitting for families as one option, to allow families to lessen the tax burden and increase family spending power. We want to freeze and to cut government expenditure overall so that we reduce the tax burden on those very same families-reduce the tax burden, reduce the inflation rate, reduce the nation's debt and increase the economic power of the families. We will abolish the fringe benefits tax, which of itself has affected and harmed Australian families. We will reduce interest rates with better economic management. We will do it by cutting government spending and so by cutting government borrowing. We will reduce or steady rents simply by abolishing the capital gains tax and by reviewing that ridiculous decision on negative gearing whose only effect has been to dry up the supply of rental accommodation in cities like my city of Sydney. We will reduce health costs. We have set out our health policies. We will assist self-provision for aged Australians by abolishing the assets test and the tax on lump sum superannuation benefits.

We will not be party to the kind of things to which this Government has been party. This is the Government which, having identified poverty traps which are harming Australian families, particularly some single income, one-parent families, and having put in place legislation to relieve them, has decided not to allow that legislation to come into effect for an extra eight months. Perhaps this Government thinks that it will be good for the families who have been affected to have another eight months unable to take steps to relieve themselves of the effects of those poverty traps. There are four million families in Australia and 2,250,000 families with children. The available statistics show that the presence of children is currently the first indicator of whether there is poverty in a family. Senator Harradine drew attention to this matter when he talked about families with children who are bearing the brunt of what is going on in this country. We know that if one looks at families in the poorest quarter of income, one finds that families with children are over-represented. Sole parent families, often the result of the breakdown of marriage, are particularly disadvantaged and over-represented. Most sole parent families fall into this poorest quarter. Of sole parent families with two children, more than three quarters will be in the poorest quarter of incomes, and their situation has worsened since the Labor Government came to office.

As a nation we do too little to help our families. We permit that sector of our society, our families, to suffer and to endure increasing financial squeeze and hardship. We tolerate children in families being brought up in poverty and in need, often with disastrous long term effects in terms of their adult potential and their personality. What our parties are on about is creating the economic circumstances and the hope for families to succeed. The Liberal-National Party message is one of hope for families, one of success, and that is not consistent with the record of the Hawke Government, under which families have been progressively worse off. In the short term we understand just how severe financial stresses are on families, just how much financial worries are contributing towards the breakdown of marriage, and how financial difficulties are contributing to sending mothers and children into even greater financial and emotional distress. The programs that we have to offer for Australia will improve the economic situation of families, and in so doing will make them and the nation stronger. We believe that Senator Harradine is quite correct to bring before the Senate today a matter of public importance which emphasises the substantial loss in the net disposable income suffered by Australian families. We wish to be associated with the matter of public importance, which is well timed and very important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating this afternoon a matter of public importance which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The substantial loss in net disposable income suffered by male and female wage and salary earners with family responsibilities by comparison to other wage and salary earners at all levels under Federal and State awards and the need for the Government to redress this situation as a necessary adjunct to a more realistic and just wages policy and to give a fair go for all families.

There is little to disagree with in that statement. In fact it is the basis of a thorough review of our current social security system which can only go hand in hand with a review of taxation measures-a review which will have a great effect on the disposable income of families. Since 1969 the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has rejected the notion that wage determinations should take into account family responsibilities. I do not think anybody is suggesting that we should go back to the old days of the basic wage-a wage which, theoretically but never practically, was designed to provide for the ordinary needs of a worker his spouse and two or three dependent children. The emphasis on those wage cases from 1969 onwards, and again in 1974 and 1977, was that responsibility for the welfare of families lay with governments through the systems of redistribution traditionally accepted in Australia. I refer to tax transfers, the dependent spouse rebate and child endowment which were in place at that stage. In 1977 the tax relief and the child endowment system, as it had existed for 30 years, was replaced by the Fraser Government by a system of family allowances. In theory, I believe that this was a measure on which there could be very little disagreement. The great problems have developed since then because the family allowance which came into being in 1977 has not kept up with inflation. Its having not been indexed, the real value has declined. Currently, family allowances would need to be increased by some 40 per cent to restore them to the value they held when first introduced in 1977.

Returning to tax relief, turning back the clock on the issue of the basic wage would not be an equitable method of redistribution. It is clear that tax relief as generally understood usually favours those on higher incomes. Attempts made in discussion of this matter of public importance to differentiate between particular households also run the risk of overlooking the needs of many groupings. When we talk about male and female wage and salary earners with family responsibilities by comparison to other wage and salary earners, we must acknowledge the fact that there is an enormously wide range of households in which there are dependent children. Whatever direct income tax measures are taken, little change will be brought about in households on very low incomes. The method that has been developed over the last few years involving a family income supplement for those on very low incomes and wages is included in our social security review, and ways of making that more horizontally and vertically equitable are being seriously discussed. Among wage and salary earners there are very many, both men and women who work part time-men part time workers being more common than they were previously. We are seeing some very interesting changes in the labour force-for example, in the participation rates of sole parents. Possibly the most unexpected change here has been that male sole parents have reduced their participation rate in the work force quite sharply from 94.7 per cent to 79 per cent. The rate for female sole parents has also declined, from 45 per cent to 40.8 per cent. That is a phenomenon to which Senator Harradine and Senator Peter Baume also referred, although somewhat more obliquely, but which is acknowledged to be a result of the disincentives that have been built into our social security and taxation systems over the years, culminating in the poverty traps, the solution to which has, regrettably, been postponed until next July.

Other groups whose income is dependent on awards of the Federal and State arbitration commissions are those who for some reason are temporarily out of the work force or who are seasonally employed. Those who are temporarily out of the work force on sick leave, maternity leave, compensation, or matters of that kind are also dependent in one way or another, either on the provisions of their awards or on whatever social security provisions can be made for them. Those with the care of young children also come into a wide range of family configurations-some intact families with one or two earners and those who are at least partly dependent upon a non-custodial parent who may or may not fulfil this responsibility. The point cannot be made too strongly that pretty well every household in relation to its earning capacity or income is rarely static. Changes occur over the years, perhaps as the mother leaves the work force for a time and then re-enters it for part time work, which is very common as her children begin to earn, or perhaps as the principal earner returns to part time employment or as either of the earners-assuming there are more than one-leave the work force for a time. Their dependency upon taxation measures will vary quite significantly, as will their dependency on social security measures.

I do not agree that the majority of families are necessarily worse off as a result of measures that have been taken by this Government over the last few years. References have already been made to the very important significance of education measures and of the introduction of the universal health scheme. These have meant significant changes to many families and their standard of living-improving it in the case of many low income families. The measures we are continuing to take on housing for low income families and the provision of public housing, although nowhere near adequate-we are certainly not resting on our laurels-are obviously of enormous importance when one is trying to assess whether a particular group in the community is better or worse off.

Another matter of great importance is the provision of children's services which, coupled with the second education opportunities, can have a great deal of effect on whether a woman, particularly, who has the care of children is able to develop her own independence, move outside a purely household existence and provide for her and her children's needs. The increasing participation rate, not just of single parents but of all women in the Australian work force, means that more women have incomes and are in a position to pay income tax, which was not the case before. I am not necessarily insisting that it is a great leap forward to be able to pay income tax, but being in the position of having an independent income has enhanced enormously the standard of living of many women in Australia over the past 10 or 15 years.

I am a little puzzled by Senator Harradine's reference to this Government's aim of having 85 per cent of married women in the work force. If that statement was made, I believe that it was undoubtedly made in the context of making it possible for women, married or otherwise, with dependent children or otherwise, to develop their independence. The surest way out of poverty in Australia or any other industrialised country is certainly by moving into the work force. Although that is not necessarily seen as a socially constructive alternative-in Senator Harradine's words-it is certainly a way by which many families have attained a standard of living which otherwise would not have been possible. It is certainly not an affront to dignity for a family or household to be provided with a decent standard of living, even if for a period this money comes from the public purse.

I find it very encouraging that the question of income support for families and children, which is the basis of the first issues paper from the Social Security Review, is getting so much attention. It is a report which certainly deserves that attention. It would have been relatively easy for this Government, as was the case with other governments, simply to tinker around with the social security system in a way which gave no recognition at all to the enormous range of variables which affect individual families-and not only in relation to taxation or whether they are entitled to spouse rebates or family allowances. A very rough and simplistic approach to these matters is taken by Mr Andrew Hay, the President of the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce, but that approach is very far from the thoughts of all of us. I do not believe that anyone at all in this Parliament believes, as Mr Hay does, that family allowances should be abolished. He describes family allowances as `a farce'. We know perfectly well that even in middle income families, whom he describes as `leeching off the Government', in many cases the family allowance is the only disposable income available to the mother who usually has the care of the children.

We are very well aware of the fact that over the years, and very much as a result of many years of conservative government, the position of Australia in the world league, as it were, of provision of family allowances and other supports for families with dependent children has dropped alarmingly. Of all the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, Australia is now in tenth position. With an OECD average of 9 per cent of universal family assistance for a two-child family as a proportion of a net average production worker's wage, Australia's contribution is 4.4 per cent. When we look at another measure-the value of tax relief in cash transfers-Australia's position is even worse. With an average of 11.4 per cent of the average production worker's wage for the OECD as a whole, Australia's contribution is only 5.7 per cent and we are listed fifteenth out of 18 countries. Over the next few months as these discussion papers and issues papers become more widely available, these matters will be dealt with thoroughly and effectively. We hope that within the next few years to make a much more effective contribution to the support of families with children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance today calls for a fair go for all families. Of course, that is a call with which none of use would disagree; but to begin with, we need to be clear about what we are referring to when we speak about families. There is a range of possible definitions. I find some useful comment on this issue from the social justice statement of the Anglican Church of Australia, which points out that perhaps one general definition is that of one or two adults living with one or more dependent children; or an even simpler definition being `where kids live'. That statement recognises that there are now many variations of families in Australia and that in policy making and in our actions we need to approach family life as it is actually experienced-not a mythical approach to some sort of family that may have existed in the past or might exist in our imagination.

SPEECH.PARA: The Anglican Church statement goes on to point out that there are external pressures on families-pressures of unemployment, poor nutrition, homelessness, emotional and physical violence, work demands and poverty; that within families there are internal pressures of violence, incest, child abuse and immature relationships; that the family is placed in the context of its immediate neighbourhood and that whether the community gives support to or ignores vulnerable families also puts stress upon families.

The report points out that families are the most economic way for people to live because resources are shared on a voluntary basis. It suggests that governments should recognise this and support it. Of course, enormous changes are going on in family structures these days. It is a fact that in general Australian households tend to be getting smaller. While some 60 per cent of Australians still live in nuclear two-parent families, some of which are of a blended nature as a result of remarriages, the proportion of one-parent families has doubled to 13 per cent of all families. Because of contraception and later marriage, 25 per cent of households in 1982 had no children. Birth rates generally are continuing to decline. There are many split households as the divorce rate has increased. There are many children living in de facto family relationships. Many other changes have to be dealt with by families.

There is evidence of the loss of net disposable income by families, as the matter of public importance indicates. One figure demonstrates that-a figure which was tabled in the Senate last year and which showed that the amount of income tax imposed over the last 10 years on a family with four children living on average weekly earnings has increased by 435 per cent while wages have increased by only 135 per cent. The tax system has changed to the point that individuals are favoured over families. A part of this decline has been caused by the fact that social security allowances have not been indexed.

Perhaps the major problem facing families in Australia today is poverty. As Professor Cass, who heads the Government's Social Security Review, has stated, the highest incidence of poverty is now among sole parent families headed by women and low income families with four or more children. Poverty is associated with being unemployed or outside the work force. As we have seen so often recently, the incidence of poverty is increasing and is deepening in our community at the moment. That poverty markedly affects families, as Professor Cass has stated. In the last four or five years, families, particularly single-parent families, have slipped further and further below the poverty line-2 to 4 per cent of single parents with up to three children. These are some of the problems faced by families in our society and ones to which we really need to pay the deepest attention. They are problems that affect two million Australians, three-quarters of a million of whom are children. As the matter of public importance states, in this case it is the very low level of disposable income that is the problem-in fact a level of income below the poverty line.

One of the most effective ways of improving this situation, of getting people out of poverty, would be to ensure that more family bread- winners, whether in single parent families or not, are able to secure employment. The level of unemployment among sole parent families, the majority of which are headed by women, is extraordinarily high. Eighty-three per cent are within the social security system. Given that fact, it is significant that we should recognise the obstacles facing women attempting to get employment, particularly women who have the responsibility for families and who have to exercise that responsibility while living below the poverty line. The first difficulty is that which faces everybody seeking employment, that is, the general high level of unemployment still being at 8.4 per cent and there having been a rise in the September quarter. In that context there is strong competition for the available jobs. It is women in our society who still lack qualifications and experience. Even though we are fast approaching the end of the twentieth century and even though we have made advances, women and girls are still not achieving the same level of educational qualifications or the same level of experience and expertise as men. As a result, women are still under represented in high income and high status occupations and professions, and over represented in lower paid and lower status occupations.

A recent Government policy which will affect families and which apparently will be endorsed by the Opposition-as so many recent Government policies which have hurt families, in particular single-parent female-headed families, have been-is the introduction of the $250 tertiary education fee. Since the abolition of tertiary fees, women have increasingly used, become involved in and been advantaged by increased participation in further education. There is no question that one of the first groups to be disadvantaged by the imposition of the $250 fee will be women. In addition, for all people who are in this situation of poverty, there is the disincentive of the high effective tax rates. The Social Security Review Background Discussion Paper No. 4 has made considerable comment on this, pointing out that for some people it represents an effective marginal tax rate of 100 per cent, but in very many cases it is up to 75 or 80 per cent. That is despite the fact that Government policy, once again supported by the Opposition, has quite recently brought in lower marginal tax rates for those in employment, those living very far from the poverty line.

That disincentive exists. Not only have we lowered the marginal tax rates for those in employment; we have also ensured that the disincentive remains, that the poverty traps legislation is deferred, and that these people will suffer considerable disadvantage as a result. In fact, for a two-parent family, a couple with two children, living on social security and renting, the loss is $31 a week because of the deferral of the poverty traps measures. There are many other figures to match that. The Institute of Family Studies and a number of other authorities have noted that these poverty traps needed to go. They have not gone. That is a matter for shame for those who are responsible. I note that the Australian Democrats were the only people to oppose that measure.

The lack of child care is a significant disincentive for women attempting to get into employment and out of poverty. The provision of child care is not adequate. The cost of child care is beyond most people trying to get into, normally, rather low paid employment, and for those who can achieve higher paid employment there is the fact that, although many other business expenses might be tax deductible, child care certainly is not.

It also bears mentioning that very often the structure of work, the work place, the hours and so forth, is very much directed towards the masculine roles in society. A good example of that is the new Parliament House, which was designed to be without child care facilities. This goes right through the whole work place. There is no question but that some fundamental changes would remove some of the disincentives for women and also would provide more opportunity for men, too, to spend more time with their families.

My contribution would not be complete without some comment on the contributions of Opposition and Government spokespeople thus far. It is significant that Senator Peter Baume suggested that the fringe benefits tax was an imposition and had disadvantaged families. It certainly has done that-for those families who were accustomed to an annual overseas trip and those families whose children were attending private schools courtesy of a tax-free concession. I do not see how it could possibly be argued any other way. Senator Baume suggested that we need more Mudginberris. If we are really concerned about families, the last thing we will want is confrontation in our industrial relations system. If that is the best that the Opposition can do, let us hope that that is where its members stay.

The old sore of income splitting is raised again. We have not seen from the Opposition any firm policy here. We do not know whether it has been costed. But the danger there is that such a system would reduce the Government's income to a level at which benefits, which are already too low, would not be able to be paid.

Senator Giles referred to her regret that the poverty traps legislation had been postponed. It is to her credit that she regrets it, but that certainly will not get that $31 a week back to that two-parent family on social security payments and renting their home.

There is no question but that there is potential in the social security review for a major improvement in the way in which we handle the sorts of problems for families about which I have spoken, but it seems to the Australian Democrats that those things for which we have often called are now even more imperative: In particular, that in order for people to get out of poverty, for family breadwinners to be able to seek work in the first place, to take work and still to carry on their responsibilities, there must be a significant increase in the free income levels available to social security recipients; that child allowances and rent allowances should be increased; and that the Government must look again at its priorities and must not penalise those least able to pay. The Government must seek its income from other sources. The Brierleys and the Elliotts of this world, whose companies are paying 10 per cent or less in taxation, should not be able to hold their heads up in a world in which people living below the poverty level can have to pay 75 per cent tax rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating, as a matter of public importance proposed by Senator Harradine of Tasmania, the following matter:

SPEECH.PARA: The substantial loss in net disposable income suffered by male and female wage and salary earners with family responsibilities by comparison to other wage and salary earners at all levels under Federal and State awards and the need for the Government to redress this situation as a necessary adjunct to a more realistic and just wages policy and to give a fair go for all families.

We have just heard Senator Giles and Senator Powell talking about the poverty situation and not really applying their minds to this matter of public importance. However, I welcome the presence in the chamber of Senator Graham Richardson, back from Coventry, or Singleton, or wherever it was. It is marvellous to see him back here, because he is an Australian Labor Party senator who understands the difficulties which bank clerks and others are suffering under this Government. It is marvellous to see him back at last. He is tending to hide from some of his colleagues, but we welcome his return. We welcome the things that he said at Singleton, where he pointed out the truth of the matters which the Opposition parties and, in particular, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) have been saying for so long: That this Government is attacking the poor people of the nation, not the wealthy people.

In relation to the subject of this debate, the Australian Labor Party has always had an unwritten philosophy. It does not express it publicly or put it in its written documents, but the truth is that most members of the Labor Party have a sort of unwritten philosophy of destroying the family unit. There are honourable exceptions, but overall one sees them constantly on the attack in relation to the family unit. Take, for example, the most recent appointment to the Office of the Status of Women, which advises the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to women's affairs. The Prime Minister has appointed one Ms Suzanne Brooks. She has spoken favourably of Sweden's 85 per cent participation rate in the work force by married women. She is aiming to get a participation rate of about 85 per cent. She says that the key to all that is to make it possible for women to have children and to keep on working, if they choose, while they are having children.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pretty difficult task.

—Senator Harradine and I agree that it is a difficult task, although some countries seem not to have worried too much about it. There was a time in China and a time in Europe immediately following the Second World War when people did not seem to bother about it. If this Government wants to bring us down to the standards that obtained in Europe shortly after the Second World War, why does it not make that public so that we know what it is on about?

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Brooks has advocated the abolition of the spouse rebate. At the same time, of course, she is not interested in that rebate because she and her husband, together, would be on an annual income of about $100,000. Let me tell the Senate what was written about Ms Brooks in the Australian Women's Weekly in May this year. This is what was reported:
Sue and her husband Ray, a lecturer in economics and industrial law at the Phillip Institute of Technology in Coburg, are childless.
`We made a conscious decision not to have children. We're both busy people and at that stage child care was even harder to come by', she says.
Instead, she and Ray have a `99-year lease' on two Siamese cats.
Ray will cat sit while Sue is in Canberra. She plans to rent an apartment there and fly home every few weeks.
`The separation doesn't bother us,' she says. `We've always lived fairly independent lives, and Ray recognises the job is important.'

That is the person the Prime Minister has chosen to advise him in relation to women's affairs. That is the problem with the Australian Labor Party. This is just the sort of philosophy that the ALP has running right through it in relation to the family and the family unit. Yet, now it is in government it can see the difficulties. It is beginning to appreciate that the family unit is absolutely vital to the future of the nation, that the family unit provides the best form of family care and that no government agency or government employee can ever step in and replace the sort of family care which used to exist before the introduction of the incredible so-called Family Law Act which brought such disharmony to this country and which has resulted in multiple marriages with children of his and her's and theirs and other combinations.

Let me get back to the subject under debate. Under this Government the average family man with a spouse and two dependent children is paying almost $30 a week more in income tax than he was paying when this Government came into office. The so-called tax cuts now scheduled for December this year and July next year will do little to remedy that situation. Even after those tax cuts are introduced completely by July of next year the average wage earner will still be on a marginal tax rate of 40c in the dollar. Glory be! What on earth has happened to this country? How much money does this Government want to take from the taxpayers of this nation? Until December of this year they will be paying 46c in the dollar, and there was a time under this Government when they were paying a marginal tax rate of 47c in the dollar. When the Hawke Government came into office in March of 1983 the average wage earner and family man was on a marginal tax rate of only 30c in the dollar, and we were concerned about that. Members of the Fraser Government's back bench were saying that the marginal rate of 30c in the dollar was too high, and the Government at that time was looking to see what it could do to lower it. Under the Hawke Government the marginal rate rose to 47c in the dollar, has been reduced to 46c in the dollar and after the tax cuts will be 40c in the dollar. Of course that is not unusual with Labor governments, Mr Acting Deputy President. You will recall that under the prime ministership of Mr Whitlam the marginal rate rose to 44c in the dollar. It was the Fraser Government which managed to drag it back to 30c in the dollar.

It is an enormous disincentive to people in Australia to go out and work harder to earn more money when they have to pay 40c in the dollar tax on every extra dollar they manage to earn. The average family man on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and dependent children currently pays an average tax rate of 20.5 per cent. So he has a marginal rate which will ultimately be 40c in the dollar but his average rate is 20.5 per cent, compared with 17.5 per cent when the Fraser Government left office. It is quite clear that all the Government is doing with these so-called tax cuts is giving back some of the extra tax it has taken from taxpayers since it came into power. In fact, it has been calculated that an additional $15 a week in income tax cuts on top of the Keating tax cuts would be required to reduce the income tax burden of a single income family on average earnings to the same level that applied when this Government came into office in March 1983. For a single income family on average earnings the tax cuts will be $15 light. In addition, the Hawke Government has dramatically increased fuel excise, it has increased the Medicare levy and it has increased and introduced a new range of wholesale taxes. It has abolished the concessional expenditure rebate which was of assistance to many large families and was some partial recognition of the increased costs suffered by those families.

Let me draw attention to some figures calculated by my colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Alasdair Webster. He has calculated that an ordinary single income family on $39,000 a year with three teenage children has only about $100 a week of what he has called `free' income. In other words, after allowing for tax and the estimated cost of housing and feeding a family, out of a quite substantial salary such a family would be left with only $100 a week to spend on food and clothing for the two adults and other things. He has also drawn attention to the fact that a single mother on the supporting parent's benefit with one young child may have as much as $172 as week so-called `free' income-in other words, $70 a week more than the so-called well-off family. The figures are clearly set out by Mr Webster.

The Institute of Family Studies carried out a household survey into the cost of feeding and clothing children in a family with an income of less than $180 a week. It found that it cost $19.73 a week for a two-year old child, $25.31 for a five-year old, $31.03 for an eight-year old and $49.04 for a teenager. It also surveyed the costs for a family with an income of $425 a week, and the costs for such a family were substantially higher. The Institute points out that the family allowance of about $5.20 a week for the first child is grossly inadequate compensation for the family. Families in this country are being totally overlooked by this Government. Mortgage interest rates are now at an incredibly high level. People are paying an interest rate of 15 1/2 per cent on their mortgages, and anyone trying to buy a house at present is being sucked into paying other massively high interest rates because this Government is keeping up interest rates in order to bring in deposits from overseas investors to paper over the crack in the monthly export-import deficit. Health care costs under Medicare are exploding out of all proportion. The inflation rate is still being maintained at an extraordinarily high figure in relation to the rates of our overseas trading partners, and it is the relationship between our inflation rate and that of our overseas trading partners which makes life so difficult for many people. The Opposition certainly supports this matter of public importance raised by Senator Harradine and congratulates him on bringing it forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Harradine goes to the question of how we can maintain at a decent standard of living the families of this nation. The point has been made again and again-it is a point that certainly nobody here would disagree with and with which very few people in the community would disagree-that the family is the fundamental unit of society. That statement has often been made, and it is clearly recognised by all. There has been a tendency in the debate to distinguish between the family and others, as if we have not all been at one stage or another part of a family. The fact of the matter is that we are all born and, hopefully, we have a family context in which to grow up. That family may split-unfortunately there is too much of that these days, caused by, amongst other things, economic problems-nevertheless, the concept of the family being the basic unit is certainly one that is accepted by and large by the whole community. The real question is how government, how any institution, can best provide for that family in the society in which we are presently living.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine, in his matter of public importance debate today, raised the question of both Federal and State award wages. I think he properly highlighted the part that the union movement can play and should play in this matter. He indicated, as he has before in the Senate, the great importance of the part that the unions play in the proper running of this country and the proper protection of the family. Senator Harradine, in speaking on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill earlier this year, pointed out that under one interpretation of the Bill of Rights as it relates to unions the fundamental rights of unions to operate in this country, and indeed elsewhere, may in some way be prejudiced. He indicated then the danger that that would bring to Australian society as a whole.

The Opposition, of course, has also worked out, has divined, that the family is important, as has just been said by Senator Lewis and as was said earlier by Senator Peter Baume. But the protection that is afforded the family by the unions in their proper operations is condemned by the Opposition. It is difficult to accept that members of the Opposition get up in this chamber and say `The family ought to be protected economically. It should be given proper conditions to work in. Enough money shall be brought home', yet that very institution, the union movement, which is there to allow appropriate amounts of money to be brought into the home so that the family can be properly looked after, is the object of attack by the Opposition. It has declared that, when it comes to office, it will bring in very stringent industrial legislation to ensure that the activities of that institution that looks after the family's income, or helps to do so, will be curtailed. The Opposition wishes to do that for the very simple reason that it believes that wages that are presently paid are too high and must be reduced, that the social wage which includes such things as Medicare benefits that are paid to families must be reduced, and that generally institutions such as the union movement and programs such as Medicare which give protection to the family should be abolished.

So it is very interesting that members of the Opposition come into this chamber and proclaim, as they have, that they are interested in the family and that they want to do something about the family-I am sure that that is absolutely correct and that they want to do something about the family-but that they then propose a course of conduct which would lead to families being left defenceless and unprotected, unable to negotiate a decent wage, having lost the protection they had by way of the commonality that is provided by the union movement.

The second thing I want to say is that the Opposition, in attempting to help the family, as it says it wants to, would abolish the fringe benefits tax, would abolish the capital gains tax imposed upon property and would generally disrupt the taxation package that this Government has brought forward, quite properly, to ensure that the revenue gathered by these measures is redistributed to those who need it. No matter how people in this chamber go through the figures, the fact of the matter is that when this Government came to power the lowest rate at which people were taxed was 30c in the dollar. By the time next year has come and gone that rate will be reduced to 24c. Indeed, that 24c level will be reached by 1 December this year. When this Government came to office the highest level was 60c and that will now be reduced to 49c in the dollar. No matter how the figures are worked out, that is a fact which stands before the country and before this Senate to indicate that there is and will be a continuing lowering of the tax rate.

I accept that members of the Opposition have said that they are interested in the family, but there is no indication of how they would arrange things so that the impact on the family wage-the impact on all wages for that matter-would be lessened in the way described in the matter of public importance. Members of the Opposition say that they would abolish the capital gains tax, which is a tax to ensure that those people who used to be able to avoid paying taxes by buying large farms and large businesses and converting their income into a capital asset that did not attract tax, pay their proper tax so that the people who earn income and are not able to convert it into capital do not have to pay as much. It is a little strange to hear members of the Opposition getting up in this chamber and proclaiming, as they do, that they are interested in the family and that they are going to make sure that the finances that are available to the family stay with the family and do not disappear in tax, when they oppose, for example, this Government's attempts to redistribute tax in a fairer way.

Members of the Opposition say that they will relieve the taxes on companies. The Sydney Morning Herald of Wednesday, 29 October 1986, indicates the sort of tax that some companies are paying. The Opposition has said that, in the interests of helping the family, it will see to it that the taxes of these companies are reduced. The article in the Sydney Morning Herald states:
Those most successful at minimising their tax bill-
what are being spoken about here are companies-
include some of Australia's best-known companies:
Ron Brierley's Industrial Equity Ltd paid 4.66 per cent in tax and his Southern Farmers group paid 5.06 per cent;
John Elliott's Elders-IXL paid 10.35 per cent;
John Spalvins' David Jones paid 10.75 per cent;
Queensland Press paid 7.13 per cent;
Alan Bond's Bond Corp paid 13.95 per cent;
George Herscu's Hooker Corporation paid 16.8 per cent . . .

And so the article goes on. Yet this is part of the program that the Opposition will put into operation if it comes to government. It is part of its proposition that the tax on these companies be reduced. If the taxes are reduced further, who will pay them? Certainly it will be the man who gets out and works for these companies-the average working man. If the general tax propositions put by the Opposition are adopted the family will be in a disastrous state because of the imposition of taxes upon them to replace what this Government presently gets from companies, from large scale capital gains and from the fringe benefits tax. The fringe benefits tax, after all, is a tax that goes to a question of equity because it states that not only income which most families receive as a way of supporting themselves should be taxed but also those company cars that people get, those free loans and those school fees that are paid should be taxed.

If we look at what this Government has done since coming to office in respect of the family, which has helped the family, the sorts of statements that are being made about the Government tend to pale. I can give some examples. The Government has introduced a number of policies which considerably help families. First of all, there is the first home owners assistance scheme, which provides grants of up to $6,000 to persons who buy their own homes. Secondly, there is the Medicare system, which Senator Lewis attacked but which provides cover for every family in Australia at a rate decided according to the level of income and not at a rate as was formerly the situation, dictated by some private company which simply says: `This is the rate we are going to fix'. Medicare is a system which allows people to obtain medical care at a rate they can afford.

Thirdly, there is a 70 per cent increase in the family income supplement, additional benefit for children, and a 100 per cent increase in the mother-guardian allowance. Fourthly, there has been a substantial increase in the benefits and allowances paid to unemployed young people and those undertaking training courses and full time study. There is the Priority One scheme, the scheme to have young people educated, and the scheme to see that they obtain work experience. In other words, this Government has set up a series of schemes to help people get into the work force and hopefully to earn more and more as the economy recovers.

On the other hand, these sorts of schemes are condemned by the Opposition. Presumably it would abolish them if it ever were to come to power, but it has not at any stage suggested what it would do as an alternative. It is very surprising-although, if one thinks about it, perhaps not so surprising-to have members of the Opposition make declarations of regard for the family and all sorts of statements which could be best described as pious, yet not produce any alternative to the schemes which are presently operating under this Government. They are operating certainly in a difficult financial climate; nobody denies that. The financial climate has been brought upon the country by policies of the past, going well back into the 1960s. Certainly there have been reductions in the standard of living because wages have been reduced. They have been reduced in an equitable way in accordance with a scheme that has been worked out with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Nevertheless, this country is going forward with social cohesion.

Compare that with the situation that would exist if the Opposition came to power. In that case war would be declared upon those representatives of the workers who protect their wages-a war which would lead to social dislocation and which in the end would disrupt the family by affecting the amount of money that comes in, by causing strife and by generally bringing upon us quite severe social dislocation.

Of course the family must be looked after. Of course it is the centre of this community. Of course it must be given proper economic protection. This Government is doing that, in conjunction not only with the unions but also with the whole community and the commercial and business world. Agreements are being reached in the interests of obtaining a fair go, not only economically but also socially, for all Australians. All Australians have at one time or other been in families. Most Australians, fortunately, are in that happy state. Let us hope that will continue. If happiness is to be obtained anywhere, it is to be obtained in the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The presentation of the annual report of the Department of the Treasury provides an opportunity for honourable senators to speak on virtually any area of government policy because the Treasury is perhaps the most pervasive of all government departments. One could say a great deal about this Labor Government's policies at this time, about policies which have produced an inflation rate in Australia more than four times higher than that of our major trading partners, an inflation rate that anyone who shops for food or clothing or any other item knows is rising day by day, week by week, month by month. It is a Labor government whose appetite for taxpayers' money to spend on its own behalf knows no bounds, which has led to the highest level of taxation in our history. It is a government whose extravagant spending habit has forced interest rates to the highest level in our history because it has had neither the ability to discipline itself nor the courage to take the tough decisions which are necessary if Australians are to maintain, let alone improve, their living standards. It is a government whose policies are destroying incentive and enterprise in this country.

One could continue almost ad infinitum with this litany of economic mismanagement, but I will not because I want to spend the remainder of my time putting on the public record my appreciation and, I am sure, the appreciation of successive governments and this Parliament for the wonderful public service rendered to this nation by a senior officer who is retiring this week after 43 years with the Australian Treasury. I refer to Dr R. J. Whitelaw, OBE, AM, who is currently the First Assistant Secretary to the Treasury's Overseas Economic Relations Division.

Bob Whitelaw has served under 11 Prime Ministers and, by my calculations, more than a dozen Treasurers. He has represented Australia in London as our senior economic and financial representative; in Washington as Australia's Executive Director on the boards of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank; and in Manila as Australia's Executive Director on the Asian Development Bank. Dr Whitelaw has been a senior member of Australian delegations to more than 24 annual meetings of the IMF and the World Bank. His whole working career of 43 years has been spent in international economics. He has played a major policy advisory role in Australia's participation in international economic and monetary affairs, going back to the formation in the mid-1940s of those gigantic pillars of international post-war reconstruction, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, better known as GATT.

Later, in the 1960s Dr Whitelaw played a significant role in seeking and obtaining Australian membership of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and, in the 1970s, in the new arrangements which followed the collapse of the Bretton Woods international monetary system based on fixed exchange rates. Dr Whitelaw is arguably Australia's best known and most respected economist in international economic matters. I could say much more about Bob Whitelaw's career of service to the Australian people, but time prevents me. Suffice it to say that this week a very distinguished public servant retires. His advice and counsel will be sorely missed by this Government and future governments and in the world's international economic forums. May his retirement be long and very enjoyable.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Committee of Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the first full annual report that we have had from the Commission for the Future. In speculating on the future for the Commission for the Future I am tempted to say that this will be the first and last annual report from the Commission for the Future. The policy of the Opposition is that, when returned at the next election, this is one of the organisations established by this Government which will be wound up. That is not to say that some of the work and some of the projects undertaken by the Commission for the Future are not without merit and it would be churlish of me not to mention in particular the seminars which the Commission has been organising and which have been very well attended by members of the Parliament. Two of them have already been held. The first of them, given by Sir Gustav Nossal, was a very interesting and useful introduction to issues in biotechnology. The second, given by Mr Fred Hilmer, certainly provoked some discussions on the future of work in Australia. A third seminar is scheduled, I think, for next week.

Nevertheless, the Opposition believes, and it has long been my view, that a body specifically established with a budget of some half million dollars or whatever it is to undertake the sort of work which the Commission has before it is not the most appropriate way for the Parliament to be kept informed or indeed for issues to be raised in the wider public arena. I certainly believe that in the selection of the Chairman of the Commission the Government got the Commission off to a wrong start straightaway. I believe that, if the intention of the Government and in particular the intention of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) was to raise a serious discussion on issues of scientific and technological significance in the parliamentary and public arenas, Mr Adams was not the appropriate person to be given that responsibility. I must say that his attitudes and the statements which he has made both about the work of the Commission and the various other bodies which he heads or participates in on behalf of this Government have been singularly unhelpful to an attempt to advance discussion and debate about science and technology issues in Australia. It is interesting, for instance, that the Commission for the Future indicates in the report that at least one of the models used in its establishment was the model in New Zealand. Anybody familiar with the history of the Commission for the Future operations in New Zealand will know that that body had to be wound up by the Government because it did not achieve the objectives which had been set for it but went off on various romps of its own.

What it seems to me is clearly needed is the establishment of a body somewhat akin to the United States Office of Technology Assessment which would be able to provide to the Parliament and, through the Parliament, to the wider community a series of discussion papers or analyses of major issues which would bring science and technology issues before the Parliament in a less jargon-ridden form and in a less `pop' form that the Commission for the Future has attempted. I believe that a body somewhat akin to the Office of Technology Assessment is clearly what is needed. We will have an opportunity to discuss some of these matters, including the parliamentary Senate Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment, when legislation currently before the House of Representatives comes to this chamber.

Nevertheless, some of the activity undertaken by the Commission for the Future is valuable. It could, however, be better undertaken and more effectively and cost efficiently undertaken by other arrangements. They will be put in place when the Opposition parties are elected to government at the next election and the Commission for the Future in its current form will be abolished and restructured in a way in which what ought to be the primary goals of informing the public and the Parliament about issues of science and technology can be undertaken more effectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that what Senator Puplick has really said is that, given his Party's policy, he has to see the Commission for the Future into oblivion if the Opposition finally gets back into government. Underneath that statement though was a fairly generous concession that the Commission for the Future, or something like it, is more than needed in this country. The Opposition's policy on this is simply to abolish it. Furthermore, that abolition was made the subject of a throwaway joke by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he addressed the nation earlier this year. I think that indicates a very poor assessment of the needs of Australia now and in the future. Many of Australia's problems, if not all in economic terms, have arisen because of bad judgments in the 1950s, the 1960s and even earlier as to the future of Australia. If this country needs anything, it needs a body to look into the future and to plot courses that it should follow so that it can get out of its present difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission for the Future, whose Chairman, Mr Phillip Adams, has been condemned in fairly round terms, has operated well under him. There are in its secretariat two people who ought to be mentioned because they have been particularly diligent in putting forward in the community ideas as to where we are going, which ideas are not only properly but also essentially put forward. They are Ms Rhonda Galbally and Dr Louise Crossley who have come to Canberra on two occasions to present for the members of this Parliament matters concerning the future. As Senator Puplick said, Dr Gustav Nossal came here. He is an outstanding scientist who gave to those members of this Parliament who wanted to hear him an idea of where we should be going in the future. I note that the Victorian Government has adopted a lot of the material that he put before us and is going forward, I think properly.

The Commission's communications program, set out on pages 13 and 14 of the report, indicated the sorts of bodies that the Commission has addressed-bodies which will train our future scientists and our future community leaders. This Commission for the Future, particularly under the auspices of Rhonda Galbally and Louise Crossley, will direct those people, those leaders of the future, into the areas that are appropriate. For too long this country has lived in cultural servitude to overseas countries. It has adopted its culture, its science, its technology and its industry programs from overseas. It has been left behind in all those areas to the extent that we are now in all sorts of economic difficulties whereas other countries are not. If honourable senators look at the countries which have set up bodies such as the Commission for the Future they will see what I mean.

The Federal Government, in setting up the Commission for the Future, followed the lead of several overseas countries, notably Sweden-which has a very successful body-Switzerland, West Germany, New Zealand and the United States, all of which have had futures thinking and planning bodies for several years. In the United States of America alone there are 31 State futures commissions. Given that and given the general regard around the world for these sorts of bodies, we now have an Opposition which joyfully looks ahead to crushing not only this commission but all it stands for, which is forward thinking as to where this country ought to go, thinking of the sorts of aspects we ought to be looking at, thinking about technology and thinking about all those areas which can lead us to the future. Instead, with a sneer, the Opposition would throw away all those opportunities so that this country would be left, as it presently is, wandering around loosely looking for overseas directions. Those overseas directions come too late to be of salvation to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Cooney in this matter. I am deeply disappointed with the Opposition's statement that it would dismantle the Commission for the Future if it came into power. I suppose it is what we must come to expect from it. It consists of conservative parties rather than liberal parties. Members of the Opposition would like to see the world stay exactly as it is and the Commission for the Future is suggesting that there can and will be change in Australia. I would like to join Senator Cooney in supporting the Commission and in congratulating Ms Rhonda Galbally who has done a wonderful job in communicating some of the more complex ideas and advances in science within this country and in the rest of the world to ordinary Australians. Senator Puplick seemed to imply a type of elitist attitude which suggests that the only way in which the public of Australia can gain information about science and technological development in Australia is through the Parliament. He wants a body which, I suppose, would be fairly dull and dry and would put out material in the right type of jargon maybe for communicating between scientists and parliamentarians. The parliamentarians would then go out and sell science. I think we have very little hope of that type of thing happening. We have in this Parliament, unfortunately, mainly lawyers and accountants. We have very few people who are scientists. I say to Senator Cooney that the lawyers are very useful, but in this area of science we have a very small voice.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been very impressed with the program of education of parliamentarians into which the Commission has entered. The seminars which have been held on Tuesday nights have had two excellent speakers. I note with enormous anticipation and pleasure that future programs for education of parliamentarians are planned in the areas of information technology in law and education, Australia's natural and agricultural resources and in the commodities trade. So it looks as if we will have an exciting program presenting some of the advances in areas such as computing, information technology, the genetic pool as a resource, and the effect of demographic change on the economic and social implications of the development of new scientific ideas. All these programs which have been produced for the parliamentarians have also been taken up by Robin Williams in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation science programs. These programs have been broadcast on radio and they offer a reasonable forum for the people of Australia to learn something about these new technologies.

I think it is essential that we keep something like the Commission for the Future. It is not an expensive commodity; it is very cheap for what it is achieving. It is achieving a popularisation of science. It is making people aware of new developments, whether in biotechnology, materials science or space technology. It is actually turning these ideas into household words and making certain that the people of Australia are capable of adapting and facing the future with the same excitement that those people who understand science have about our future and about our development of technology. This is a job which is being well done by the Commission for the Future and for which it should be commended. I commend both the report and the Commission to this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate but I feel that it is important to observe what is contained in Appendix 1 of the last page of the annual report of the Commission for the Future. Appendix 1 deals with programs and projects which presumably have been undertaken or will be undertaken by the Commission for the Future. I draw the attention of the Senate to a program relating to technology and development of a productive culture and the project which is described as `Unions of the Future'. I cannot for the life of me see where in the membership of the Commission for the Future there are sufficient capabilities to address that particular subject. That subject has been given a run over the course many times.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that when I first became an official of a trade union way back in 1959 or 1960 people were saying that one of the major problems was the structure of the trade union movement. Of course, others were saying we should get rid of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. At that time, incidentally, it was the communist manifesto within the trade union movement to get rid of the Arbitration Commission. Now it seems to be the new establishment's manifesto. Nevertheless, we have this sort of suggestion to do this and do that, forgetting, of course, that the essential element for orderly industrial progress is that the persons within the system desire to see the system work. That is the essential element. All of these ideas about structure, about the unions of the future and so on may be relevant debating points, but they do not go to the central issue. After all, these matters have been considered by a number of commissions and committees. I recall, for example, that the Australian Science and Technology Council did a report on technological change and employment. There is also a reference by this Senate to its Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment. There was, of course, as honourable senators will know, the Senate select committee which I had the honour to chair on industrial relations legislation. There is a whole host of areas.

I do not know quite what the Commission for the Future is doing in respect of this particular area. Someone might say: `Well, unions of the future is a narrow area'. But my concern is that so often people address that issue from on high. They do not even go to the rank and file to see what the membership of the union movement wants. After all, they are the people who ought to have the say; we should not have persons such as commissioners for the future imposing upon the ordinary rank and file what they consider to be the unions of the future.

Indeed, this particular question goes to other areas as well. The Commission, in its latest publication, which is a rather hep, glossy publication-I do not have it with me-talks about one of its projects involving biotechnology. I do not see it here in the appendix number 1. I would be interested to know, for example, whether the Commission has been through all of the evidence that we on the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 have gone through. We received some 273 submissions; we waded through those submissions. We heard evidence from 64 people. There are, I think, seven books of Hansard verbatim evidence; and we gave a report to this Parliament. This is the sort of way to deal with these questions, rather than through a non-elected body such as the Commission for the Future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the annual report of the Commission for the Future from a number of points of view, but I am moved particularly to do so because in the early 1980s a body known as Australian Frontier had for two years running annual future directions conferences. In 1982 I was privileged to participate in the second of those conferences, which seem not to have taken place since. That conference addressed the issues of the minerals boom and whether that would be the future for Australia. It was an exciting and rewarding experience. Perhaps one of the most significant things that arose from that conference was from a very disparate group of people a feeling that Australia needed some kind of futures institute to operate on a regular basis in examining issues of the future. It was not until the Commission for the Future was formed and became operational in February of this year that such a body existed in this country. I am not sure that that body is exactly as was envisaged in the Australian Frontier Conference, but in my contacts with the Commission for the Future I have felt it to be an extraordinarily successful and potentially important group for the future of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of Parliament I find the remarks in the report on page 5 which refer to there being no more important group for focusing and reflecting community expectations than parliamentarians, and the words that follow that passage, rather polite. It suggests that parliamentarians often have little opportunity to consider issues that are not immediate and are beyond party policy, the next Budget or the current parliamentary schedule. That is very polite and puts the matter mildly. If there is any group in the community that needs its vision drawn further into the future it is parliamentarians. I have no doubt that the longer I stay here the more I will believe that. Here in the chamber this afternoon we had a good instance of some people having problems with the present, let alone with the future, when earlier in the day we heard a senator grappling with the thought that women might actually have a choice; complaining about what has happened because of the introduction of the Family Law Act-that women are not now staying where they should be, in their homes, whether or not they are miserable or suffering physically or emotionally.

Women as much as anyone else have a right to choices. That is a fact of the present, and hopefully will be even more significantly a fact of the future. It is in that sort of area that a body such as the Commission for the Future can play a significant role in drawing the attention, particularly of parliamentarians but of the rest of the community also, to what is likely to happen. This report shows how already the Commission for the Future has spread its influence right across the spectrum. I am greatly looking forward to my first participation in one of the seminars provided for parliamentarians next week. I note from the report that the Victorian Parliament is planning to use the good offices of the Commission for the Future. I can only hope that certain other parliaments in other States will take the opportunity to give their parliamentarians a change to consider issues of the future, guided and encouraged by the Commission for the Future. I, too, wish the Commission well and commend the report. I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Examination of Annual Reports

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Colston:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report by the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts is one in a series of seven reports that deal with the various papers and annual reports of statutory authorities and departments that are tabled in the Senate. The public might wonder what happens when hundreds of reports are tabled. In the last half an hour senators have commented for a period of up to five minutes on various reports and papers received by the Senate, but it is our procedure to refer annual reports from statutory authorities to the various standing committees of the Senate for them to consider whether they want to follow up matters more particularly. The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has taken that course and we now have seven such reports before us dealing with items arising from annual reports. The report that is to hand concerns the annual reports of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for 1983-84 and 1984-85. In particular we wished to examine more closely some aspects of the ABC's radio broadcasts in Queensland. Consequently public hearings were held in Queensland in February this year. The outcome of those hearings and the Committee's deliberations are in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Sport on radio can be controversial, particularly when an event of national interest is not broadcast in a region, especially by the ABC whose radio stations have the best coverage of remote areas and country areas generally. Also, a sports service on radio can be controversial when, after many years of covering a sport at particular times in the week, that service is abruptly and permanently discontinued. It is with such an event in mind relating to the broadcasting of sport in Queensland that we came to focus on some particular areas of inquiry. However, my interest in this inquiry has not been aroused by the fact that it concerned a sporting service, nor that it concerned a radio broadcast or Queensland. My interest in this inquiry and in the report before the Senate centres entirely on the accountability of the ABC to Parliament-and through Parliament to the people of Australia. I believe, and I know that the Senate believes, that the ABC should be properly accountable to Parliament. The ABC is a Commonwealth statutory body and is governed by the legislation of the Commonwealth Parliament which created it. The ABC, like other Commonwealth statutory bodies, receives almost all its revenue from taxpayers through the annual Budget decisions of the Commonwealth Government and the decisions subsequently made by the House of Representatives and here in the Senate.

In this report the Senate Committee has described a serious breakdown in the ABC's willingness to be accountable to Parliament. I describe this as a breakdown because from the outset and from the highest authority in the ABC, the Board itself, there was a determination earlier this year not to co-operate with the Senate inquiry. The stance adopted by the Board flowed on in all the following months from this decision by the ABC Board. The decision not to co-operate is reflected in the ABC's written submission to the Committee. It is reflected in the ABC's Press statements and the disparaging leaks the Corporation made about the inquiry. It is reflected in the ABC's limiting its representatives appearing before the hearings. It is also reflected in the ABC's appointing legal counsel to attend the public hearings with the ABC witnesses. Quite dramatically and most unfortunately, it is reflected in the ABC's refusal to answer questions. The deadlock that ensued and the complete farce that developed in the Brisbane hearings is further evidence. Finally, the ABC refused, at the level of the Chair of the Board, the General Manager and the Board itself, to be conciliatory and it failed to resolve the matter.

This is very clearly brought to the attention of the Senate in the report before us. All these events are described in chapter 4 of the report-I believe very adequately-and there is no need to go over them in detail here. I note only that, having been a senator now for more than eight years and having participated in dozens of inquiries, I have never encountered or even thought possible such a recalcitrant and reluctant witness. In my view, the ABC has been extraordinarily lacking in responsibility. I hope that the Senate's resolution in this debate and in response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts will put this precedent, this kind of impasse, entirely behind us. The ABC must see itself as being properly accountable to Parliament, accountable to the Senate and to the Senate's committees. Now that there have been changes in the Board and the general management of the ABC and also changes for the ABC, in this year's Budget, I expect there will be a full acceptance by the Corporation of its proper accountability to Parliament and through Parliament to the people of Australia.
I refer briefly to three particular aspects of the ABC's argument. First, in section 4.8 of the Senate Committee's report we highlight the principal summary statement the ABC put to us. It said:

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 guarantees the editorial independence of the Corporation's program services. The ABC holds its power to make programming decisions as a trust on behalf of the people of Australia, for which it is accountable to Parliament, but in which by law and convention, neither the Government nor Parliament seeks to intervene.

I regard that statement as circular and self-serving and I reject it. I do not reject that the Parliament should not interfere in the programming decisions of the ABC, but I reject the conundrum at the end of that statement whereby the ABC is saying that it is accountable to Parliament but `by law and convention' it is not, in effect, accountable to Parliament. In other words, it wants to be accountable in theory, but not in practice. Also at section 5.5 and section 5.9 of the report, the ABC sets out its view that it wishes to pick and choose which committees of the Parliament it will answer and which it will not. It said that it would be quite all right to answer questions if they had been put by the Estimates Committee of the Senate, but not if they had been put by a standing committee of the Senate. I reject this totally. Also, the ABC tries to appeal for protection from interference because it claims that its programming decisions are not to be interfered with. I agree with that, but I do not think that that limited programming area should be extended to the wider and general decisions the ABC has made. It must be fully accountable for its wider and general decisions.
In the time available to me, and bearing these points in mind, I foreshadow an amendment to the motion that the Senate take note of the report. With such amendment, the motion would read:
That the Senate take note of the report and

(a) agrees with the Committee's conclusion that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's approach to the Committee's inquiry was incorrect and that the ABC and any summoned officers of the ABC should have answered the Committee's questions; and

(b) asserts that the ABC and any other witnesses to Senate Committees have an obligation to co-operate and to answer questions within the terms of reference of Senate Standing Committees and Senate Estimates Committees alike; and

(c) requests the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts to consider, in the light of its own evidence and the answers subsequently given by the ABC to Senate Estimates Committees whether further investigation is required.
Time prevents me from continuing now and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have used up your full time already, Senator Teague.
—Nevertheless, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Colston) agreed to:
That, on the resumption of the debate, Senator Teague be given a further two minutes to speak.
