DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present the report on the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority annual report 1983-84.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The 1983-84 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority-or GALA for short-was not tabled until some 14 months after the end of the relevant financial year and the financial statements of the Australian Capital Territory Totalisator Agency Board operations and poker machine operations were qualified by the Auditor-General. The Committee received explanations for the delay in tabling the annual report from the Authority and from the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes). A number of factors contributed to the delay, including lengthy negotiations with the Audit Office on the form and content of the financial statements, staff absences over holiday periods, and difficulty in deciding on the appropriate policy on one matter. The Committee observes that not all the delay is adequately explained.

The Gaming and Liquor Authority's enabling legislation does not require an annual report to be made. However, the Betting Ordinance and the Poker Machine Ordinance require an annual report to be prepared for the Minister, although the Minister is not required to table the report. Government guidelines for annual reporting by statutory authorities require that annual reports of all authorities be furnished to the relevant Minister as soon as possible after the end of each financial year but no later than six months after that time and that the Minister table the report within 15 sitting days. Compliance with the guidelines did not occur in the case of GALA's 1983-84 report. The Committee regards annual reporting as an important aspect of accountability. It believes that it is undesirable that the Gaming and Liquor Authority remain without a clear obligation to report on its operations and therefore recommends that the Gaming and Liquor Authority Act be amended to require GALA to furnish an annual report to the Minister. This would then bring the report under the 1983 amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act, which requires reporting within six months.

With respect to the qualifications of the financial statements made by the Auditor-General, the Committee is satisfied that the matters have now been resolved so that the qualifications no longer apply. However, a number of matters were noted by the Committee. First, GALA exceeded its powers by investing TAB funds in bank accepted bills of exchange, particularly with banks other than the Commonwealth Bank. This matter was finally remedied in December 1984.

Secondly, GALA and the Department of Territories have failed to ensure that a necessary amendment was made to the Poker Machine Ordinance so as to remove doubts about the validity of the Authority's investment policy. It is nine years since the matter was first raised and even now the amendment has still not been made. Thirdly, from 1978 apparently misinterpreted-to put it kindly-ministerial approval was relied upon as the basis for the continued investment of large sums of money. The Committee states that the Authority should have ceased the investment until the necessary powers promised by the then Minister in 1978 were enacted.

Fourthly, GALA should have in the first instance sought advice on the legal interpretation of its ordinances from the Attorney-General's Department. If that had been done, the dispute over the investment of poker machine moneys would not have arisen. The Committee believes that all authorities should seek advice on statutory interpretation from the Attorney-General's Department, not from private solicitors unless specific and valid circumstances prevent the Department from providing that advice.

Finally, the Committee notes that GALA's 1984-85 annual report was tabled with only a small delay and that, although the financial statements were again qualified, the qualifications were in respect of the two matters that have now been resolved.

I regret that lax administration involving an Australian Capital Territory authority has again led to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations having to conduct an inquiry and table a report. However, I am pleased that we have helped to ensure that some of the problems have been resolved. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was debating the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill and I had indicated that the Opposition is in complete agreement with the intention of the legislation, which is to increase the variety of services to the aged in the area of residential accommodation and community services. I commented that Australia has only just scratched the surface as far as community services are concerned and that, apart from meals on wheels, assistance in the home varies considerably. So much of it depends on the local government in the area where a person lives. We could do so much more to help people stay in their homes as long as possible as we know that that is where they want to be. We could help with home cleaning and home maintenance, with small jobs and minor repairs. We could finance ramps instead of steps and hand rails that could assist the elderly to pull themselves up out of baths or showers and thus give them security. We could assist with alarm systems. As I have already indicated, there is considerable worry for the safety of those people. We could help with personal hygiene care.

SPEECH.PARA: As we went around the country we saw that some of the nursing homes have certainly made a commitment in this area. Some of them go to extreme lengths. They send out a bus to collect the elderly from their homes or from local hostels and take them to their day care centre where they are bathed or helped with showers. For the rest of the day they are assisted with activities and entertainment in which they participate, and with general diversional therapy. If we could give that home service, it would be so greatly acceptable not only to the Government coffers, because it would be very much cheaper to keep the elderly in their homes even if we supplied all of the services that I have mentioned, but also to the elderly who, as I have already indicated, want to stay in their homes for as long as possible. Once they are no longer able to do that, the elderly usually move into hostel accommodation.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen, in her speech, said that many of the church groups have a system whereby the elderly go into hostels, then move into church nursing homes and then into a hospital when they become too ill to stay in the nursing home. In the hostels it is so much easier to supply the services required. The elderly are all in one area so the services for meals, home assistance, the alarm system, the personal care and the activities are so easily able to be carried out. Many of the elderly go on tours around the countryside from the hostels. In general it has become a very acceptable way for the elderly to spend some of their years.

Senator Crowley said that in the past nursing homes have been places to which people have not been very keen to go. They were also places into which many of the elderly were inappropriately placed. That has altered over the years. We now find that the proprietors of nursing homes say that their clientele has changed considerably. No longer are the people who are fairly healthy bedded in their homes; the current residents are more frail and aged than previous residents. However, we must continue to move in that direction. Indeed, the Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, of which I was a member, brought down a major recommendation that a multi-disciplinary assessment team, comprising the patient's doctor and various other health people, should assess patients before they move into the nursing homes. We also recommended that, having moved into the nursing home, a patient should be reassessed after three months to make sure that the placement has been appropriate. So many people move into nursing homes, and they can be rehabilitated and moved out after a short period.

We also recommended that all nursing homes should provide some diversional therapy. We also said that they should supply some respite care. If a certain number of beds were set aside in nursing homes, subsidised by the Government, for respite care, I believe that this would be of considerable assistance in keeping the elderly in their own homes. The situation arises so frequently where a daughter, who visits her mother regularly and makes sure that everything is all right for her and that she is in good health, has to go away with the family on a holiday. She ought to be able to do that knowing that when she returns she can again take up the job of looking after her mother. In so many cases, daughters do not consider it a burden to look after their mother in that situation; they consider it a joy. If while the daughter was on holiday the mother could be moved into respite care just for that period, it would assist families to be able to look after their elderly.
In the second reading speech, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) gave the four basic goals of the legislation. With these goals we certainly agree. The goals are as follows:
Aged and disabled people should as far as possible be supported in their own homes, in their own communities.
I have already spoken about this at length and underlined the importance that the Opposition sees in that. The next goal is:
Aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs.
Again, the Opposition would agree wholeheartedly with that. The next goal is:

Services should be provided in an atmosphere and using processes which promote as far as possible rehabilitation and restoration of function. The manner in which these services are provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and independent functioning of all residents.

We saw that when we attended some of the nursing homes. Some of them supplied very good rehabilitation services and the residents were able to function very happily in that atmosphere. The fourth goal is:

Services should be based on a recognition that, for many people, discharge to a residential service providing a less intensive form of care or to a community-based support service will be a possible and desirable outcome.

The Minister then went on to say that if there were to be an emphasis on hostel financing, away from nursing home financing-I underline what Senator Crowley said when she commented that there is no suggestion in the legislation that the number of nursing home beds be decreased-the increase in nursing homes would be governed. So the increase in the number of nursing homes will not be as great as it has been in the past, but the financing will be put into hostel accommodation. In that, the Minister has said that five matters must have consideration. These are as follows:
the requirement for flexible planning, which provides for monitoring, evaluation and changes where necessary, including more integration with community services;
a publicised and better resourced hostel sector so that hostels can care for increasingly dependent aged people . . .
At the moment they do not provide for increasingly dependent aged people, and that is an area for which the Government intends to increase finances. Another matter is:
the extension of residential care services beyond hostels to other forms of accommodation such as group housing arrangements.
The Government sees it not only in the area of hostels but also in group housing arrangements. The next matter is:
the expansion of community services to assist those elderly people most at risk of premature and inappropriate institutionalisation.

The last matter is the importance of carefully developing a process of assessment so that it will gain support from consumers-that is, the elderly-the professionals, who look after them, and the service providers.

This legislation covers only a couple of those areas. There are several areas that have not been approached by the Government in this legislation, and I dare say that it hopes to move to those areas in the future. This was referred to by Senator Giles when she spoke of the inappropriate placing of so many of our young in nursing homes. As we went around, we found the results of many car crashes. The young, because of their disabilities, have been placed in nursing homes. This was most inappropriate. We found young, mentally alert people in wheel-chairs or with various forms of disability, unable to communicate with people of their own age, unable to undertake the activities that would be appropriate for them, and surrounded by elderly people. We really must move in the direction of giving them an opportunity of being placed in appropriate care.

Our Committee's recommendation was that nursing homes specifically for young people be moved from the nursing home program to a more appropriate scheme-for example, the handicapped persons assistance program. I know that that would be a very expensive way of going about this matter, but we viewed one very successful scheme under which the young were all in one very large house. Each had his or her independent bedroom, and they moved around and socialised together. That was most appropriate. They all seemed fairly happy there. Some were able to go home at weekends, where their wife or husband, as the case may be, could tend to them for just that weekend, and then they would return to the home arrangement. We must work in that area.

Another area that has not been fully examined and one which needs appropriate action is that of the confused and psychiatric patient. So many nursing homes are unable to supply proper facilities for this group of people. So many criticisms are levelled against nursing homes because the patient has to be tied, either in a chair beside the bed or in the bed. In many cases this criticism is most unjustified because there is no other way that the nursing home could possibly keep a confused or psychiatric patient away from harm. Indeed, if proper facilities are not available, there is often no alternative, because the majority of such patients will wander at large, either out on to the road, where he or she may get run over, or into areas that are most dangerous for such people. We did see some very appropriate and very nice nursing homes with large gardens and walled areas where the psychiatric or confused patients were able to wander, and they appeared to be very happy in those circumstances.

The third group that I believe we should be looking at in a more compassionate way is the ethnic elderly. We were told that when the ethnic elderly become aged they move back to their original customs, even though they may have been successfully integrated into the Australian community until then. They want their ethnic meals and they revert to their original language. We were told that it was most appropriate in those instances for nurses at least to be able to translate the language used and that these elderly people should be able to get the type of meals they want.

Senator Peter Baume has spoken about the amendments the Opposition will put forward. As I have already said, the Opposition agrees entirely with the legislation before the Senate. The proposed amendments are designed to give the Parliament more scrutiny and control, rather than relying entirely on ministerial power. I believe that the Government will agree with this proposition. I am sure that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) would not want to have the power unto himself; I am sure he would be far happier with parliamentary scrutiny. I believe he will accept at least some of the amendments.

It is extremely pleasing for me to join in a debate where there is general agreement by all parties in the Parliament, where the Government and the Opposition can come together for the good of one section of the community. It is even more pleasing for me when that section of the community is the aged. It is, as it should be, a situation where both sides of the Parliament have joined to enable our elderly as far as possible to be supported in their own homes and in their own communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that all parties agree that the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill is a congenial one, and we will be happy to see it passed. It certainly represents a step in the right direction. When this Government takes a step such as this I wonder whether it has not lost its way! Be that as it may, we had better grasp this legislation while we can. It represents another chapter in the saga of the Federal Government wrestling with the nursing homes monster that it created many years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I happen to have been in medical practice before the Federal Government decided to help the nursing home industry. In those days it was a congenial part of medical practice. There were a few large nursing homes run by the religious and charitable institutions but there were many more small nursing homes scattered throughout the suburbs of the big cities and in the towns around the country. Most of the people were looked after at home. It was just after the war and there was a tremendous amount of community goodwill in those days. Service groups such as the Rotary clubs, the Australian Jaycees, various guilds and Meals on Wheels used to help people looking after others who needed nursing home care in their homes. There was no shortage of beds. When a doctor was out visiting a patient he and the family could see when the time a patient would need nursing home care was approaching. They could pick which nursing home had the facilities and the various therapies available for that particular patient, get in touch with the matron or the sister in charge and then the matron or the sister would visit the patient with the doctor, talk to the family and see whether the one suited the other.

We did not need any assessment teams such as the Government is introducing now, at an initial cost of something like $16.5m, to make sure that a low cost patient is not in a high cost bed. Back in those days the assessment team was the family, the patient, the doctor and the sister in charge of the nursing home. It was all done as part of looking after the patient and, when the time came, the patient went into the nursing home. That arrangement meant that patients were living in a nursing home that was rather similar to the home they had come from. They were near their relatives for ease of visiting during visiting hours. They could be visited by grandchildren, if they wanted, and if they were well enough they could have outings. They could be taken to church or shopping, or just for a drive. The patients could take family portraits and even articles of their own furniture and things that they felt more comfortable with into the homes. Any sloppy service was very quickly picked up by the staff, the visiting doctor, the family or the patient. There was no need for myriad inspectors. In those days any faults with feeding, bathing or nursing were quickly picked up and amicably rectified. I do not recall a lot of problems. Undoubtedly there was some variation in the quality of the nursing homes, but nothing like the variations that have been disclosed by the report of the Senator Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, which I think are a direct result of the government assistance given to nursing homes.

The Government decided to intervene, in about the middle of the 1950s, and the method it chose was open-ended funding for nursing homes. Of course once open-ended funding was introduced there was an immediate proliferation of nursing homes throughout the country. It became one of the biggest and best businesses in the country and it was not long before the Government realised that it had created an open-ended financial monster. Inevitably on came the Government restrictions, controls and regulations that dictated what type of buildings could be used as nursing homes, their siting, what sort of staffing they would have, their staff-patient ratios and what fees they would charge. Accreditation was brought it. There were a whole lot of terms and conditions that increased costs above even their existing level.

The licensing of nursing homes was removed from the field of State governments because of the open-ended funding, and joint Federal-State licensing teams were formed which allocated beds on a population ration basis. Naturally they had a very slow turnover and could not pick where new beds or extensions to homes were required, and dislocations started to appear. Hostels started to appear as a means of providing cheaper care, respite care appeared, independent living units appeared, home help appeared. In the days before the Government stepped in the flow of patients was naturally from their own homes, where most of them were looked after, to an independent living unit or a hostel if it was available, to a nursing home and then to a hospital. Of course, once the Government stepped in with open-ended funding all the people wanted to go to nursing homes and hospitals because that is where they got the greatest rebate for their medical insurance. So there was a glut at that end.

The whole thrust of this legislation is to reverse the patient flow to take them out of the high cost end of hospitals and nursing homes and encourage them, using the financial incentive, back into the hostels, the independent living units and their own homes. A vast range of community home care is envisaged to help this flow of patients back to their own homes. Of course, that is the right direction, but that is where they all were in the first place, before the Government tried to assist nursing home patients. Honourable senators have mentioned in this debate that the problem has been the government subsidy. Of course, government subsidy means government control. As I have explained, dislocations occur where we get the low cost patient in the high cost bed and where we do not have the development of the industry that we should have. We have heard mentioned in the debate this afternoon that young people who have been disabled have not been looked after, that old, mentally deranged people do not have facilities available to them; but that is all because those parts of the industry were not allowed to develop as a result of the types of nursing homes that developed under the open-ended funding. Had the industry been left alone I am sure that by now those areas would have been adequately catered for.

However, the government controls were imposed, the dislocations occurred, costs went up, and restrictions were imposed. Right at this moment many nursing homes are in need of extensions and many areas could do with more nursing homes, particularly in my own area in south-east Queensland. On the Gold Coast where I live there is a need for extensions and additions to nursing homes. Of course, with the Government committee deciding now many beds will go where, it is all taking too long and often it is not being decided. This Bill, in particular, will put restrictions on the numbers of nursing home beds that will be allowed in the future simply because the Government is subsidising them. I know of nursing homes that would be quite prepared to put on any extension that is necessary, and put patients in there and not receive a subsidy for them but they cannot do that because once a nursing home bed is recognised and registered it attracts a subsidy and it has to have the subsidy. So the Government refuses these nursing homes extensions or additions, and it even refuses to allow new nursing homes. One of the easiest ways out of the problem would be for the Government to allow nursing homes to make additions or extensions and allow new nursing homes that do not attract a subsidy at all, in order to get us back to where we were. Local needs change. Quite often they change rapidly, particularly in a State such as Queensland, which is decentralised and has new towns appearing in mining areas, for example. They need the facility of nursing home care so that younger people can have their parents or grandparents with them when they go to isolated areas. By the time the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) gets around to making a decree the need will probably be over, or it will be very desperate.

With any luck this legislation will mean a reduction in real terms in the government subsidy to nursing homes. In other words, there will be a bigger gap between the fee charged and the subsidy the Government pays. It may sound a little callous and harsh, but every step we retreat from the government subsidy is a step in the right direction and it will be better for all of us. It is just a pity that the Government does not reduce personal income tax by the amount of money it will save with this Bill. All the talk we have heard about tax reductions under this Government has been only rhetoric. Taxes are higher and money is being taken away from the people, so it will be more difficult for them to manage. Nevertheless, this is still a step in the right direction.

It is cruel to decrease services and increase taxes. If the Government would reduce personal income tax so that people could better afford private care that would take an enormous load off the Government. I liken this step to the Government removing the subsidy to private hospitals. Some $140m a year has just been removed from the private hospitals. I actually see that as a good step. I think the Government was probably trying to drive patients out of the private hospitals and have them all go to public hospitals, but because the private hospitals are now not subject to receiving the Government subsidy it will lead to a freer and better type of private hospital care and I think we will see an upsurge in private hospital care in Australia that is freed from the thraldom of government.

There are two main purposes of the Bill. The first one is the grants for capital works-grants up to the full amount of the capital cost of buildings for aged or disabled persons, so long as the grants are used exclusively to finance disabled groups. The second purpose I have been talking about is the new growth control of nursing home beds. As has been mentioned, we want to move some amendments to the Bill. These amendments were discussed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and I understand that they have been discussed with the Minister. With any luck he will be amenable to those amendments, particularly as there is obviously no provision for a review of a departmental secretary's decision on whether a nursing home facility is necessary for a disadvantaged group.

The point I want to leave with the Minister-I would like to have it answered if possible-is that thought be given to allowing the construction of new beds which do not attract a subsidy from the Government. I think that would be a major step that could help to relieve a lot of the problems of the nursing home industry in Australia today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not speak at great length on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill, which is before the Senate, because the Opposition is supporting it. Other senators have spoken to this Bill, but I wish to refer to some aspects as they affect the Australian Capital Territory. I have spoken previously about some of these matters. I have told the Senate that there are over 240 citizens in the Australian Capital Territory who have been classified as being in need of nursing home beds but who are on a waiting list and are not able to obtain them. It is necessary to remember that this is the case while we talk about other forms of care. The home and community care program enables people to remain in their own homes for a longer time. For many that is desirable, it is what they want, and undoubtedly it is the cheapest way of caring for a person. Of course, there are some who eventually get to the stage where they are not able to care for themselves. In some instances, to leave them alone and merely give attention periodically leaves them in a totally isolated situation. They are merely existing in their own homes without really being able to enjoy life at all or get any assistance towards rehabilitation.

SPEECH.PARA: I also recognise that the concept of developing more hostels meets some of the need. In fact, I think a lot of people would welcome the opportunity to live in a hostel environment where they have the opportunity to mix with others and enjoy the life that can be obtained from having more people around them. That still does not address the fact that there are people who require nursing home care eventually, and they are not all the frail aged. Earlier in the debate we heard about those younger people who for various reasons fall into the category of needing the quite intensive care that comes with nursing home care.

I refer to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review report which was prepared by the Department of Community Services and which was tabled in, I think, April this year. It refers in a couple of places to the Territory. In one part, in reference to numbers of people, there is the statement:
The rate of increase will be fairly stable in all States, while the two Territories-
that is, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory-
will experience a more rapid increase in the numbers of the aged.

That would lead me to conclude that the present number of 240 people who are waiting for nursing home beds in the Australian Capital Territory will grow if this report is correct. The report also gives details of the overall placements and bed provision. There we see that presently, on the basis of number of beds per thousand people over the age of 70, the rate in the Australian Capital Territory is much lower than in other States and Territories-57.9 per cent for nursing homes and 33.2 per cent for hostels.

I endorse the comments made by Senator Sheil that the present system, whereby the granting of a licence for nursing home beds must attract a subsidy, needs to be reviewed and that nexus needs to be broken so that there can be a place for private nursing home beds which do not attract a subsidy. There may not be call for a great many of them, but I think there would be call for some which would be occupied and which would take the pressure away from the number of beds which presently attract a subsidy. I think that needs to be looked into. I also question whether the present cost, alleged to be about $20,000 per nursing home bed on an annual basis, is realistic or whether savings could be made in that area. While there are subsidies the cost is likely to be higher than it ought to be.

The report on which I have referred also indicates that, on present indications, by the year 1996 the Australian Capital Territory will need an additional 848 nursing home beds. Under the proposal that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) announced recently, the Australian Capital Territory will get an additional 180 hostel beds but only 20 nursing home beds between now and 1989. I think that is fairly dismal news for the families who are worried and concerned about the welfare of the frail aged to whom I have referred as being presently in need of nursing home accommodation but who cannot get it. In addition to the 240 who are waiting, I would say that 40 or more in our hospitals need nursing home beds. They do not really need hospital accommodation, but they are not able to obtain the nursing home beds that they need. When the situation becomes desperate in Canberra, as it is at present, it is necessary to look to New South Wales. Some of the elderly people from this Territory have been taken to Eden, Pambula, Sydney and beyond. This is almost inhuman in terms of the stress under which it puts the aged person and the stress for the families who have to make arrangements to send elderly relatives so far away from them. It is difficult for them to visit. It is certainly unsettling for an elderly person to have to adjust to being removed from his or her family in that way.

I could spend the rest of the afternoon recounting stories, which I have heard in my electorate office, of people who suddenly need nursing home beds but who are not able to get them. It can happen quite suddenly. An elderly person who has managed to live by himself or herself for a considerable time, with support from family or perhaps from Meals on Wheels and the other services which are provided, may have an accident or fall-it particularly happens to elderly women who may break bones-and may no longer be able to live in that way and may require a nursing home bed. In Canberra, even a hostel bed is hard to come by. I have the figures for the beds that are available. There are 126 at Jindalee Nursing Home; 128 at Allambee Nursing Home; beds in the hospitals are being used as nursing home beds; there are 126 private nursing home beds and 335 hostel beds. On the evidence that we have as to the needs of this community, they are well short of the numbers that are required.

We do not have beds available for people to convalesce. We do not have beds available for respite care. If older people who need to convalesce are sent home and are living by themselves, it frequently means that they will be back in hospital before too long because they are not able to cope. It is a vicious circle of having a shortage of hospital beds in Canberra so that people cannot be kept in them for as long as they require and not having enough nursing home beds either. One way or another, as a community we have an obligation to look after our elderly and those who are sick and cannot fully care for themselves. I suggest that at present we are not doing it properly.

It would seem from this report of the Department of Community Services that, in addition to the 200 extra beds that the Minister has announced, we will need another 648 in the seven-year period to 1996. I do not think I would be unreasonable if I expressed some pessimism about whether they will be available, but I say that they must be available. In the Australian Capital Territory we have in hospital beds and nursing home beds people who have come here from other places because their families are here. I believe there is a distortion in the figures because of that. It is my view that we are not adequately providing at present for people who need this sort of care in this community. I welcome the move that is made in this legislation. As I said, the Opposition is supporting it. I take the opportunity to refer specifically to the problems that exist in my electorate, and I hope they will be addressed before too long.

I refer also to the scrutiny of Bills report which has been referred to. I hope the Minister will deal with the matters that have been raised within that report because I think they are important issues as to the discretion conferred on the secretary. In relation to a number of sections the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills refers to the lack of parliamentary scrutiny. The Committee reported to the Senate that it recognises that it is the view of the Administrative Review Council that decisions which involve apportioning of finite resources are not appropriate for review on the merits, but it also goes on to say:

Nevertheless the Committee draws clauses 19 and 32 to the attention of Senators in that they may be considered to make rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable administrative decisions.
I think these observations of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee ought to be dealt with by the Government, and I hope the Minister will do this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their thoughtful contributions to this debate on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. This area of nursing homes, hostels, accommodation and care for the aged generally is not an easy one. It is one with which governments in this country have been grappling since, I suppose, the Second World War. It is an interesting situation in that so many people have so many firm views on the subject and so many people have views on the subject which are just not right. I will refer, not in any critical way, to what the last two speakers said. Both Senator Sheil and Senator Reid referred to the possibility that nursing homes could be built without subsidy and that maybe this would be a solution to the problem. There is nothing--
—We did not say it was a solution. It may help, in part, by providing some beds, not nursing homes. You are misinterpreting what we said.

—I am sorry, but the honourable senator has misheard what I said. I said that she and Senator Sheil suggested that part of the problem may be solved by providing nursing home beds without subsidy. Senator Sheil, at least, and, I thought, Senator Reid asked: Why is that not possible? My response to that is: It is perfectly possible. There is nothing in the world to stop anyone building a nursing home and filling it with people without Commonwealth subsidy.
—They have to be licensed, and that attracts a subsidy.

—The licensing authorities are the State governments. In the Australian Capital Territory certainly it involves the Federal Government. Senator Sheil is quite wrong. There is nothing to stop people doing that. There is nothing that the Commonwealth would want to do to stop people doing that. If people want to build nursing homes without subsidy, they can. If they want to run them without subsidy, they can. The licensing authorities, I am sure, in many of the States would be only too happy for them to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: However, we have in this country a problem, which Senator Reid, I think, touched on, of a very high percentage of nursing home beds for the elderly population. We have a maldistribution of nursing home beds, I am the first to admit, which we have been trying to correct. In the past nursing homes in, say, the big conurbations of Sydney and Melbourne tended to be built in the eastern suburbs where there were appropriate old homes and mansions, but the people tended to be in the western suburbs where there were not the mansions et cetera which could be converted into nursing homes. Only in recent times has there been a better distribution of nursing home beds. Also, under the legislation previously in place, people tended to build nursing homes rather than hostels because of the increased amounts of subsidy they could get for nursing homes and people tended to believe that the only alternative to staying in one's home, when elderly, was to go into a nursing home. In this country people tended to believe that nursing homes were the only alternative form of accommodation. As the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review pointed out, and as various organisations in the area have pointed out for many years, to concentrate on building the most expensive and the most dependent form of care accommodation for the aged and not to concentrate on the provision of services or on the provision of hostels or less dependent accommodation led to the distortion we have.

All governments with good faith and all parties involved in government or potentially in government in this country have been taking a conscientious approach to this very real difficulty. Senator Peter Baume, Senator Walters, Senator Powell and Senator Bjelke-Petersen-I think every speaker-made the very valid point, which I agree with, that there is a need for more home and community services if we are to provide less of this more dependent form of accommodation. We certainly agree with that. We have an agreed plan, as is known, I think, with the State governments to develop more home and community care services. In the last Budget we announced further home and community care funding totalling $94m over four years to further increase growth in home and community care services. We have had very good examples in some isolated situations where this can be extremely effective. I know of one city in Victoria where nine years ago there was a 40-bed nursing home with a waiting list of 150. For reasons which obviously involved people thinking way ahead of their time, instead of succumbing to the pressure to build more nursing home beds that community built a hostel, provided more independent-type accommodation, and, what is more important, provided community-based home and community care services. Now, nine years later, that community has a 40-bed nursing home, as it had before, and a waiting list of nil. The temptation in those days was to double or even treble the size of the nursing home to overcome an apparent lack of nursing home beds in that area. In fact, the problem was solved in a much more socially and economically acceptable way by providing that mix of services which resulted in the nursing home of 40 beds nine years ago being a perfectly satisfactory level of nursing home beds in that town.

Only last week I was in Scone in New South Wales, a very enlightened and small community which, over the last few years, has provided independent-type units scattered throughout the town, a nursing home and a hostel and which now has facilities worth something like $4m of which that relatively small town provided $2m-worth. That town has a very satisfactory care of the aged program and is doing it in an economical way and in a way of which the town is very proud and of which anyone in the community would be very proud. All these things are possible. They would not be possible if we proceeded down the track we were proceeding down in the past whereby the number of nursing home beds was increasing rapidly, the cost per bed to the taxpayer was rising at something like twice the rate of average weekly earnings and we were facing in the long run a situation in which the community would have great difficulty supporting this relatively unsatisfactory form of care.

Senator Powell noted that the Bill provides for two elements, improved planning and improved hostel growth and said that, with these two elements of the Government's announced five-point residential care reform strategy, we also have to address the other three elements-expanded assessment, greater flexibility in the provision of accommodation and further HACC expansion. I have said that we agree with the further expansion of home and community care. We agree also with the need for better assessment. In fact, in the last Budget we provided an increase from $4m to anticipated expenditure of $13m in 1988-89 for geriatric assessment. This assessment does not mean just a gate-keeping role to keep people out of this dependent nursing home accommodation. What it means is assessing people's needs so that they have a better idea of the choices they have in their retirement and the choices available to them in the community to ensure that they get the care which is appropriate to their needs and which maintains their independence and their dignity as individuals.

If people's view is that the only choice they have is to stay at home or to go into an expensive, dependent-making nursing home, that is what they will think of. If they are afraid that some day they may need to go into a nursing home and that the best thing for them to do is to put their names on a waiting list for fear that when they get sick five or 10 years down the track they will need to go into a nursing home, we get a distorted picture of nursing home waiting lists. That is what happens now. When we send out geriatric assessment teams and they are working satisfactorily and talking to people who are on nursing home waiting lists, the very first thing that happens is that those nursing home waiting lists go down. We find on them people who should not be on them. We find people on them who do not know that there are alternatives for them in the future. We are meeting now with State governments, with consumers and with provider professional and union bodies to help to plan the expansion of the geriatric assessment program.

We are also acting on several fronts to develop greater flexibility in the type of accommodation in which care can be provided, again to get away from this obsession with nursing homes. We have discussions with State housing authorities, who in some States are providing group housing and making houses available to organisations which are looking at innovative forms of accommodation for the aged. We have funded the Abbeyfield organisation-in fact, I opened the first Abbeyfield house in Victoria recently-which is encouraging the promotion of small scale community models, in this case in two houses specially modified for the individuals involved. We are providing information and assisting service providers to look at concepts such as hostels without walls and at providing services in small community groups so that people can stay in their own homes or in independent units and retain that independence they want.

We are trying to expand the range of special services to meet the needs of special groups. There was a meeting today with the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled to develop plans for special services for the aged with special disabilities-the blind and the deaf. We have proposals to improve services to the ethnic aged, following the release of the ethnic aged working party report which I received today. We had meetings in all States with the ethnic community councils to improve the services to the ethnic aged, a problem which is becoming increasingly apparent to all of us as the percentage of ethnic people, people born outside Australia, in the over 65 age group increases in this country. We expect a threefold increase in funding this year to provide special dementia care in hostels, taking it to a level of about $1.5m, because as this population ages the biggest percentage increase in the aged will be in those over 80. It is in that group that we get the higher percentages of people with dementia or afflictions which cause them to need the special nursing care that we will have to provide.

We have to ensure that the bed provision is adequate. Several honourable senators raised the issue of needs based planning. Senator Powell, I think, expressed concern that nursing home bed numbers would be reduced or that nursing home bed provision would not be adequate. I must make this point in response to a point that was made by Senator Peter Baume in his speech in the second reading debate: There will be no reduction in nursing home beds. In fact, we will need more nursing home beds between now and the year 2010. What we do need, though, is a curb on the future growth of nursing homes so that the ratio of nursing home beds to the aged population will fall. But this will be offset by an increase in the ratio of hostel beds to the aged people in our community. Better assessment-by which I mean, necessarily, a better knowledge by elderly people and their relatives of the choices-will mean that pressure will be taken off nursing homes by avoiding inappropriate admissions to nursing homes, a problem which has been known and which has been mentioned in every report that has been put down inside and outside this Parliament in the last 15 years.

This problem of people inappropriately in nursing homes because there is nowhere else for them is a problem which has bedevilled us. Also, as Senator Reid mentioned, there is the problem of people being inappropriately in acute care hospital beds because no one else has a place for them. These people cause a blockage for the entry of elderly people into nursing homes. We have a consultancy on needs based planning which is nearing completion and which will guide future planning arrangements. The advisory committees which will be appointed will ensure proper sensitivity to consumer and other local needs in the planning process. The existing planning process tends to be a reactive one, but we need to take into account the very factors that Senator Reid talked about, such as the fact that in the Australian Capital Territory people tend to come into the area from outside to retire and be with relatives and later look for nursing homes. We want to take this into account. Unlike the existing nursing home legislation, this Bill will provide flexibility to meet actual and identifiable needs.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen made the very valid point that there is no point in our providing more hostels and providing them with adequate funding if they are going to become de facto nursing homes as the residents become more and more dependent. I agree entirely with that very real concern of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's. Hostels should not become de facto nursing homes with all the trappings of institutionalisation such as acute medical care, thereby becoming the pseudo hospitals that so many nursing homes become. Hostels are able to provide a better lifestyle for people and it is in the interests of the aged to enter them rather than nursing homes when they can no longer stay at home, because they can maintain independence and a much freer and more natural and sensible lifestyle. It may be that in the future we have to look at providing extra funding, even more than we do now, for those people who become a bit frail in nursing homes, because I think the concept of people gradually moving from one place to the other as they become more and more frail is not necessarily a good one. But the fact of the matter is that only about 7 per cent of the people in our community ever end up in a nursing home or a hostel. Most people do not go near them. There is not this transition of the whole mass of the population from home to hostel to nursing homes. There never was, there is not now and there will not be in the future.

We know that some hostels will have to change their functions now. We know that there will be, compared to now, some increased dependency of people in hostels, and we recognise this by increasing the personal care subsidies in the Bill and in fact indexing payments of this type. We need to provide services to those people in hostels to ensure that they are not dumped there, ending up in the situation about which Senator Bjelke-Petersen expressed concern.

Senator Powell welcomed the widening of options for the aged. At the same time she cautioned against reduction in expenditure on aged services. In the Budget the Government announced the strategy of redistributing the resources for care of the aged people away from nursing homes to hostel and community care and committed itself to an extra expenditure of roughly $24m in 1986-87, $80m in 1987-88 and $150m in 1989 on these initiatives. In addition, there are increases in the funding provided for ongoing services. The residential care appropriations in 1986-87 are to total something like $1.2 billion, which is an increase of about $86m or $90m, I think, on last year's expenditure.

This is, as I said, a complex and difficult area. It is one we are grappling with. It is one which I believe this legislation will enable us to grapple with much better than we could in the past. There are many myths surrounding the provision of aged people's accommodation in this country. Among them is the myth that people who go to nursing homes should go in there, stay there, die there and never come out. Hence people tend to burn their bridges. There should be a rehabilitative function in nursing homes. People do go into nursing homes and, with a bit of care and attention, improve. They have the capacity to come out and they should come out. Some poignant literature has been written on this matter in recent times. There are those who believe that we should return to the far gone days in this country when people stayed with their relatives all their lives. In fact, surveys have shown, and the paper `The Greying of Australia' has demonstrated, that there never was a time in this country's history when a majority of people in fact stayed at home with their children and their relatives. Most people did in fact lead and live independent lives and will do so in the future-even with the aging of the population and more people reaching those ages.

As Senator Reid mentioned, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had some concerns with aspects of the legislation. I, in fact, have written to the Chairman of that Committee, Senator Tate, answering, I believe, some of those concerns. Most of those concerns are taken up by Senator Peter Baume in his amendments, particularly the concerns about non- reviewable decisions and the lack of parliamentary scrutiny, which were raised by Senator Reid. I think probably those matters are best dealt with at the Committee stage, particularly when we deal with the matters raised by Senator Peter Baume in his amendments. I have been trying to speak to Senator Peter Baume since the second reading debate began today. He intimated to me that we certainly would be able to come to a compromise on some of his amendments. I am certainly happy to do that. With that in mind, I have in fact produced some Government amendments which are alternatives to the Opposition amendments which have been circulated and I will circulate them. Again they are the best dealt with in Committee, when I hope we can sort them out. I think the compromise amendments are reasonable and will be acceptable to the Opposition, as Opposition members will see in debate.

I thank honourable senators for their contributions and co-operation. This is an important area. These legislative changes are crucial to the sensible development of care for the aged in our community and I hope they will be welcomed by the majority of the community. I know that some people have done pretty well out of the existing system and are uneasy about changes. The simple fact is that it has been recognised for some years by governments of both political parties, by operators of nursing homes, and by organisations who represent the aged, that it is impossible for this community to go on in the way it has in the past. We have carefully considered the recommendations of the committees that have looked at this problem for the last decade. We have considered the representations that have been made to us by parliamentarians and by those involved in the industry and we believe that we have come up with legislation that will not be perfect, as no legislation ever is, but at least sets down the rules of the game. It is up to those of us who are playing the game at government level and industry level to ensure that the game advances and that we reach the sorts of goals we are looking for. I urge honourable senators to support the legislation. I understand from a note passed to me by the Opposition Whip that Senator Peter Baume is unavoidably delayed. Therefore, I suggest that after the second reading vote, it may be sensible to adjourn the debate until he is available.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:
That consideration in the Committee of the Whole be adjourned until a later hour this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1986-87[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1986-87APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1986-87]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was adjourned, I was part of the way through my speech on these Appropriation Bills. Perhaps I should turn my attention to the question of taxation, which has been the meat of this parliamentary session, and no doubt will continue to be. The great debate is about tax, who should pay it and at what rates. Again and again, it is proposed by the Opposition that in some way people will pay more tax at their income level than they did previously. Although it has already been said, notably by Senator Maguire in his many excellent speeches in this chamber, it is worth repeating that since this Government came into office there has been a downward trend in the rates at which tax is levied on people earning income in this community. The first was in November 1984, when those on lower incomes had their rates of income tax reduced from 30 per cent to 25 per cent. By way of the further tax cuts, that will be reduced by one per cent to 24 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The next lot of tax cuts will come into operation on 1 December this year, and again at the risk of being repetitious I point out that it is important to realise what will happen then. The maximum tax rate anybody will pay, no matter what he earns, will be 49c, whereas when this Government came into power the maximum rate was 60c, and that looked like continuing. In addition, there will be an increase in the threshold of the amount of money people can earn before they have to pay tax. That will happen from 1 December 1986, when the tax free threshold will be lifted from its present level of $4,595 to $4,890, and from 1 July 1987, when it will be lifted to $5,100. There has been a rearrangement of the tax scales so that everybody who pays income tax will now have to pay at a lower percentage rate than was the situation before this Government came into office.

Taxes have been imposed which were not imposed before. The classic is one that has common currency overseas, and that is the capital gains tax. That was applied to assets acquired after midnight on 19 September 1985. At the time it was imposed it was said that disaster would follow, and that is still being said. Well, if that disaster has happened or is about to happen, I point out that the Australian sharemarket does not seem to understand that. As was pointed out in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 November 1986-I think Senator Maguire has already dealt with this in his address-`Market hits 42nd record this year'. The following passage appears in the body of the article under that headline:

The market's breathless 86 per cent bull run over the past 18 months has some pundits such as EquitiLink executive directors Laurence Freedman and Brian Sherman saying the market is in an unstoppable phase.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—Senator Messner laughs, and that may be reasonable from where he sits. No doubt Senator Messner is expecting and projecting that disaster will happen. Predictions of disaster have continued, but it has not happened. I simply use the capital gains tax as an illustration of what I am saying. The capital gains tax was imposed over a year ago on assets acquired after 19 September 1985, and Senator Messner predicted-it was his honest belief-that disaster would follow. However, that disaster seems to have had a short life span because at the moment the market is going at an all time high.
—Is it not a fact that the capital gains tax is causing a shortage of scrip and forcing prices higher artificially?

—Senator Messner puts forward his explanation, but I am saying that the figures and the article to which I drew attention show that people still have great confidence in the market-so much so that they are buying scrip at record levels. Senator Messner says that there is another explanation for that, but if he examines the evidence of what has occurred, he will see that what I have said is correct. If Senator Messner's predictions were right, the price should have fallen. Let us take the abolition of the entertainment deduction. Again that was predicted to bring disaster and that has not happened. Somebody has to pay tax, and this point is worth repeating. In order to carry on a civilised society in which people, hopefully, get some sort of return from the society in which they live and to which they contribute, a government needs taxes. This argument is really not about whether tax should be imposed, but who should pay that tax. I quoted some figures earlier in the day which showed that many of our top companies are not paying their share of taxation. When Opposition members make protests about the tax burden being too great, whom are they defending? Are they defending the family man? Are they talking about the man who has a wife at home and two, three, four or five children? Are we talking about saving him from the incidence of taxation or are we talking about saving big companies? If one looks at the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of Wednesday, 29 October, to which I referred earlier, one sees that John Elliott's Elders-IXL paid 10.35 per cent by way of income tax in the period mentioned in the article, which was the last financial year. John Spalvins's David Jones paid 10.75 per cent and Alan Bond's Bond Corporation paid 13.95 per cent. When people talk about the heavy incidence of taxation, who do they think is affected by it? Certainly, the person who goes out into the work force, earns his money and brings it home to keep his wife and family-and much was made about this sort of person earlier in the day-is paying tax to enable the big companies to pay the sorts of rates of tax that I have just mentioned here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is right and proper that the tax burden be redistributed so that people who can properly afford to pay the tax do so. It is in that context that the much-debated fringe benefits tax has been brought in. There has been a great controversy, tumult and shouting about the fringe benefits tax. But those who have made all the fuss have never been able to detract from that fundamental point of principle that those who earn big incomes, partly in cash and partly in terms of free houses, free cars, free school fees and what have you, should be made to contribute some part of that benefit towards those who do not have such benefits and have to pay income tax at a much higher level than they otherwise would if everybody paid his tax. If everybody paid his tax, the sorts of problems that we have now would not be with us.

One answer that is put to that argument is that we must encourage enterprise. I wish to a say a few words about that. Of course enterprise must be encouraged, but it must be encouraged correctly. Again and again Opposition members seem to be saying that the people who pay the level of tax that this Government will soon reduce should not only continue to pay it, but should also take a cut in their incomes in order to make the country more competitive. If we analyse the competitiveness of this country simply in terms of wage levels, we will not get out of our present difficulties. The problems we have with the sorts of goods that we produce are not simply created by the level of our wages. That is not so in any particular case. We must make an analysis-and this has been done by our redoubted leader, Senator Button, over the years-to ascertain sensibly how our industries have been developing and whether they have been developing with the necessary initiative, drive and attention to technology. If they have not, some encouragement should be give to them and some demands made upon them.

In my closing few minutes I wish to say something about industrial relations policy. If this country is to go forward and develop as it should, if this country is to get out of its present economic problems and the social problems that may flow from them, it must do so on a co-operative basis and all sections-those who manage, those who work and those who provide capital for the industries which give us an income-should co-operate. Behind the accord, whether it be mark 1, mark 2 or the proposed mark 3, that concept reigns. This is the one way forward. That co-operation and ability to work together will see us through the present situation. Co-operation will not come if the Opposition makes continual attacks on the unions, on the Australian Council of Trade Unions and upon those organisations and instruments which represent the vast majority of workers in this country. The recipe that has been put forward in the Opposition's industrial policy-I believe that certain aspects of it were launched yesterday-is a recipe for conflict, disaster and a lowering of the incomes that we can earn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Do you mean that it is rubbish that the unions and the workers contribute or is it rubbish that your policies will attack the ACTU?
—It is rubbish that our policy is confrontationist.

—I am glad to hear that. It will be interesting to see what happens. I have no doubt that everyone in the community will be well able to see whether the Opposition's policies are confrontationist to the ACTU, the unions generally, other peak organisations and the employees of this country. Let us hope that Senator Messner is right on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Appropriation Bills and as these Bills authorise the Government's finances for the current year, it gives us an opportunity to review briefly the Government's Budget strategy and to look at it in an overall context. The first point that must be made about the Government's Budget strategy is that there is no real strategy at all. This Budget represents an attempt to kowtow to international money markets. It is based on the fact that we must screw the economy down as the only way to solve our balance of payments problem. This is a point of view that the Australian Democrats absolutely reject. There are other approaches, there are imaginative ways of solving our balance of payments problem, which is the essential problem in our community and this has not been addressed in this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy from Australia's point of view is that there has emerged a consensus between the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia. The policies of both those parties on how the economy should be managed are identical. We now have two parties in this country-the `Liborals' and the Democrats. The Democrats stand alone as a small party putting forward an alternative method of managing the economy and we are doing it against the two major parties which have combined. Time and time again we have seen during the Budget debates that the Government's Budget Bills have been passed with the support of the Liberal and National parties. The Democrats have moved constructive amendments and these have been voted down by the Liborals, by the coalition of the two major parties. Thus, the alternative is not really being put to the electorate.

I want to take this opportunity to point out that there is an alternative. It is critical that this alternative be discussed in the community and at least acted on in some important areas. There is no fundamental strategy. The first thing that we could have seen in this Budget was a long term indicative plan over a period of three or five years that would have allowed us to move the economy in a new direction. No such long term indicative plan has come forward. The plan should have stated: `We will have growth of 2 1/2 or 3 per cent. If that growth pattern is to emerge, we have to tackle the export problem. This means that we have to have a rapid development of our manufacturing industries and to buy less from overseas'.

The essential problem is that we are spending money that we do not have. Nothing has really been done to stop the haemorrhaging of Australia's hard-earned foreign exchange. What can we do about that? There are various approaches. The first thing is that there seems to be around in the community an attitude that Australia must borrow money overseas and that, if it does not do that, it cannot continue to function. This is an attitude that does not have very much substance when we look at the facts. The fact is that 90 per cent of the capital that has gone into developing Australia over the last 30 years is Australian. Unfortunately, that 90 per cent Australian capital has gone into developing our infrastructure, into building roads and building houses, and the 10 per cent foreign money has been directed at taking over our wealth-producing industries, our manufacturing industries, our farming and so on.

If we had a long term indicative plan, it would be possible over a period of five years for Australia to develop its resources without the hang-up that we must continue to borrow money. The fact is that we cannot afford to borrow money anyway. That has been the policy in the last 30 years and we are now in the position that we cannot meet the interest payments on the money that we have borrowed. If we cannot meet the interest payments on the money that we have borrowed, why do we keep borrowing? A family has to face such facts sooner or later. This country has to face the fact that our credit is running out. If our credit is running out, we have to turn around and look at our internal resources. That means that we have to spend less and earn more. We have to get a long term plan that brings those two fundamental approaches into some real economic strategy. Until we do that, I am afraid that Australia runs the risk of becoming bankrupt.

The Government has given lip-service to various ad hoc approaches. For instance, it has said that we will advertise and try to get Australians to buy more Australian produced goods. But the fact is that no legislation has been introduced to bring in a buy Australian Act that would require people in this country, and particularly governments, where possible, to buy Australian made goods. There has been no attempt to slow down the takeover of Australia's manufacturing industries. The Government's attitude is that it does not matter who owns the industries any more; it does not matter whether they are Australian owned or foreign owned. The teeth of our Foreign Investment Review Board have been taken away. It would appear that it is now only a very small step before the Foreign Investment Review Board is disbanded altogether by this Government.

It does matter who owns our industries. It does matter whether they are foreign owned or Australian owned. The fact is that about 50 per cent of our industries are now owned by overseas interests; the other 50 per cent are owned by about one per cent of the Australian population. Why does it matter that there is not a greater degree of Australian owned industry? It is for the very simple reason that it is a demonstrable fact that Australian owned industries export more; they are more export oriented; they are not inhibited by export franchises that apply to most of our overseas owned industries. Our foreign owned motor car companies are told to where they can export. They cannot look at the world as a potential market. It is also a demonstrable fact that overseas owned companies do not invest in research in this country. They like to do the research at their home bases. It can easily be shown that Australian owned industries have a much better record on research than foreign owned industries. For those two very important reasons we should be concerned about the degree of overseas ownership of our industries.

There is no doubt that we have to look to our manufacturing industries to earn foreign exchange and to solve the problem of our balance of payments. Unfortunately, very little in a concrete way has been put forward as a plan to develop rapidly our manufacturing sector. The fact is that Australia is really still a Third World economy. We still rely on exports of our wool, coal, wheat, meat and minerals. Unfortunately, these products have a very low value added. With the exception of wool, they are trying to compete on a glutted world market, often with subsidised products from our competitors. The high value added manufacturing industries should be exporting. In comparison with other Western countries, Australia has a very poor record. Only about 15 per cent of our exports presently are manufactured goods while in other Western countries the percentage is much higher and more like 80 per cent. If we are not to be a Third World country but are to be in the league of industrialised countries, we have to do something about that pretty urgently. We have to do something about it now.

This year our shortfall, our foreign debt, will probably be over $16 billion. It is a very critical shortfall. To continue on this course will only mortgage our future to pay for our current expenses. This strategy will send us broke in double quick time if it is continued. Our foreign debt is currently at $80 billion and is tipped to rise to over $100 billion by the end of next year, so the day of reckoning is not very far away.

Under the Hawke Government we have seen more deregulation and more kowtowing to foreign markets than we have ever seen before in Australia's history. There will be no future if we continue to follow the path of financial deregulation. We must manage the economy. We cannot sit back and let market forces run it for us. That is a disastrous policy which has led us into this critical position right now.

So what do we do about getting our manufacturing industries more competitive? What do we do to make our industries export oriented and to make them look at the whole world as their potential market? I said that we need a long term indicative plan. We need co-operation between government and industry, the unions and the work force, along the Japanese model. For instance, the Japanese Government takes responsibility for collecting data on potential markets all around the world and then calls the industries together and discusses those potential markets and what can be done to capture a realistic percentage of them. There is co-operation between industries and the Government. When the plan is sorted out and they have a realistic assessment of what of the potential world market the local industries can hope to capture, the Government sits down and co-operatively discusses with those industries whether they have to increase their productive capacity, if so to what degree and so on. The industries go away knowing that there is a plan and that they should spend money to develop their resources to meet that plan. For instance, they know that their Government will encourage development to a certain percentage in the automotive industry, the shipbuilding industry, the steel industry, the computer industry, the machine tool industry or whatever; there is that co-operation. We could do that but so far there has been very little progress, although the Government has at times paid some lip-service to a more co-operative approach to our manufacturing and export oriented industries. If we had this co-operative approach, the Government could be more selective in what sort of help it could give to industries which would be most effective, and what sorts of industries could be helped. It would be a rifle shot approach rather than the shotgun approach which tries to spread assistance widely through industries, many of which would not have export potential anyway.

If our industries are to be competitive, we must get co-operation between unions and between managements. There has been virtually no attempt to develop this approach in this Budget or generally by the Government. There is no doubt that the success of Japanese industry has been due simply to its ability to harness the efforts, brain power and co-operation of the entire work force in the interests of making Japanese industries as efficient as possible. In the Toyota company last year, for instance, there were no fewer than 1.9 million suggestions from the workers of that company. There were about 38 suggestions per worker per year. Of those suggestions, 90 per cent were acted on by management. A company structure that allows the whole work force to be involved in that way, as it has been in the Toyota organisation, will win every time. It is not an approach that one can introduce overnight; it takes many years to get the confidence and trust of the people in the work force that one is genuinely interested in hearing their ideas and trying to work out better ways. But it can be done. A start must be made.

Had this Government wished, it could have taken steps to encourage this to happen very quickly. There is before the Senate now an Employee Participation Bill of mine which is still awaiting debate and which lays down five criteria which, if adopted by companies, would make them eligible for government incentives. These are criteria such as the small group activity to which I have just alluded. The Bill also sets out criteria such as more employee share ownership or profit sharing techniques that allow the success of an enterprise to be shared with the whole work force. It sets out cellular organisational structures or profit centres around small groups of people, so that people can relate to each other and understand what is going on and are not just a part of an enormous hierarchy in which they are working away but do not realise where they are going.

These initiatives are vitally important if we are to get our industries as efficient as the Japanese industries and as our competitor industries in other Western countries. Unfortunately, although there has been some talk by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, and his Department about industrial democracy and employee participation, virtually no action has occurred. This matter has been going on for a long time. Why can the Government not allow a Bill which is already before the Senate to be debated, and amended if necessary, get the legislation into place, and then let the broad range of industries right across Australia strive to meet the criteria of greater employee involvement and get things moving? It would not cost the Government much money. It is estimated that the cost would be less than $50m a year-a very small price to pay for getting our industries to a state in which they are able to compete and to export.

Unemployment is a critical problem in Australia. It is a great tragedy but one which could be solved overnight if the Government wanted to do that. If we cannot offer everyone in Australia who wants to work employment for eight hours a day, surely what we should be doing is sharing the available work. There are many people, women in particular, who would be very happy to be able to work, say, three or four hours a day, rather than to work eight hours a day or not work at all. There are many people who are reaching retirement age who would like to work less than an eight-hour day. Why can we not share the available work amongst all those who wish to work?

It means, of course, that we must negotiate with the unions and get an hourly rate, I suggest, rather than penalty rates and other work practices that prohibit our getting to a stage at which we can reasonably share the available work.
