But this can be done. If we had a system of enabling companies to negotiate with the unions on a whole range of issues for their particular company, it could be done. I am sure that it will never happen and that we will never solve our work practices problem unless we do it on a company-by-company basis. We will not do it centrally through the conciliation and arbitration system.

It is my intention to introduce next week a Collective Agreements Bill, which would set up a legislative framework which would allow this direct negotiation on a broad range of issues on a company-by-company basis without cutting across the centralised wage fixing system. It would allow companies, if they so wished, voluntarily to engage in direct negotiations with the unions on a broad range of issues that affect the companies. The essential points about this Bill are that it lays down that the negotiations must be on an above-award basis-one cannot negotiate awards downwards, as I understand the Liberal Party will attempt to do if it ever gets into power-and that the trade union movement cannot be bypassed, so the negotiations must be undertaken with the trade union movement. With these two provisos, it is then possible to have collective agreements which allow broad negotiation over a whole range of issues. That is critically important.

There is also before this Parliament a youth employment Bill, which again sets out to share the available work so that the unemployed youth of this country can work at least on a permanent part time basis and get work experience without getting involved in some of the Mickey Mouse schemes that are around today, under which it is said: `Here is four weeks work. You may work for that long and then at the end of four weeks you are unemployed again, on the scrap-heap'. That is disastrous for young people, but it is what is going on. Why can we not give unemployed youth a permanent part time work role in our society so that they become part of the work force, get the work experience and can apply for full time work in the sure knowledge that they are at least employed on a permanent part time basis?

The other important problem is that of investment in our productive industries. That is not happening. Dr Mazouk, a visiting professor at Macquarie University, has put out a paper and will shortly be putting out a book on his research into the disparity between what he calls financial investment and productive investment. He has traced the trends in financial investment as opposed to productive investment over the last 30 years. It is found that it trends something like this: Back in the 1960s about 50 per cent of investment in this country went into productive areas, such as building industries, investing in machines and so forth, and 50 per cent went into financial investment such as putting money into the stock exchange and so forth. Right now, however, the overwhelming investment is going into financial investment and very little of it is going into productive investment. Why is that so? It is because there is a great incentive to invest in financial areas and a very great disincentive to invest in productive resources.

One has only to see what is going on in the stock exchange to appreciate the exact extent of the problem. Enormous amounts of money have been invested this year and in previous years-for instance, $5.5 billion in defending and attempting to take over the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd alone. There has been no additional productive capacity to BHP with that $5.5 billion investment, and not one additional job was created in spite of that enormous investment. Something like $500m was borrowed from the Bank of New South Wales by the Bond Corporation to takeover Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd. Did that increase the efficiency of Castlemaine Tooheys? I suggest not. I suggest that that money was used simply in an attempt to get a Western Australian beer into the eastern markets.

People are pursuing paper profits because that is the easiest way to make money. There is a tax incentive. If a company borrows money and uses that borrowed money to buy shares in another company, two things happen. First of all, the company can write off the interest on the money it has borrowed through all sorts of other activities it is engaged in. It does not have to write off that interest bill against the profits from the shares it buys; it can write it off against profits in every one of its other activities. Then, of course, the dividends from the shares it has bought are tax free in the hands of the company. So, in effect, there is double dipping. The company gets a deduction from the borrowings and it gets the dividends tax free. Contrast that with a company that decides to expand its productive capacity by buying a machine. What happens there? The interest on the money borrowed to buy the machine is tax deductible but the profits that that machine earns are taxable. So immediately the company that is trying to expand its productive resources is at a disadvantage compared to the company that expands through takeovers.

This has been pointed out by me and others time and time again. The Government has refused to act. I would have thought that the problem should be plain to the Government; it is certainly plain to most Australians when they sit back and see the enormous profits that have been made by the Bond Corporation, Elders-IXL Ltd and the Holmes a Court companies, when they see the enormous profits that have been made purely in share trading, in speculating on the stock market. The tragedy of the matter is that if the stock market should collapse all that money would be wasted. At least if it were invested in machinery, in productive capacity, that machinery and productivity capacity would still exist if the stock market collapsed.

So we are treading a fine line. We are running an economy that is headed for bankruptcy, without doubt, because we are continuing to borrow money. We are continuing to spend money we do not have, and this current Budget makes no attempt to change that direction. Unfortunately members of the Liberal Party are not shouting from the rooftops that there has to be a change of direction. They are simply saying we should let market forces run the economy. The Australian Labor Party says the same thing. It amazes me that some members of the Labor Party have not been able to see the great similarity between this market forces philosophy and the laissez-faire survival of the fittest philosophy that was so prevalent in the early part of the nineteenth century. It is an identical philosophy. It says, simply, that governments do not have to worry, the market can run the country and the government does not have to do anything about it. That is another way of saying we will let the survival of the fittest prevail. It took the French Revolution, the storming of the Bastille, to change that laissez-faire attitude of the nineteenth century.

I do not know how we can change the philosophy that the Liberal and Labor parties are espousing today. It is a critical problem for this country. There has to emerge somewhere concern by the Australian people as to what is going on. They must demand a change of direction. An alternative approach to economic management in this country must be debated. I cannot understand why at least some branches around the country of the once great Labor Party somewhere are not coming out and saying: `Look, why don't we debate within the Labor Party itself an alternative approach?'. Why are members of the Labor Party sitting back asking what they can do, suggesting that this is the only approach they can take, that they have to let market forces run, that they have to borrow money overseas. We have to stop borrowing money overseas. We cannot do that overnight, but we must plan to start doing it. We have to do something to reduce the flow of imports by some means or other. We could impose a luxury tax. In fact, the Australian Democrats in their alternative Budget suggested just that. We could put a tax on luxury imports such as the orange juice being imported from Brazil while our own growers are letting their oranges drop to the ground because they cannot afford to pick them. If we put, say, a six per cent tax on about one-fifth of our imports, we would raise something like $1.5 billion, which would go a long way towards reducing the Government's deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be about half that.

—It is not half that. It is a very clear and simple sum, and I think if Senator Walsh bothered to look at our alternative Budget he would see how it has been worked out. So there are alternatives. They are not being debated in this place to any degree at all simply because the two major parties have an unholy alliance that says market forces have to prevail and no alternatives will be considered. We have to have a long term plan. We have to have co-operation. We have to build our manufacturing industries rapidly. We have to look upon the whole world as a potential market. We have to do something about the degree of foreign ownership of our industries so that we can have industries that are more export and research orientated. The longer we delay making a start on a new direction the greater will be the disaster facing this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Walsh) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment on a matter which is of concern to me and I am sure is of concern to many Australians. The situation is that we have a Treasurer who is neglecting the proper operation of his Department, who is ceasing to be responsible to this Parliament, who is ceasing to answer his correspondence, and who in many ways is spending his time on other pursuits. I do not know quite what those other pursuits are, but they might be winding clocks, filling out travelling allowance forms or renovating his terrace in Sydney. Whatever it is, it is quite clear that he is not attending to the proper business of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to the fact that throughout the year Mr Keating has refused to answer questions from both the Opposition and the media on tax matters and matters relating to his portfolio. The Treasurer brushed aside Opposition questions in the other place and told members that they should put such questions on notice. However, Mr John Hodges, a Liberal member for Queensland, has had questions on notice unanswered by the Treasurer for over a year. In addition, the Treasurer has not even acknowledged, let alone answered, 11 letters I have written to him over a period of five months on behalf of constituents. The subjects on which I have written to him on behalf of constituents have included the introduction of a sales tax on flavoured milk and fruit juices. I have sent him letters on 18 July, 8 August, 8 September and 13 October. I also wrote to him on 10 July on the classification of an invalid spouse under the Income Tax Assessment Act. I wrote to him on 7 July, 29 July, 1 September and 17 October in regard to exemption from taxation for a sporting organisation, in this case a pony club. On 14 August and 23 September I wrote to the Treasurer in relation to the effect of the fringe benefits tax on a non-profit making educational institution. I also wrote to him on 2 October concerning the National Trust and its problems with the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer has seen fit to acknowledge none of those letters, which, I emphasise, were written on behalf of constituents. He has not even tried to answer them. When we take into account that he has also had a policy of never replying to Senator Michael Tate in his capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills-he has not sent one letter in response to that Committee's concerns-we have to wonder what he regards as being the due operation of his portfolio. He is responsible to this Parliament yet he seems to regard it with a total arrogance. When members of the Parliament are performing their proper duties as members of parliament they cannot get correspondence answered by the Treasurer at all, they cannot get questions taken seriously in the Parliament and they have not had questions on notice answered for more than a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is shameful. It is a shameful way of treating this Parliament. He is taking not only his travelling allowance but also his wages under false pretences. His lack of interest is extremely alarming. If he is not prepared to answer to the people of Australia for his taxation measures they have good reason to mistrust him and he should start looking for alternative employment. The Australian Constitution provides that Ministers should be responsible. If the Treasurer is not prepared to fulfil his constitutional duties he should go.
—That will be after the next election.
—As Senator Watson has said, he will go after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.31 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has the Government taken in respect to recommendation Number 1 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking that the recommendations of the Williams Commission in favour of co-operating to pool resources and ending the fragmented approach of law enforcement to organised crime, particularly drug trafficking, should be implemented.
(2) What negotiations has the Commonwealth Government had with the various State Governments concerning the implementation of a uniform drug trafficking act.
(3) When will a uniform drug trafficking act be enacted throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is satisfied that the degree of co-operation between law enforcement agencies has greatly improved since the recommendations were made.

(2) In the light of action already taken by jurisdictions to amend their drug legislation, the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy resolved at its meeting in May 1986 that the Secretariat to the Standing Committee of Officials identify those key areas of drug control legislation in which a uniform approach is most desirable and initiate discussions with all jurisdictions on the achievement of a uniform approach in those areas. This is being pursued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government raised the need for State action through the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy following its response to recommendation 68 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking concerning uniform Commonwealth and State laws for the forfeiture of property and the payment of financial penalties by drug offenders where the Government stated: ``existing Commonwealth legislation substantially provides for the penalties and remedies proposed and the Government will raise the need for State action through the Ministerial Committee on Drug Strategy''; if not, why not.
(2) When will it be raised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Special Premiers' Conference on Drugs (held in Canberra on 2 April 1985) agreed in principle that legislation be introduced in each jurisdiction to enable for forfeiture and confiscation of assets of convicted drug dealers and noted that the question would be further considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG).

In October 1985 at the request of SCAG, the Commonwealth prepared and circulated to the States a preliminary draft model Bill providing for the imposition of a pecuniary penalty (representing the benefits an offender has derived from serious criminal conduct) as well as the forfeiture of property used in or obtained as a result of the commission of an offence.

In November 1985 New South Wales enacted legislation along the lines of the Commonwealth Model Bill. South Australia has also enacted legislation and other States have indicated that they are about to follow.

The States have continued to be interested in the development of the model legislation as it was agreed that there should be provisions for the reciprocal enforcement of forfeiture and pre-trial restraining orders in other jurisdictions. Without such provisions State legislation would be ineffective where an offender's forfeitable assets are located in another jurisdiction. A reciprocal enforcement scheme was finally agreed to by SCAG on 25 September 1986.

On 26 September 1986 the Commonwealth Government announced that it would be introducing comprehensive legislation to attack the proceeds of crime. This legislation will provide for tougher forfeiture provisions than were contemplated in other jurisdictions where persons had been convicted of drug trafficking, organised fraud and money laundering. In these cases all the offender's assets will be liable to automatic forfeiture at the expiration of 6 months after conviction, subject to the offender establishing that they were not acquired as a result of criminal activity.

(2) The matter is currently being monitored by the Ministerial Council of Drug Strategy who have responsibility for the follow-up action on the matters agreed to at the Special Premiers' Conference on Drugs, and, as has been indicated, the matter has been discussed in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the legislation been drafted following the Government's response to recommendation 10 014 of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union concerning the requirement that the Commonwealth and State Governments enact legislation similar to the USA's Racketeer and Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Statute providing for uniform legislation for the forfeiture of assets, and when will it be introduced into Federal and State Parliaments.
(2) Why has there been such delay in carrying out this recommendation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 26 September 1986 the Government announced that it will be introducing a comprehensive legislative package to attack the proceeds of crime. The legislation approved by the Government would:
* permit, after conviction, the forfeiture of property used in, or obtained as a result of the commission of an indictable offence against the law of the Commonwealth;
* require for more serious offences the automatic forfeiture of the offenders assets 6 months after conviction (subject to the offender establishing that they were legitimately acquired);
* permit, prior to conviction the tracing and freezing of property that may be subject to forfeiture;
* create new offences of ``money laundering'' (the process by which profits of crimes are disguised in order to make them appear legitimate);
* require keeping of certain financial records by financial institutions and permit subject to safeguards, access to such records; and
* provide for proper identification of all persons and corporations opening bank accounts.

The Government also indicated that it was favourably disposed to the introduction of legislation requiring financial institutions to report currency transactions above a specified amount. This may be required for the effective enforcement of these new measures.

The Government has agreed to examine the practicalities of introducing such a scheme. The Attorney-General, the Special Minister of State and the Treasurer, will be reporting back to the Government on this matter by November 1986-after further consultation, including talks with financial institutions.

It should be noted that most States and the Commonwealth already have some form of forfeiture legislation in relation to assets derived from the commission of serious drug offences. New South Wales and South Australia have also recently enacted legislation providing for the forfeiture of assets derived from criminal conduct in general.

(2) This matter has been the subject of consideration not only by the Commonwealth Government but also by the Australian Police Ministers Council and subsequently the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG). As SCAG agreed in principle that uniform legislation on this subject should be introduced in each jurisdiction the proposals have required full consultation with the States and the Northern Territory. The new Commonwealth legislation will go much further than the State legislation and the complex nature of the issues raised by the proposal required lengthy and detailed consideration (including consideration of the US Racketeer Influence and Corrupt Organisations Statute, as well as similar legislation in other countries).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What counter measures are being considered, in addition to improved intelligence gathering, in view of the Special Minister of State's recent statement on the cocaine problem, and his recognition that such a problem does exist.

(2) What firm proposals are being considered on ``the development of intelligence on overseas aspects'', ``expansion of liaison officer positions'', and ``increased participation in conferences, training programs and liaison visits''.

(3) What additional staff and other resources will be provided to the Australian Federal Police so that the maximum value can be gained from the anticipated improvement in intelligence gathering, given the Minister's statement and the already well documented resource deficiencies in the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In view of the current situation regarding cocaine abuse in Australia, emphasis is being placed on strengthening intelligence gathering arrangements, including by the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Customs Service.

In addition both the Australian Police Ministers Council and the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy are examining the problem from a national perspective, the latter covering both demand and supply aspects.

(2) On 3 June 1986 I advised the House of Representatives that an additional Australian Federal Police liaison officer was being stationed in Honolulu which is viewed as a potential transhipment point for cocaine en route to Australia. In addition to this initiative, I am advised that a micro-computer based network is being established between Customs administrations within the Pacific Base Region to identify and monitor the movement of small craft, in particular, yachts and light aircraft. Two senior officers (from the Federal Police and Customs Service respectively) also recently attended the Inter-regional Heads of Narcotic Law Enforcement Agencies meeting in Vienna. I understand that the meeting was successful in furthering at the international level, co-operation between law enforcement agencies.

(3) In October 1985 I directed (pursuant to Section 13(2) of the AFP Act) that investigation of drug offences is to be the first priority for the AFP nationally. I am advised that on the basis of current planning by the AFP and with increased resources being made available by the Government, AFP police staff directly devoted to drugs investigations will have increased by around 70 per cent by 1987/88 with a major increase in supporting intelligence staff.
The Federal Government is also providing an additional $5.5m over two years to the Australian Customs Service as part of its law enforcement contribution to the national campaign against drug abuse.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Would the transition period to self-government of some African nations have improved if adequate education of their future leaders had taken place before the change to self-government.
(2) Is it not advisable to educate black South Africans, to prepare them for fair representation, given the eventual fall of apartheid in South Africa.
(3) Will the Government make available scholarships to enable South African students to study in the vocational areas which their country will need in the future.
(4) Would these students then be qualified to work in other African countries and gain the experience they will need to apply in their own country one day, so that this training is not wasted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This is a hypothetical question. I am not in a position to speculate on the adequacy of the education received by past or present African leaders nor on the effect of that education on the transition period to self-government.

(3) The Government currently provides educational assistance to black South Africans and Namibians through programs administered by the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. The Australian Embassy in Pretoria administers scholarships for black South Africans to study in their own country. Scholarships are also available for Namibian and black South African refugees to study in Australia and non government organisations are funded by ADAB to arrange specialised training, work experience programs and trade union training in Australia.
The Budget provides for a new $5m assistance program for Southern Africa over a five year period to 1990. Further details would be available from the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

(4) Australian vocational qualifications are of a high standard and are recognised and respected in countries where they are known. Where they are not known, the skills demonstrated by those holding them should commend them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have some graziers in Queensland who have been issued with pest destruction permits been using unacceptable and unorthodox methods in the killing of kangaroos, such as leaving gunshot wounded kangaroos to die a slow death, together with allegations of slow acting poisons being introduced to water holes and along boundary fences endangering all animal and bird life in the area.
(2) Will the Minister undertake an investigation of these serious allegations with a view to ensuring that such practices are discounted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of any evidence confirming that such practices are being carried out in Queensland. The Director of the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service (QNPWS) Dr G. Saunders, has commented in relation to this question that his Service does all it can to ensure that kangaroos are taken by acceptable methods only. For instance I understand that a planned ``kangaroo drive'' near Goondiwindi was prevented recently by Queensland police.

(2) While responsibility for the methods used to kill kangaroos in Queensland rests with the QNPWS which can specify the legal manner by which kangaroos may be destroyed and the Commonwealth has no power to intervene directly in such matters, the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers, which is composed of all Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers responsible for wildlife, including the Queensland Minister, endorsed in May 1985 a Code of Practice for the Humane Shooting of Kangaroos. This Code specifies the requirements for humane shooting of kangaroos.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 8 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the intent of Section 24 (1) (a) (b) (c) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act to lay down the qualifications for TPI pensions.
(2) Is Section 24 (2) (b) intended to apply beneficially to veterans under the age of 65 years.

(3) Is the attitude taken by the Commission Review Board and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that if a veteran qualifies under Section 24 (2) (b) he must also qualify under Section 24 (1) (a) (b) (c) and Section 24 (2) (i) (ii) the correct interpretation; if so, does this negate entirely the beneficial effect of Section 24 (2) (b).
(4) If the answer to (3) and (4) is ``Yes'' will the Government be amending the Veterans' Entitlements Act to remedy this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In part, yes. Sub-section 24 (3) provides for the grant of special (T & PI) rate of pension where a Veteran has been blinded in both eyes as a result of war-caused injury or disease.

(3) Decisions of the Repatriation Commission, the Veterans' Review Board and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal indicate that a Veteran must meet the criteria set out in paragraph 24 (1) (a) (b) and (c) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 in order to qualify for pension at the special (T & PI) rate. Where a Veteran who is under 65 years of age satisfies the test set out in paragraph 24 (2) (b), he is regarded as having met that part of the T & PI criteria which is provided for by paragraph 24 (1) (c).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 8 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date was the disease ``potato cyst nematode'' first identified in Western Australia (WA).
(2) What was the origin of the seed.
(3) What quarantine arrangements will be undertaken to minimise the potential spread.
(4) What restrictions to the movement of tubers within WA and interstate have been made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Potato cyst nematode was positively identified in Western Australia on 30 September, 1986.
(2) The seed was from a supplier in the Albany area approved by the Department of Agriculture. There is no reason to believe that the pest was introduced into the infested areas on seed.

(3) Immediate quarantine action by Western Australia following the discovery of PCN involved the imposition of restrictions on the movement of produce and machinery from the affected areas. Following that, the Department of Agriculture initiated intensive surveys of all potato growing areas in the State. These are continuing. Further action is under consideration by the Standing Committee on Agriculture's Consultative Committee on Insect Pests, Weeds and Plant Diseases which met in a telephone hook-up on 30 September and again on 14 October.

(4) Western Australia has restricted the movement of potatoes from the affected areas so that all produce must be sent for processing. All potatoes grown in the metropolitan areas not affected by the pest are to be washed and limited in distribution to areas where potatoes are not grown. Other States, with the exception of Tasmania have or are preparing proclamations/orders to ban the import of potatoes from Western Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2626) Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked me, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question without notice on figures on employment growth during the Government's first three years in office and the basis of those figures in terms of full and part-time employment. The honourable senator also sought an explanation of the apparent disparity between the number of persons receiving unemployment benefit and the number seeking employment. I undertook to direct the question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations who has provided the following response:

ANSWER.PARA: Between April 1983 and April 1986 employment (seasonally adjusted) in Australia increased by 669,400 according to the Labour Force Survey. This figure comprises net growth of 460,600 in full-time employment and 208,800 in part-time employment. Some 69 percent of the employment growth was therefore full-time.

The latest figures available on unemployment benefit (UB) recipients are for the week ending 29 August 1986 when there were 573,735 persons receiving UB. This compared with 595,600 persons unemployed and actively seeking employment as estimated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), for the month of August 1986. Neither of these figures are seasonally adjusted.

There are significant and fundamental differences between figures on unemployment, which are derived by the ABS from a population survey, and those on UB which are an administrative series. For example, persons in part-time or casual employment may retain eligibility for some UB payment under current testing provisions. Such persons would be classified by the ABS as employed, provided they worked one hour or more in the survey week. On the other hand, some unemployed persons are ineligible for UB for such reasons as spouse income, age or attendance at full-time education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 August 1986 (Hansard, page 352), Senator Crowley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice relating to changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: Pamphlets explaining the new scheme will be available from pharmacies from late October.
The honourable senator asked whether the arrangements which will apply to oral contraceptives from 1 November 1986 might apply to other drugs as well.
The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) regularly reviews the listing of drugs as pharmaceutical benefits, including the maximum quantities and repeats which apply.

Whereas it has been usual to list drugs used to treat chronic conditions to enable one month's supply per prescription plus two repeats, for chronic conditions which do not require frequent clinical review the PBAC often now recommends further repeats to enable up to six months' supply to be obtained between visits for clinical reassessment.
For example, most items for use in the treatment of hypertension and arrhythmias now have five repeats available as do many of the anti-asthmatic drugs listed.
Other than this, there is no proposal at present for a general increase in benefit availability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Controller of Fuels is not a Statutory Authority but an officer of the Territories Department appointed and exercising the functions of a statutory office holder under the Fuels Control Ordinance 1979 of the ACT. The Controller of Fuels controls the use of fuel in the ACT in times of fuel shortage.
(2) Nil. Departmental Officers are used to carry out the directions of the Controller of Fuels.
(5) The Controller of Fuels is not a Statutory Authority.

(1) The Collector of Maintenance is not a statutory authority but an officer of the Attorney-General's Department appointed and exercising the functions of a statutory office holder under the Maintenance Ordinance of the ACT. The Collector of Maintenance collects fees and other payments; on request, initiates local and interstate enforcement proceedings for non-compliance with maintenance orders; on request, receives and disburses maintenance payments; and on request, arranges for the service and execution of process under the Maintenance Ordinance of the ACT and the Family Law Act. These payments are generally for the maintenance of the children.
(4) There is no private sector subsidy; yearly cost (including 85% overhead costs) is estimated at $122,000.

(5) The Collector of Maintenance is not a statutory authority. However details of the Collector of Maintenance are included in the annual report for the Attorney-General's Department under Magistrates Courts Branch activities.
(c) Public Baths Inspectors and (d) Trespassing Inspectors.

(1) There is no Statutory Authority established under the ACT legislation which is titled ``Public Baths Inspectors'' or ``Trespassing Inspectors''. However, section 7 (1) of the Public Baths and Public Bathing Ordinance 1956 (``the Public Baths Ordinance'') provides that the Minister (for Territories) may appoint such persons as he thinks fit for the purposes of the Ordinance. Sections 10, 11, 16, 20, 22, 33 and 35 of the Public Baths Ordinance confer various powers and functions on Public Baths Inspectors. Sections 3a of the Trespass on Commonwealth Lands Ordinance 1932 is in terms similar to section 7 (1) of the Public Baths Ordinance. Various powers and functions are conferred on persons who are appointed as inspectors under the Trespass Ordinance by sections 3C, 8, 8A and 9 of that Ordinance.

(2) The duties of Public Baths Inspectors and Inspectors under the Trespass Ordinance are carried out by officers of the ACT Health Authority and Department of Territories respectively in the course of other duties.
(5) The Public Baths and Trespassing Inspectors are not Statutory Authorities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs: Overseas Travel

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the nature of the ``Nuclear Policy Mission'' on which SES officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs visited Japan, Sweden, Belgium, the Netherlands, Ireland and Germany.
(2) What were the (a) names; (b) qualifications; and (c) employment areas within the Department of the officers involved.
(3) Have there been any other overseas trips by officers of the Department in connection with this matter; if so, in each case (a) when; (b) by whom; and (c) to which countries.
(4) What were the individuals, Government and non-Government agencies, authorities or institutions visited by officers of the Department in connection with this matter in each case.
(5) What was the nature of the ``Policy Planning Talks'' in Japan, Hong Kong and Indonesia to which the Department sent 3 officers.
(6) What were the (a) names; (b) qualifications; and (c) employment areas within the Department of the officers involved.
(7) What was the purpose of the ``Chemical Weapons Convention'' to which an SES officer was sent.
(8) What was the name, qualifications and employment area within the Department of the officer concerned.
(9) Were nations other than Australia and the USA involved; if so, which nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The nuclear policy mission conducted in February-March 1985 comprised two SES officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs and one officer from the Department of Trade.
The two Foreign Affairs officers visited Japan, Denmark, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Ireland and the Federal Republic of Germany. One officer also visited France, Italy and Greece.

The mission was authorised at this time so as to sensitise member States of the European Community as well as the European Commission to Australian interests in issues involving the NPT and the forthcoming third NPT Review Conference, and in their decision-making relating to the proposed enlargement of the European Community to include Spain (a non-NPT member) and Portugal (a NPT member). The timing of the Mission was determined by the timing of EC enlargement set for 1 January 1986 and of the third NPT Review Conference (27 August-21 September 1985). Inclusion of Tokyo on the itinerary facilitated consultations on NPT-related matters with the Japanese. It also provided an opportunity for bilateral consultations under the Australia/Japan safeguards agreement. In the case of the visits to the Netherlands and Italy, the mission was a response to outstanding requests for consultations among officials on issues concerning the NPT.
(2) (a) and (c) Mr D. A. Townsend, the then Assistant Secretary Nuclear Policy Branch, Department of Foreign Affairs. Mr G. A. Brennan, Legal Adviser, Department of Foreign Affairs.

(b) Mr Townsend has been a Foreign Affairs officer since 1964 and has served in a number of posts. At the time of the nuclear policy mission he had been in charge of branches dealing with nuclear policy and safeguards matters for approximately six years.

Mr Brennan has been the Department's Legal Adviser since 1980. He was Assistant Legal Adviser from 1978 to 1980. He has since 1978 been associated with the negotiation and implementation of Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements and also with the provision of legal advice in respect of Australia's non-proliferation policies and associated international legal obligations.

(3) There have been no other visits abroad by officers of the Department with the specific purpose of pursuing the matters referred to under (1) above. Australian delegations did participate in the three meetings of the Preparatory Committee for the Third NPT Review Conference and at the Conference itself. I presented a full report on the Conference to the Parliament last year. I would point out also that for many years successive Australian Governments have pursued both bilaterally and multilaterally Australia's interest in preventing the further proliferation of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. This Government has done so with particular vigour.

(4) During the nuclear policy mission referred to in the question Departmental officers met relevant officials of the organisations set out below. I do not consider it appropriate to provide the names of individuals concerned in foreign Government Ministries or authorities.
Japan-Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of International Trade and Industry, Science and Technology Agency, Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation.
Denmark-Minister of Foreign Affairs, Danish Commission on Security and Disarmament Affairs.
Belgium-Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Commission of the European Communities, Directorate-General of Energy, Euratom Safeguards Directorate, Euratom Supply Agency.
Luxembourg-Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Public Health.
Federal Republic of Germany-Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Research and Technology.

Italy-Ministry of Foreign Affairs, European Political Committee working groups on Disarmament and Non-Proliferation (during Italian Presidency of the EC), Italian Commission for Nuclear and Alternative Energy Sources.
(5) and (6) Three officers travelled from Australia to Japan to take part in the 9th Meeting of Japan-Australia Policy Planning talks, held on 28 and 29 March 1985 in Tokyo. The officers were:

Mr D. M. Sadleir, the then First Assistant Secretary, Executive, Policy Planning and Defence Division, Department of Foreign Affairs (an SES officer with extensive service in Canberra and overseas, including Japan, the United States and the Soviet Union, and whose responsibilities in his position as Division Head included supervision of the Policy Planning Unit).

Mr R. E. Little, the then Head of the Policy Planning Unit, Department of Foreign Affairs (a Foreign Affairs Officer Class 4, equivalent to a CAC 11. Mr Little is a senior officer with previous posting experience in Japan, Laos, Bangladesh, Ireland, China and Jamaica.)

Dr R. W. Rigby, then a staff member of the Policy Planning Unit, Department of Foreign Affairs (a Foreign Affairs Officer Class 2, equivalent to a CAC 7. Dr Rigby previously served in Japan and China). Both Mr Little and Dr Rigby are Japanese speakers.

Also taking part in the talks in Tokyo were the then Australian Ambassador to Japan, Sir Neil Currie; the Minister at the Australian Embassy, Mr C. R. Jones; and the Counsellor at the Australian Embassy, Mr C. G. S. Willis.

The Japanese delegation at the talks was led by the Director-General of the Information Analysis, Research and Planning Bureau in the Japanese Ministry of Fo-reign Affairs. Also taking part on the Japanese side were staff members of this Bureau and of other Bureaux in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The purpose of these talks, the ninth in a series, was to have a wide-ranging exchange of views with senior Japanese officials on political and economic questions of common interest. The main topics addressed at the talks included East-West relations, the South Pacific, China, South-East Asia, Pacific economic cooperation, the Bonn Economic Summit, the Indian Ocean, and the global multilateral system. The talks contributed usefully to our understanding of Japanese views on these matters.
Meetings also were held with the National Institute for Research Advancement; the Nomura Research Institute; and the Japanese Institute of International Affairs.

Mr Sadleir travelled directly between Australia and Japan, while Mr Little and Dr Rigby on the return journey visited Jakarta for two days of talks with Indonesian counterparts, from 31 March to 2 April. They saw the Director-General of the Policy Research and Development Agency in the Indonesian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. They also saw a senior member of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies. Issues addressed in these discussions included the South Pacific, China and South East Asia, developments in Indonesia and the region, Pacific economic cooperation, and the global multilateral system.
Hong Kong was a transit stop and no policy planning talks were held there.

(7) Dr Peter Dunn of the Defence Department's Materials Research Laboratories, visited the United States in the latter half of February 1985 for bilateral discussions with United States officials on issues concerned with the verification of compliance with a chemical weapons convention (i.e., the convention outlawing chemical weapons currently under negotiation in the Conference on Disarmament), with particular focus on the issues concerned with verifying allegations of use of chemical weapons.

(8) Dr Peter Dunn, Superintendent, Organic Chemistry Division, Materials Research Laboratories (MRL), Maribyrnong. He has been involved in defence science research continuously since joining MRL (then the Defence Standards Laboratories) in 1951.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 10 July 1986:

(3) When were any such assessments made.
(4) When was the decision to remove the facility made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has endorsed development by the Department of Aviation of an Airways Plan designed to increase efficiency and productivity within the Airways System while maintaining or improving levels of air safety and continuing to provide adequate air traffic services. A key element of this plan is the consolidation of air traffic services into fewer, larger centres where staff resources may be used more efficiently. Modern communications technology allows a more centralised system than was feasible in earlier years. It is in this context that the operational functions of the Alice Springs OCU/RSC are to be transferred to the Adelaide Operational Control and Rescue Co-ordination Centre (OCC/RCC).

(2) A thorough examination of operational requirements was made prior to the closure decision. This examination confirmed that Adelaide could assume the existing Alice Springs' operational control and search and rescue responsibilities without affecting air safety in Alice Springs area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Treasurer explain why the imposition of a 20 per cent sales tax imposed on certain aluminium products of industrial and commercial use as of 19 May 1986 was not preceded by notification of retailers that they were obliged to add this tax to their charges.
(2) Will the Treasurer explain why this new tax was levied on this particular group of aluminium products.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Sub-item 82a (1) in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Act exempts from sales tax piping or tubing of a kind used exclusively, or primarily and principally, in the construction or repair of, and wrought into, or attached to, so as to form part of, buildings, fixtures, structures or other works. The Commissioner of Taxation has informed me that a review of the operation of the sub-item was recently conducted for the purpose of issuing guidelines on the extent to which piping and tubing are exempt from sales tax under the sub-item.

On the completion of the review, advice on the sales tax classification of piping and tubing products was issued to all sales taxpayers who were either known to be in the business of marketing piping or tubing products or could be identified as likely to be engaged in that business. As some taxpayers have been treating products as exempt from sales tax which, following the review, were considered to be taxable, liability to tax was made effective from a future date in order to give them time to adjust their accounting systems and prices. The date fixed was 19 May 1986.

As sales tax is a wholesale tax, liability for sales tax generally falls on manufacturers and wholesalers and not on retailers. Accordingly, it was not necessary to notify retailers of the rulings except where they had a sales tax liability, i.e. manufacturing retailers and retailers making wholesale sales. Retailers who were identified as affected by the rulings were notified by the Taxation Office.

(2) There has been no sales tax on aluminium products. As explained in the answer to the first question, some taxpayers who had been treating taxable piping as exempt were advised of the correct classification and required to account for tax on sales of such products from 19 May 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 February 1986 (Hansard, page 169) Senator Siddons asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning Australia's foreign debt. As part of my answer I undertook to ask the Treasurer whether consideration had been given to controlling and regulating the inflow and outflow of capital. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Prior to floating the Australian dollar in December 1984, as part of the exchange rate system, there was an extensive array of exchange controls directed primarily towards controlling capital flows. These controls were almost completely removed concurrently with the Government's decision to float the Australian dollar. That decision both reflected, and was a response to, the increasing integration of the Australian and international capital markets.

Re-introduction of exchange controls would be inconsistent with the Government's deregulatory initiatives in the financial sector and would have significant costs, both administratively for authorities and business, and in terms of inefficiencies in the operation of international capital flows.

The pre-float experience of capital controls pointed up the limitations of exchange controls in controlling large undesirable capital movements. Moreover capital controls were part of the apparatus whereby the former Government maintained an overvalued exchange rate which has had such detrimental effects on Australian industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 March 1986 (Hansard, page 1233) Senator Siddons asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, a question without notice concerning technical aspects of company takeovers. Senator Button undertook to seek advice from the Treasurer, who has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The issues raised by Senator Siddons have now been addressed in depth in Treasury Economic Paper No. 12 entitled ``Some Economic Implications of Takeovers''. The main points flowing from that analysis are presented below.

The basic purpose of section 46 is to ensure that dividends paid out of income on which company tax may already have been paid once are not subject to further taxation as they pass through the corporate chain before being taxed again (under the classical system) in the hands of the individual shareholder.

High Court decisions between 1931 and 1953 have resulted in a situation where virtually no interest deductions need be subtracted from dividends in calculating the section 46 rebate unless they exclusively relate to the earning of dividends. Because some legal uncertainty may still exist on that point, arrangements such as those alluded to by Senator Siddons appear to have been used by some companies in acquiring shares in other companies in order to avoid the risk of interest expenses having to be deducted from the share dividends received in calculating the section 46 rebate on those dividends.

The question whether the section 46 rebate should be calculated on the basis of gross dividends received or net dividends after the deduction of associated interest expenses has been raised in connection with corporate takeover issues. The view expressed in Treasury Economic Paper No. 12 is that neither the history of sections 46 and 50, nor an in-principal analysis of how they ought to operate, compels the conclusion that they should work along the lines suggested in the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many nuclear reactors without containment buildings is the Department of Resources and Energy aware of.
(2) In which countries are they to be found.
(3) Are any special steps being taken to internationally monitor ageing nuclear reactors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Detailed specifications of the various types of nuclear reactors are not held by my Department. However, I note that each reactor type has different inherent characteristics, and hence requires different design features and safety systems to ensure safe operation under all foreseeable conditions. A containment structure is only one of the engineered safety systems which may be relevant to a particular reactor. Thus a realistic comparison of the overall safety levels of different reactor types would require a detailed study of many complex issues, and cannot be based on a consideration of containment provisions alone.
(3) While I am not aware of any special steps being taken to internationally monitor aging nuclear reactors, I note that reactor safety is not necessarily related to the age of a reactor.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Taxation Office currently issuing assessments to taxpayers, not allowing credits for prescribed payments tax already paid by the taxpayers.
(2) Does provisional tax liability arising out of these assessments take account of those credits for prescribed payments tax.
(3) Are these assessments due and payable, in total, prior to the end of the financial year.
(4) Have any of these assessments been issued as long as 4 months after the returns have been lodged with the Taxation Office.

(5) Is the Taxation Office empowered to proceed with legal action and impose penalties on the full amount stated as owing, in the notices of assessment, even though those notices of assessment, in fact, result in the taxpayers being triple taxed when the provisions tax effect is considered.
(6) Is interest on outstanding tax charged at 20 per cent without a tax deduction.
(7) Will any subsequent refunds to the taxpayer bear interest at 14 per cent, and will any such interest be taxable.
(8) Are such income tax assessments being used to inflate estimates of tax collections and/or outstanding tax liabilities for the year ended 30 June 1986.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that some assessments have issued which do not include an amount of credit equal to the amount due to the taxpayer. There are a number of reasons for this, some to do with payer and payee error and omission, others arising from administrative oversight.

The Commissioner of Taxation advised that a range of additional measures are being introduced to streamline the processing of returns with prescribed payment credit. These measures should also significantly reduce the number of disputes about the amount of prescribed payment credit allowed in assessments.
(2) The Commissioner advised that the credit which has been allowed in the taxpayer's assessment is taken into account when calculating provisional tax.

(3) The Commissioner has advised that assessments are due and payable on the date specified in the notice of assessment or on the 30th day after service of the notice on the taxpayer, whichever is the later. Thus, normally, if an assessment issues more that 30 days before the end of June, that assessment will be due for payment before the end of the financial year.
(4) The Commissioner acknowledges that some assessments have issued more than 4 months after the returns were lodged. These returns represent the most difficult ``mismatch'' cases.

(5) The Taxation Office is empowered to proceed with legal action to recover outstanding tax whether a dispute exists or not. Additional tax on amounts unpaid accrues at the rate of 20% per annum from the date on which the tax became due and payable. The Commissioner assures me that where a discrepancy as to the amount of prescribed payment credit is resolved in the taxpayer's favour, the taxpayer is not required to bear any penalty in relation to the amount involved in the discrepancy. Where an assessment is the subject of a genuine dispute, an extension of time for payment of portion of the amount of tax in dispute is generally allowed.

(6) Yes. However, the Commissioner is authorised to remit the additional tax, or part of the additional tax, in limited circumstances. The additional tax is not allowable as a deduction against assessable income.

(7) A taxpayer who successfully objects or appeals against an assessment is entitled to interest on any resultant refund of tax overpaid. No interest is payable on refunds resulting from original assessments. The current interest rate is 14.026%, and any amount of interest paid or applied under the relevant provisions is itself assessable income.

(8) No. The Commissioner has assured me that the estimates in respect of tax collections and outstanding tax liabilities represent an accurate and realistic estimate of the collections and liabilities for the year ended 30 June 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1986 (Hansard, page 701) Senator Cook asked me, as Minister representing the Special Minister of State, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Given that an examination of the compulsory returns from political parties since the 1984 Federal election does not disclose any donations from Mr Ric New or his Midland Brick Co. Pty Ltd to the Western Australian Branch of the Liberal Party of Australia, would the Minister check to see that those returns have been properly filed and donations properly disclosed.
The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was amended in 1984 to require all political parties to disclose after an election all donations of $1000 or more received since the last election, apart from those which were made on the condition that they be used for a purpose other than a purpose related to an election, and which were so used.

Following the 1984 election the Australian Electoral Commission had proposed to audit a sample of parties' financial records in order to establish how well parties had understood, and fulfilled, their obligations under the new funding and disclosure provisions. The Opposition parties, however, challenged the legality of the proposed audit.

The proposed audit was subsequently abandoned by the Electoral Commission in the light of legal advice it received that there is no power under the Electoral Act to require parties to produce records in order to establish whether the provisions requiring disclosure of donations have been complied with.
In the absence of that power I am unable to advise whether or not donations have been received by the Western Australian Branch of the Liberal Party which should have been disclosed.
I have drawn the legal advice to the attention of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which is currently examining the operation of the 1984 amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Japanese Government Power Nuclear Corporation (PNC) continuing a search for uranium mineralisation in the Officer Basin area in Western Australia.
(2) Has the uranium search led miners right up to and over the borders of the Cundeelee Mission Reserve, where the Wankatja people settled after fleeing the Maralinga atomic tests in the 1950s.
(3) Have the Wankatja people now been moved by the Government to Coonana, ostensibly to overcome the chronic water supply problem, despite the fact that water is of little better quality at Coonana.
(4) Was the issuing of Mining Licence M28/15 on 15 February 1985 to PNC in direct contravention of Federal Australian Labor Party Policy Clause 58.
(5) Has the PNC dug an `exploration pit' 200 ft x 100 ft x 40 ft deep and shipped ore to Japan from Fremantle.
(6) Has any uranium been exported from the exploration operation in the Officer Basin to Japan or anywhere else, between November 1983 and July 1986.
(7) If uranium has been exported between the dates given in (6) above, then-
(a) on what dates was it exported;
(b) how much was exported;
(c) in what form was it exported;
(d) through which ports; and
(e) for what purpose was it to be used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Western Australian Mines Department confirms that there has been no uranium exploration or mining on the Cundeelee Reserve, although the company has identified a uranium deposit approximately 40 kilometres north of the Reserve. PNC has not sought permission to enter the Reserve at any stage.

(3) The Aboriginal Development Commission, after full consultation and with the agreement of the community, purchased the Coonana pastoral lease for the Upurl Upurlila Ngurratja Community in 1983 because the Cundeelee area had proven incapable of sustaining a water supply for the community.

Since then, all members of the community of approximately 360 people have elected to move to Coonana. All the movements have been completely voluntary, and occurred progressively as small groups made their own decision.
It is hoped that an adequate water supply can be progressively developed at Coonana which has better capabilities for surface catchments.

The chemical quality of water at both Cundeelee and Coonana is excellent, and the bacteriological quality is slightly better at Coonana owing to the community not camping in the catchment area. Both sites are bacteriologically treated, although Cundeelee has been unoccupied since January 1986.

However, there has been no change to the Federal Government's policy, which permits exports of uranium from only the Ranger, Nabarlek, and Olympic Dam projects. The PNC operation is at the exploration stage and it is unlikely to proceed to the development stage in circumstances where it is unable to obtain export permits.

(5) and (6) PNC operations are authorised by the Western Australian Government and information on exploration activities should be obtained from Western Australia. There have been no shipments of uranium from PNC's Officer Basin (Mulga Rock) prospect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What evidence is available that pilots who were granted dispensations in licencing requirements prior to the policy change in mid-1974, are in any way less safe or less competent to fly in Australia than locally trained pilots.

(2) When, under what circumstances, and for what specific reasons did the Department of Aviation decide to revoke their longstanding practice of accepting the US Airline Transport Pilot Licence as an equivalent to the Australian SCPL, without the need for additional requirements.
(3) Where there any significant precedents for such action which could be definitely proven to have had a significant adverse effect on Australian air safety.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My department has no information regarding the relative safety or competence of individual pilots who have been issued with Australian pilot licences on the basis of foreign qualifications.

(2) The change of policy followed a review which showed that the written examinations for issue of the ATR are significantly less searching than Australian SCPL examinations. However it is recognised that practical commercial operating experience in the USA could lead to an equivalent standard through the influence of airline training organisations. Since 19 June 1975 the US Air Transport Rating (ATR) has not been recognised as the equivalent of the Australian Senior Commercial Pilot Licence unless the holder of the ATR has made significant use of the qualification. ``Significant Use'' means at least 200 hours pilot in command on heavy aircraft on scheduled overseas commercial operations.

(3) Standards and procedures in regard to flight crew licensing are under continual review, both internationally at ICAO and in Australia. The variation referred to above was part of this continual review process which has led to many improvements in Australian air safety over the years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 August 1986 (Hansard, page 133-135) Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice, concerning the estimate of the number of unemployment benefit recipients in 1986-87. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The estimate of the number of unemployment benefit recipients in 1986-87 is based on forecasts of the number of unemployed persons and of the ratio of recipients to unemployed. The number of unemployed persons, in turn, depends upon the rate of growth of employment and the rate of growth of the labour force.

Employment grew very strongly in 1985-86 (3.9 per cent) and a slow-down to about 1.75 per cent is expected in 1986-87. Much of the forecast growth in the average level of employment for 1986-87 is accounted for by the strong increase in employment through the course of 1985-86. Employment growth is expected to be modest through the remainder of 1986-87.

The labour force participation rate (and, therefore, the labour force) grew strongly through 1985-86 and is currently at a high level. It is expected that the participation rate will level out and perhaps decline a little through 1986-87 due, in part, to the weakening in labour demand. This would slow the rate of growth of the labour force.
The above considerations imply some increase in the unemployment rate in 1986-87 from its average level of 7.9 per cent in 1985-86.

There has been a long-term rising trend in the number of unemployment benefit recipients as a proportion of the number of unemployed persons. In 1985-86, the ratio was 95.5 per cent, compared with 94.6 per cent in 1984-85 and 78.9 per cent in 1981-82. A further increase in this ratio was assumed for 1986-87, before allowance for the improvements in unemployment benefit administration announced in the Budget.

On the foregoing basis, the number of unemployment benefit recipients was estimated to rise from 559,000 in 1985-86 to 605,000 in 1986-87. The administrative improvements announced in the Budget are estimated to reduce this number to 595,000, which is the basis of the Budget estimate of unemployment benefit outlays.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: African National Congress: South West African People's Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government made a decision to fund the African National Congress and the South West African People's Organisation via the Commonwealth Secretariat or some other means; if so, what is the amount of the allocation, how is the allocation to be administered, what conditions apply to the use of the allocated money, and which Government Department is responsible for this expenditure; if not, does the Government have any intention of providing funds to these organisations in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government does not fund the African National Congress (ANC) and the South West African Peoples Organisation (SWAPO) via the Commonwealth Secretariat.

The Government position regarding the representation of the ANC and SWAPO in Australia was stated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 26 October 1983. No government funding is made available to either organisation in respect of the information offices they have established.

The Government does, however, provide funding for a limited range of humanitarian programs for southern Africa and in some instances the southern African nationalist movements are eligible for assistance under these programs. These programs are:

provision of undergraduate scholarships in Australia for black South African and Namibian refugees. This program is managed by the Commonwealth Secretariat in London and is open to student nominations from the nationalist movements (ANC/SWAPO/ and Pan Africanist Congress);
humanitarian assistance through multilateral channel to various United Nations Funds for Namibian and southern African refugees, including education ($320,000 in 1985/86);
a scholarship program for tertiary studies in South Africa for black South Africans, administered since 1983 through the Australian mission in Pretoria (A$84,000 in 1984/85);

a program through non-government organisations for trade union training and post graduate study in Australia. These two programs are administered by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau in co-operation with the ACTU and the Australian Council of Churches (A$100,000 in 1985/86);

The Government has made provision in the 1986/87 Budget to establish a humanitarian assistance program for black South Africans, Namibian and black South African refugees amounting to $5 million over five years. This program will be available for education and training, including members of the nationalist movements. The program will enable a considerable expansion of existing activities outlined above and will be managed by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and the Department of Foreign Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information is known, or held, by the Department of Foreign Affairs or any other Department, about a West German political organisation known as ``Hanns Seidel Foundation''.
(2) What, if any, leading West German political figures have affiliations with the Foundation.
(3) Is any West German political party affiliated with the Foundation.
(4) Has any delegation or representative from the Hanns Seidel Foundation visited Australia in 1986 or any other time, if so, what are details of such visit or visits.
(5) If this visit or visits took place what was the purpose of such visits to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Hanns Seidel Foundation was set up in October 1961 in memory of Hanns Seidel, Premier of Bavaria 1957-1960.

The avowed aim of the Foundation is to promote political education on a Christian basis. It is proposed to collectivist ideologies. To achieve its aim the Foundation has a number of Departments concentrating on research, education, foreign relations and development.

In the Federal Republic of Germany it organises seminars, specialist conferences and meetings on a large range of current political, education, and ethical topics. It organises training workshops in many areas, for example, trade unionism and youth leadership. Both Germans and foreigners attend these events with the financial assistance of the Foundation.

Outside the Federal Republic of Germany the Foundation runs educational, training and health projects in countries in Africa, Central and South America, the Middle East, South East Asia and the Pacific. In these countries, the Foundation has a local partner organisation, often a church body.

(2) and (3.) The Hanns Seidel Foundation is directly associated with the Christian Social Union party (CSU). The CSU forms the Government in the State of Bavaria and is a participant in the Federal Coalition Government. The Premier of Bavaria, Mr Franz Joseph Strauss, is a member of the Board of the Foundation.
(4) and (5). The Government has no knowledge of a visit or visits by members of the Hanns Seidel Foundation to Australia.
