QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 12 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Communications in the light of material contained in an article by Anthony McAdam in The Bulletin of 10 June 1986, instigate an investigation into the decision of Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) management to have Mr Mark Aarons produce the radio series titled ``Nazis in Australia'' and to hire Mr John Loftus as his co-researcher; if not, why not.

(2) Will the Minister investigate why, given the highly controversial nature of the series, no reputable historian of World War II appears to have been involved either in the programs or as a consultant.

(3) Did the Corporation or management of the ABC responsible for ABC programs take any steps to ensure that the programs would be fair-minded and intellectually defensible; if so, what steps; and if not, why not.

(4) Is the Minister concerned about the program's smear by insinuation of thousands of Australian citizens in several ethnic communities who share the universal Australian loathing of Nazism and, if so, will he ensure that disciplinary action is taken against the officers of the ABC concerned.

(5) Do these programs violate the ABC's own explicit guidelines referring to balanced and fair-minded coverage of controversial issues; if so, will the Minister ensure that the ABC will, in the near future, broadcast a prominently featured and genuinely open discussion of the issues raised by the Aarons-Loftus series to which those ethnic communities smeared by insinuation in the programs can nominate their own spokesmen.
(6) How much did the ABC spend on research and travel in the preparation of the radio series.
(7) How much was Mr Loftus paid for his contribution to the series.
(8) How much did the ABC spend on the lavish pre-broadcast press advertisements.

(9) Was Mr Laurie Aarons, the former national secretary of the Communist Party of Australia, in any way engaged in researching the series; if so, in what capacity and what was he paid for his services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has pointed out that this question relates to a programming matter and it is inappropriate for him to comment. Nevertheless he sought the advice of the ABC about questions (2) to (9) which is included in the following response.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The ABC as an independent statutory authority is able to make its own programming decisions and I do not consider it appropriate to interfere in these matters.

(2) `Background Briefing-Nazis in Australia' did use a reputable historian of World War II. Professor Raoul Hilberg was interviewed in the series, and his information also was used in preparation for the programs. The producers, needless to say, read widely in preparation for the programs and a bibliography of the histories used in research would include many eminent, authoritative and internationally recognised historians.

Professor Hilberg is recognised as one of the international experts on the Jewish Holocaust, and has testified in cases involving war criminals living in America. U.S. courts have described him as ``eminently qualified'' to give such expert testimony.

(3) Yes, the Corporation did take such steps as it does with all its programs. The story is an important one. Mark Aarons is a senior journalist and producer with the ABC. The series was carefully researched and documented. Other senior people worked with and assisted Mr Aarons in his research and production, and each program was listened to by lawyers and editorial management before it went to air.

(4) The programs did not smear any large groups by insinuation. The programs dealt only with the activities of certain groups who collaborated with the Nazi Government. At no time was anything said which concerned or implicated all the members of any European Community. The programs did not imply that those groups who collaborated with the Nazi authorities were supported by significant numbers of any regional population. The programs documented and investigated the history of some individuals and suggested a further investigation would reveal others who may have escaped the international judicial processes that were taking place after World War II.

(5) The programs did not violate the ABC's guidelines on the coverage of controversial issues. They comprised journalistic investigation, using original material, which formed part of the process of community discussion and debate on a very important issue. The ABC has documentation and evidence for the issues raised in its programs.

(6) There are two major components of the research involved in the preparation of the programs. One component comprised ongoing research, which falls within the normal salary and operational budgets allocated to the Talks Unit. The other major component was an overseas program gathering assignment, which is standard practice within the ABC for researching a story with such a significant overseas focus. Mark Aarons undertook a trip to Washington, London and Zagreb in June/July 1985. In addition to the standard staff travelling allowance, the costs involved were $3000 in airfares, and research costs of approximately $1500, covering search fees, photocopies of archival material and other necessary costs associated with an investigative project.
During this trip Mark Aarons secured much of the material which was central to the accuracy of the program.

(7) Mr Loftus was paid a fee which covered a return airfare Boston/Sydney, two internal airfares in the United States for the purpose of assisting Mark Aarons in research in that country, and a fee based on standard rates for research, scripting, and his on-air contributions to the programs. As is usual practice within the ABC, the fee is regarded as a confidential agreement between Mr Loftus and the ABC.

(8) The ABC arranged for a series of press advertisements at a level considered appropriate for a major national radio feature series. Because of the importance to the community of the issues covered in the programs, the ABC considered that publicity warranted a high priority.
The total cost of press advertising was $23,460.15, comprising $4,102.76 in production costs, and $19,357.39 for the advertising space.
(9) Mr Laurie Aarons (Mr Mark Aarons father) was not engaged in researching the series.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the facility known as `call charge recording' available to subscribers to Telecom who wish to have an itemized telephone account for STD and ISD calls, if so, how widespread is the availability of this service.

(2) Does the provision of this service involve a connection fee of $24 and an annual fee of $20. If so, how does the Minister for Communications justify these charges, given that there is no charge for itemizing STD and ISD calls in countries such as Canada and the USA, and that in these countries local calls are free of charge.

(3) Is it possible for Telecom subscribers, other than those with a PABX system, to obtain an itemized account for local calls; if not, how can subscribers verify that they are being charged correctly for local calls.
(4) If such a service is not available, will the Minister consider introducing the service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Both ISD and STD Call Charge Record (CCR) are available to Telecom customers.

ISD/CCR is currently available to approximately 3.3 million customers and will ultimately be provided to all customers as a standard service. On the other hand, STD/CCR is provided as an optional service and is available, within exchange capacity limitations, in all capital cities and the regional centres of Geelong and Mornington (Vic) and the Gold Coast (Qld). Further expansion in country areas is planned from 1987-88.

(2) Because of the very large volume of STD calls, the provision of STD/CCR involves considerable additional capital investment by Telecom in major exchange equipment modifications and the provision of extensive data processing facilities. For this reason, Telecom applies a once only fee of $20 for connection to the service and an annual service fee of $24. Telecom also charges 10 cents usage fee per itemised STD call.

However, as ISD call volumes are much lower, ISD/CCR can be provided at much less expense to Telecom and no charges apply for connection to the service. The only applicable charge is $1.20 each time an itemised statement of calls is requested.
(3) Telecom's metering system does not allow for the provision of an itemised statement of local calls.
However, there are several `in-house' facilities which Telecom uses to continuously monitor the performance of the metering system to ensure its accuracy.

(4) The provision of local call CCR would require a major restructure of the telephone metering system as well as the provision of extensive data processing facilities. Telecom is not able to commit the very high level of capital investment required to provide this service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What criteria does the Government use when evaluating applications to export military equipment from Australia.
(2) Which Australian-based public, or private, manufacturers have been granted permission to export military equipment in the past 5 years.
(3) What categories of military equipment were exported by such manufacturers in the same period.
(4) Which governments or private organisations purchased the above exports.
(5) Does Australia still rank 12th in the list of defence equipment exporting countries as placed in the table put out by the Stockholm Peace Research Institute in 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's policy is to exercise close control over the export of defence materiel. Applications for the export of defence materiel are therefore considered on a case-by-case basis. They are not approved to countries against which the United Nations Security Council has decided to take enforcement measures or where there are international instruments of proscription, to which Australia is party.
The criteria used in judging the applications comprise:

Australian foreign policy interests (Australia does not generally export defence materiel to countries involved in, or likely to become involved in, military conflict or where there is strong evidence that the materiel would be used primarily in the suppression of legitimate domestic opposition);
the viability of Australia's defence industries.

(2) Office of Defence Production, Andrew Antennas, Bullet Resistent Equipment Co, Miltec Systems, Fairey Australasia Pty Ltd, PJP Marine, GEC Marconi, Smith Industries Pty Ltd, Wormald Fire Systems, Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation Scott-Xtek Pty Ltd, McDonnell-Douglas, Walkers Ltd, JRA Ltd, James N. Kirkby Pty Ltd, Corn Products Fielders, Dept of Local Government and Administrative Services, North Queensland Engineers and Agents, Keogh Wood Management Pty Ltd, Mack Trucks Aust Pty Ltd, Precision Tools Annexa (trading as PTA Engineering), Cleveland Marine, Australian Training Aids Ltd.

(3) Bombs, rifles and spares, firing device demolition, bomb charges, ammunition, base couplings, target silhouettes, HF communications equipment, body armour jackets, muzzle velocity indicators, surface trip flates, personal military equipment, propellant, protection plate anti-armour, amphibian collapsible canoes, mechanical items for demonstrator mines, fire fighting system components, bomb retarding fins, stun grenades, F/A-18 parts, landing craft spares, 66MM launcher (empty and inert), harpoon missile cases, smoke generators, detonators, land rovers 6 x 6, guided structural shell, fuses, sleeping bags, phosphorous oxychloride, ex RAAF Hercules aircraft and spares, patrol craft, trucks (army style), shafts (for standard missile parts), aluminium boats, blank firing attachments, rifle cleaning kits, training aids, radio controlled target equipment and associated equipment.

(4) Government/Defence Forces-New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Sri Lanka, Singapore, Bahamas, Brunei, Denmark, United States of America, United Kingdom, Malaysia, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Norway, Yemen, Algeria, Colombia, France, Thailand, Pakistan, Jordan, Qatar, Oman, India, Abu Dhabi, Nepal, Indonesia, United Arab Emirates, Nigeria, Kuwait, Botswana, Egypt, Belgium, Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong, Mauritius, Portugal, Tonga, Brazil, Holland.

Private Organisations-Mertonbond Pty Ltd, UK, A B Bofors, Sweden, Marconi Underwater Systems Ltd, England, McDonnell-Douglas, USA, New Zealand Starches, NZ, Ford and Vlahos, Alabama, USA, Lockheed Western Export Co, USA, General Dynamics, Pomona Div, USA.

(5) Australia was ranked 12th in the list of defence exporting countries in table 8.1 of the 1978 yearbook Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) and 10th in the 1980 yearbook. As with any statistics of this kind, there are data and definitional problems. Further, the SIPRI statistics, particularly at the lower end of the ranking, are sensitive to the use of SIPRI trend indicators and the tables are intended to be representative of arms trade patterns rather than absolute levels of exports. These reservations notwithstanding, a small group of countries dominate arms exports (with the first five ranked countries accounting for over 90 per cent of total exports), and in these years, Australia accounted for only 0.2 of 1 per cent and 0.7 of 1 per cent of world arms exports. Australia has not been given a separate ranking in the SIPRI yearbooks since 1980. Australia is also not given a separate ranking in the US Arms Control and Disarmament Agency's publication `World Military Expenditures and Arms Transfers-1985'.

(2) If there is any significant difference in the occurrence of injuries between male and female cadets, can the Minister give any explanation for this difference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes; however, the monitoring is done at Unit level. The statistics are not collated centrally because the manpower and computing resources which would allow central collation and comparison are not available. The comparative injury records requested cannot, therefore, be provided.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Selection Committee

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were the members of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Section Committee appointed by you on 25 May 1984 for a 3 year period.

(2) Was the function of the Committee ``to select persons other than the Chairman, Managing Director and Government Representative (8 persons in total in each case) to be nominated to the Minister for Primary Industry for appointment by him as members of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation.''

(3) Did the Committee furnish to you by 31 May 1985 `` . . . the names of eight persons considered by the Committee to be suitable for appointment as members of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation.''
(4) Were not all the nominations to the Corporation appointed by you for a two or three year period beginning on 2 July 1985.
(5) Why has the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Selection Committee continued to exist.
(6) What public funds have been expended by the Committee since 2 July 1985.
(7) What would be the estimated expenditure of the Authority till 30 June 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No, members of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee were appointed on 25 June 1984 for a 3 year period.

(2) The original function of the Committee as established by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) Selection Committee Act No. 59 of 1984 was to select persons to be nominated to the Minister for appointment as members of the AMLC, other than the Chairman, Managing Director and Government Representative.

Following the enactment of the Australian Meat and Livestock legislation (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Act No. 13 of 1985 the Selection Committee was given the additional function of selecting persons for nomination to the Minister for appointment as members of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation.

(5) There is a need to have a selection mechanism in place to arrange for nominations when the fixed terms of Corporation members expire, or in the event of casual vacancies (resignation, death) arising.

(6) Under section 37 of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act 1977 all costs and expenses of the Selection Committee, including remuneration and allowances of the Chairman, Acting Chairman, Committee members and deputies and staff and consultants to that Committee are met in the first instance by the AMLC. The AMLC is required to notify the AMLRDC as soon as possible of all costs and expenses specifically relating to AMLRDC selections and is reimbursed such monies. The AMLC is funded from industry livestock slaughter levies and livestock export charges and no public funds are involved.

In the case of the AMLRDC the Government matches approved expenditure and therefore 50% of the costs relating to the selection of members for the AMLRDC are obtained from public monies with the remainder being industry funded.
Since 2 July 1985 no expenditure has been incurred by the Selection Committee on behalf of the AMLRDC and consequently no public monies have been expended.
(a) in 1983-84 was $68,027 none of which related to AMLRDC nominations
(b) in 1984-85 was $67,013 of which $63,694 related to AMLRDC nominations
(c) in 1985-86 was $38,914 none of which related to AMLRDC nominations
(d) is estimated for 1986-87 at $75,000 of which some $35,000 could relate to AMLRDC nominations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1986, Senator Hill asked me a question without notice regarding the effects of the current industrial dispute at Broken Hill, on Broken Hill and Port Pirie. Senator Hill asked:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the refusal of mine workers at Broken Hill to comply with an interim award handed down by Justice Fisher. Is the Government aware of the effect this industrial dispute will have not only on Broken Hill but also on Broken Hill Associated Smelters which employs some 1,480 workers in Port Pirie and which, of course, is reliant on ore from Broken Hill? What action will the Government take to ensure compliance with the award noting that it has condemned businessmen for advocating breaches of the law in recent days and that the Government subscribes to our highly centralised industrial relations system and the strict application of our rigid award system?
The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government has been monitoring the ongoing industrial situation at Broken Hill and is aware of the implications which any prolonged stoppage could have for the communities of Broken Hill and Port Pirie.

It was the Government's concern over this matter which led to the meetings the Minister for Resources and Energy and myself had with unions and employers, on 30 May and 2 June this year respectively, to be briefed on developments. The Commonwealth has been involved in other meetings with the parties.

On 21 July the parties to the dispute agreed to an interim settlement which resulted in a return to work at Broken Hill on 22 July. The outstanding safety and other issues relevant to the dispute have been the subject of an investigation by a Technical Committee chiefly representative of the New South Wales Department of Industrial Relations which, I understand, presented its findings to the parties on 22 September. The parties have since been studying the report and having discussions on its findings and I understand that recourse is available to the New South Wales Industrial Commission should aspects be incapable of resolution.

With regard to the interim award handed down by Justice Fisher of the State Industrial Commission which the honourable senator has raised, I am advised that this award was rescinded by a Full Bench of that Commission on 25 July following the signing of a new agreement between the parties on 21 July. It should be emphasised that this dispute has principally been a matter for the New South Wales Government and the State Industrial Commission although the Commonwealth Government has remained available to assist in any appropriate way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 October 1986 (Hansard, page 1192), Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. His question concerned a proposal by the Australasian Meat Industry Employee's Union to export Merino rams and semen. The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: The current guidelines covering the export of Merino rams and genetic material include provisions that
Export of up to 300 Merino rams per year with a sale price of more than $1,000 will be permitted.
All rams purchased for export to be sold at a designated export auction and declared for export at the fall of the hammer.

Prior to being offered for possible export at an export sale, all rams must comply with standard animal health and fertility requirements; these requirements are set by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service of the Department of Primary Industry.
Restricted Goods Export Permits (RGEP) to be issued at the time of export in accordance with the requirements of Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations.
There is a total ban on the export of Merino ewes, semen and other genetic material
- except for trade with New Zealand which is free of restrictions.
A review is currently being undertaken into the export of Merino rams and genetic material.

In addition to the above mentioned restrictions, all animals leaving Australia must be sent by an exporter licensed by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and such exports are subject to the issue of a RGEP. As Minister for Primary Industry, I and my delegates are empowered to issue RGEP's. Any application not strictly satisfying the necessary requirements would be rejected.
